'di gnyis ni byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pa brtan pa'i sems can rnams la lhag pa'i bsam pa bzang po 'jug par 'gyur ba yin te/ gnyis gang zhe na/ phan pa bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang bde ba bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa'o/ / de la phan pa bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa ni mi dge ba'i gnas nas bton nas/ dge ba'i gnas su 'god par 'dod pa gang yin pa'o/ / bde ba bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa ni sems can phongs pa dang / mgon med pa dang / rten med pa rnams la nyon mongs pa can spangs te/ phan pa'i dngos po sgrub par 'dod pa gang yin pa'o/ /

A bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm [enlightenment] mind exhibits two salutary forms of superior attitude[164] toward sentient beings. What are they? They are the beneficial superior attitude and the superior attitude that relates to happiness. Regarding these, the beneficial superior attitude is the desire to cause [sentient beings] to turn away from opportunities [to engage in] nonvirtuous [actions] and become established in opportunities [to engage in] virtuous [actions]. The superior attitude that relates to happiness is the desire to provide those sentient beings who have fallen into misfortune, who have no protector, and who have no shelter with the things that will assist them and free them from their state of affliction.
[sbyor ba gnyis]
TWO FORMS OF APPLICATION [I.2.10]

'di gnyis ni byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pa brtan pa'i sbyor ba yin te/ lhag pa'i bsam pa'i sbyor ba dang / sgrub pa'i sbyor ba'o/ / de la lhag pa'i bsam pa'i sbyor ba ni phan pa bya ba dang / bde ba bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa de nyid nyin gcig bzhin du yang dag par spel ba'o/ / sgrub pa'i sbyor ba ni nyin gcig bzhin du bdag gis sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su smin par byed pa'i sbyor ba dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa'i sbyor ba nyid la brten nas ci nus ci lcogs kyis sems can rnams la yang phan pa dang / bde ba sgrub pa'i sbyor ba'o/ /

A bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm [enlightenment] mind employs two [kinds of] application: (1) the application that relates to [one’s] superior attitude and (2) the application that relates to [one’s] conduct. The application that relates to [a bodhisattva’s] superior attitude is the daily strengthening of the superior attitude that wishes to benefit [sentient beings] and make [them] happy. The application that relates to [a bodhisattva’s] conduct is both [one’s] daily activities [that seek] to ripen the spiritual qualities of a buddha within oneself and, relying upon the application that relates to [a bodhisattva’s] superior attitude, [one’s daily] activities [that seek] to provide sentient beings with as much benefit and happiness as [one’s] power and strength will allow.
[dge ba'i chos chen po 'du ba'i sgo]
TWO GREAT DOORS FOR GAINING VIRTUOUS QUALITIES [I.2.11]

'di gnyis ni byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pa brtan pa'i dge ba'i chos chen po 'du ba'i sgo yin te/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub yang dag par bsgrub pa'i phyir bdag gi don la sbyor ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi sdug bsngal thams cad bsal ba'i phyir gzhan gyi don la sbyor ba'o/ / 'du ba'i sgo gnyis ji lta ba bzhin du dge ba'i chos kyi tshogs chen po gnyis dang / dge ba'i chos kyi phung po dpag tu med pa gnyis kyang de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

There are two great doors by which a bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm [enlightenment] mind gains virtuous qualities: (1) the application that pursues one’s own aim in order to achieve unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment and (2) the application that pursues the aims of others in order to liberate all sentient beings from every form of suffering. As with [the explanation for] the two sources of virtuous qualities, a similar [description should be made with regard to what are referred to as] the two great stores of virtuous qualities and the two immeasurable heaps of virtuous qualities.
[khyad par du 'phags pa gnyis]
TWO FORMS OF SUPERIORITY [I.2.12]

'di gnyis ni byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pa brtan pa'i sems bskyed pa nas bzung ste/ byang chub kyi phyir dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa ni de las gzhan pa'i dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa las khyad par du 'phags pa yin te/ rgyu khyad par du 'phags pa dang / 'bras bu khyad par du 'phags pa'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa de ni bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi rgyu yin te/ de yang de'i 'bras bu yin no/ / de las gzhan pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyi dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa yang de lta ma yin na/ de las gzhan pa'i sems can rnams kyis lta ci smos/ de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa ni de las gzhan pa'i dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa thams cad las rgyu dang 'bras bu'i ngo bos khyad par du 'phags pa yin no/ /

From the time that [a bodhisattva] first generates [enlightenment] mind, there are two forms of superiority regarding the acquisition of virtue for the sake of enlightenment by one who has newly generated [enlightenment] mind as compared with the acquisition of virtue by anyone other than that [bodhisattva]. [They are] (1) the superiority that relates to the cause and (2) the superiority that relates to the result. The acquisition of virtue by a bodhisattva is indeed the cause for unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment, and [supreme enlightenment] is the result of that [acquisition of virtue]. This is not the case for the acquisition of virtue by all those other listeners and solitary realizers, much less [for the acquisition of virtue] by any beings other than [the listeners and solitary realizers]. Therefore, the acquisition of virtue by bodhisattvas is abundantly superior to the acquisition of virtue by all others, both in terms of its causal nature and in terms of its result.
[phan yon gnyis]
TWO BENEFITS OF GENERATING ENLIGHTENMENT MIND [I.2.13]

'di gnyis ni byang chub sems dpa' dang po'i sems bskyed pa brtan pa'i sems bskyed pa'i phan yon yin te/ sems bskyed ma thag gis kyang sems can thams cad kyi yon gnas su gyur pa dang / bla mar gyur pa dang / bsod nams kyi zhing dang / skye dgu rnams kyi pha dang 'dra bar gyur pa dang / gnod pa med pa'i bsod nams yongs su 'dzin par byed do/ / de las gnod pa med pa'i bsod nams ni gang dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa' 'khor los sgyur ba kun nas bsrung ba'i nyis 'gyur gyis bsrung ba yin te/ kun nas bsrung ba de dag de la rtag tu nye bar gnas pas/ gnyid log gam/ myos par gyur pa'am/ bag med par gyur pa na yang / gdug pa'am gnod sbyin nam/ mi ma yin pa gnyug mar gnas pa rnams kyis gtse bar mi nus pa'o/ /

These are the two benefits of generating [enlightenment] mind that are gained by a bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm [enlightenment] mind: (1) As soon as [one] has generated [enlightenment] mind, [one] becomes worthy of being venerated[165] by all sentient beings; [one] becomes worthy of honor;[166] [one] becomes a field of merit and is like a father to all beings. (2) One also acquires the merit that will keep one from being harmed. Regarding this [latter point], the merit that keeps [a bodhisattva] from being harmed is such that the bodhisattva who possesses it is safeguarded in a manner that is twice as great as the [form of] protection [experienced] by a wheel ruler.[167] Because it is a form of protection that is always present, neither malicious beings, nor harmful spirits, nor demons, nor local guardian spirits are able to harm [such a bodhisattva], even when he or she is asleep, or in an excited[168] or inattentive state of mind.

tshe brjes pa'i 'og tu yang byang chub sems dpa' de ni bsod nams yongs su bzung ba des na/ gnod pa nyung zhing rang bzhin gyis gnod pa med pa yin te/ gnod pa yun ring ba dang / drag pos 'debs par mi 'gyur ro/ / de lus dang ngag gis sems can rnams kyi don dang / sems can gyi bya ba dag la rtsol ba dang chos ston pa na shas cher lus ngal bar mi 'gyur zhing / brjed ngas par mi 'gyur la/ sems nyams par mi 'gyur ro/ / byang chub sems dpa'i rigs la gnas pa ni rang bzhin gyis kyang gnas ngan len shas chung ba yin la sems bskyed na ni 'di lta ste/ lus kyi gnas ngan len dang / sems kyi gnas ngan len gyi gnas ngan len shin tu chung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Even after a bodhisattva has taken on a different life, he or she meets with little harm and is by nature free of illness through the possession of that merit. He or she also does not experience harm that is long-lasting or intense. When [a bodhisattva] is striving physically or verbally [to accomplish] the welfare of beings or [to carry out] activities on behalf of sentient beings, or when [a bodhisattva] is teaching the Dharma, [his or her] body does not experience excessive weariness, [his or her] recollection does not become clouded, and [his or her] mind does not become impaired. A bodhisattva who is established in the [Great Vehicle’s] spiritual lineage is a person in whom [the condition of] indisposition[169] is naturally weak. And once he or she has generated [enlightenment] mind, then [that bodhisattva] becomes one in whom [the condition of] indisposition is much more weak, in terms of both indisposition of the body and indisposition of the mind.

gsang sngags kyi tshig dang / rig sngags kyi tshig sems can rnams kyi yams kyi nad dang / gnod pa dang / nad 'go ba zhi bar byed pa dag de las gzhan pa'i sems can gyi lag na 'dug pa ma grub pa rnams kyang de'i lag tu 'ongs na 'grub par 'gyur na/ grub pa dag lta ci smos/ lhag par yang bzod pa dang / des pa dang ldan te/ pha rol gyi gnod pa byas pa bzod pa yin no/ / gzhan la yang gnod pa mi byed la/ gzhan gyis gzhan la gnod pa byed pa mthong ngam thos na yang shin tu mi dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / de'i nye ba'i nyon mongs pa khong khro ba dang / phrag dog dang / g.yo dang 'chab pa la sogs pa rnams kyang bcom ste/ nyams smad pas brgya la spyod par gyur na yang myur du 'bral bar 'gyur ro/ / de grong gi gnas gang na gnas pa de yang 'jigs pa dang / 'jigs par 'gyur ba dang / mu ge'i nyes pa rnams dang / mi ma yin pas byas pa'i gnod pa ma byung ba rnams ni 'byung bar mi 'gyur la/ byung ba rnams ni rnam par zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

The mantra formulas and vidyā spells [that are meant] to ward off the disease, misfortune, and contagion of sentient beings but that prove unsuccessful in the hands of someone else do succeed when carried out by that [bodhisattva]. Needless to say, those [mantra formulas and vidyā spells] that are successful [in the hands of others will also succeed when carried out by that bodhisattva]. [A bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm form of enlightenment mind] possesses an abundance of patience and gentleness; he or she endures the pain inflicted by others and does not inflict pain upon others. He or she is also greatly distressed upon learning[170] that someone is inflicting pain upon another person. The intensity of his or her secondary mental afflictions such as anger, envy, guile, dissembling,[171] and the like has been blunted. Those weakened forms that occasionally develop quickly disappear. The kinds of fears, sources of terror, scarcity of provisions, and other faults that can occur in an inhabited region, as well as the misfortunes that are caused by both human beings and [malevolent] spirits, do not occur [when a bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm enlightenment mind] is residing there. Any [such calamities] that have already arisen cease [when a bodhisattva who has newly generated a firm enlightenment mind resides there].

gal te byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pa de lan 'ga' zhig ngan song gi sems can dmyal ba rnams su skyes su zin kyang de ni gnod pa med pa'i bsod nams yongs su 'dzin pa'i rgyus shas cher shin tu myur bar thar bar 'gyur la/ sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba myong ba yang shin tu tshabs chung ba myong bar 'gyur te/ skye ba yang shin tu skye bar 'gyur ro/ / sems can de dag la yang snying rje'i sems bskyed par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar byang chub sems dpa' dang po sems bskyed pas ni gnod pa med pa'i bsod nams yongs su 'dzin pa las 'di lta bu dang / mthun pa'i phan yon mang po nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro/ /

If a bodhisattva who has newly generated [enlightenment] mind should take birth on a particular occasion in the hells that represent a level of the lower realms, he or she will ever so quickly escape from that hell because of possessing the merit that keeps one from being harmed. He or she will also only experience the slightest form of suffering there and will generate both an extremely strong form of aversion [toward the suffering of samsara] and the mental state of compassion toward those [other hell] beings. These are [some of] the numerous kinds of benefits that a bodhisattva who has newly generated [a firm enlightenment] mind experiences because he or she possesses the merit that keeps one from being harmed.
byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i gzhi'i rnal 'byor gyi gnas las/ sems bskyed pa'i le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //

Within [Book I of] The Stage of a Bodhisattva, [known as] “The Object of Mental Application That Relates to the Support,” this completes the second chapter, entitled “Generating [Enlightenment] Mind.”
bam po gnyis pa/
[bdag dang gzhan gyi don]
3. ONE’S OWN AND OTHERS’ AIMS

'di ltar sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gang zhe na/ de la rnam pa gsum du rig par bya'o zhes ston pa/ mdor bsdu na byang chub sems dpa' rnams gang la slob pa dang / ji ltar slob pa dang / gang dag slob pa de dag thams cad gcig tu bsdus pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa zhes bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams gang la slob ce na/ gnas bdun la slob ste/ gnas bdun po dag gang zhe na/ bdag gi don dang / gzhan gyi don dang / de kho na'i don dang / mthu dang / sems can yongs su smin par bya ba dang / rang gi sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su smin par bya ba dang / gnas bdun pa ni bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub bo/ /

What is the bodhisattva practice [that is undertaken] by those bodhisattvas who have generated [enlightenment] mind in the manner [that was just described]? In sum, the phrase “bodhisattva practice” refers to the combination of everything that is included [in the following three categories]: (1) [those subjects] in relation to which the bodhisattvas train themselves, (2) the manner in which they train themselves, and (3) those [individuals] who train themselves. What, then, are [the subjects] in relation to which bodhisattvas train themselves? They train themselves in relation to seven subjects.[172] What are the seven subjects? They are (1) one’s own aim, (2) others’ aims, (3) the meaning of reality, (4) spiritual power, (5) the ripening of sentient beings, (6) the ripening of a buddha’s qualities in oneself, and (7) true and complete enlightenment.
sdom ni/ bdag dang gzhan don de nyid don/ / mthu dang sems can smin byed dang / / rang gi sangs rgyas chos rnams smin/ / byang chub mchog ni bdun pa yin/ /
Summary verse: One’s own and others’ aims, the meaning of reality, Power, the twofold ripening of beings And of a buddha’s qualities in oneself, And the seventh is supreme enlightenment.

bdag dang gzhan gyi don gang zhe na/ mdor bsdu na bdag dang gzhan gyi don ni rnam pa bcur rig par bya'o/ / 'ba' zhig dang gzhan dang 'brel pa dang / phan pa'i rgyu dang / bde ba'i rgyu dang / rgyur bsdus pa dang / 'bras bur bsdus pa dang / tshe 'di pa dang / tshe rabs gzhan pa dang / gtan du ba dang / gtan du ba ma yin pa'o/ /

What are one’s own and others’ aims? In sum, one’s own aim and that of others should be understood as having ten aspects: (1) being exclusive, (2) being related to others, (3) being linked to what is beneficial, (4) being linked to happiness, (5) being included within a cause, (6) being included within a result, (7) being related to this life, (8) being related to a future life, (9) being perpetual, and (10) not being perpetual.
['ba' zhig pa]
THE QUALITIES OF EXCLUSIVITY AND OF BEING RELATED TO OTHERS [I.3.1–2]

de la bdag gi don dang gzhan gyi don 'ba' zhig pa gang yin pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i bya ba las thal zhing 'tsham pa ma yin pa'i phyir/ byang chub sems dpas yongs su shes par byas la spang bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams ni bslab par bya'o/ /

Regarding these [ten aspects], the quality of being exclusive as it relates both to one’s own aim and to the aims of others should be fully understood and then rejected by a bodhisattva, because [this quality] violates and is not in agreement[173] with the bodhisattva’s code of conduct. The [nine] remaining [aspects of one’s own aim and that of others] should [all] be practiced.

de la des yongs su shes nas spang bar bya ba gang yin pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i bdag gi don ni 'di yin te/ bdag nyid bde bar 'dod pa longs spyod pa dang / nye bar spyad pa rnams yongs su tshol ba dang / chos la ser sna byed pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpas bshad pa rnams yongs su tshol zhing 'dzin par byed pa dang / mtho ris 'dod pa mtho ris kyi don du tshul khrims dang / brtson 'grus rtsom zhing / bsam gtan dang / shes rab yang dag par blangs nas 'dug pa dang / 'jig rten gyi zang zing gi 'bras bu 'dod pa/ 'jig rten gyi zang zing 'thob pa'i rgyur de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la mchod pa byed pa dang rnyed pa 'dod pa rnyed pa'i rgyu dang /

The following are examples of a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of] one’s own aim that are exclusive and that he or she should fully understand and reject: (1) the seeking after and experiencing of forms of enjoyment by [a bodhisattva] who is desirous of [indulging in] pleasure for him- or herself; (2) the seeking after and retaining of Dharma [instructions] that buddhas and bodhisattvas have taught, by [a bodhisattva] who exercises stinginess regarding the Dharma; (3) the way of life that is engaged in by [a bodhisattva] who is desirous of [being reborn in] a celestial realm[174] in which he or she initiates [the practices of] morality and effort and undertakes [to cultivate] meditative absorption and wisdom in order [to attain rebirth in] a celestial realm; (4) the worshipping of a tathāgata caitya[175] by [a bodhisattva] who is desirous of [gaining] the result of worldly material things[176] and who engages in this act as a means of attaining worldly material things;

rnyed pa 'grub pa'i yang dag pa ma yin pa'i yon tan sna tshogs don med pa gzhan dag gi spro ba skyed pa dag ston pa dang / bdag la bsnyen bkur bya ba bdag gir bya bar 'dod pas bsnyen bkur bya ba bdag gir bya ba'i don du chos ma yin pas tshogs sdud par byed kyi/ chos kyis ma yin pa dang / gzhan gyi bran du gyur pa'i sems can rnams bdag gi bran du bya ba'i ched ka tsam gyi phyir bran byed pa las thar bar byed pa dang / sems can bcing bas bcings pa rnams bdag gi bya ba sgrub pa'i ched tsam gyi phyir bcings pa las thar bar byas te/ bdag nyid kyis 'ching bar byed pa dang / sems can chad pa la sogs pa'i 'jigs pas skrag pa rnams bdag nyid kyis 'jigs par byas pa'i ched tsam gyi phyir/ gzhan gyi chad pa la sogs pa'i 'jigs pa las thar bar byed pa dang / tshe 'di'i bde ba la gnas shing / sems can gyi don la nges par sems pa dang bral ba ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i bdag gi don 'ba' zhig yin par rig par bya ste/ de ltar 'di lta bu dang mthun pa rnams ni byang chub sems dpa' yongs su shes par byas nas spang bar bya ba gang yin pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i bdag gi don 'ba' zhig yin par rig par bya'o/ /

(5) the meaningless[177] and false utterings made to others by [a bodhisattva] who is desirous of [acquiring] material gain in which [he or she] tries to please [those persons] by telling them that they possess manifold good qualities in order to [obtain] material gain and procure material gain; (6) the attracting of a group [of spiritual followers] in a manner that is contrary to the Dharma and that is not in keeping with the Dharma by [a bodhisattva] who is desirous of obtaining acts of service [from those followers] for him- or herself and [who attracts a following] in order to obtain [such] acts of service; (7) the freeing of beings who were the servants of others from their state of servitude, so that [they may enter into] a state of servitude to you; (8) the freeing of beings who were bound in prison from their imprisonment only to bring them under your control so that they may be made to perform work for you; (9) the freeing of beings who are threatened by others with the dangers of undergoing [judicial] punishment and the like[178] in order to make them subject to the same dangers from you; and (10) the remaining in a state of ease during this life by a bodhisattva, without engaging in careful reflection about the welfare of others. These [descriptions] should be understood as [examples of activities in which] one’s own aim is being pursued exclusively. These and other similar kinds of bodhisattva activities that are understood to represent the exclusive pursuit of one’s own aim are [circumstances] that a bodhisattva should fully understand and reject.

byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa dang / bzod pa dang / snying rje sngon du 'gro ba'am/ byang chub tu yongs su bsngos pa'am/ mtho ris kyi phyir bsngos pa ni dus thams cad du bdag gi don gzhan dang 'brel pa kho na yin par rig par bya'o/ de ltar ji skad bstan pa'i rnam pa de dag la ma gtogs par de ma yin par de las bzlog pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bdag gi don thams cad ni gzhan gyi don dang 'brel pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

On the other hand, a bodhisattva’s [practice of] generosity and patience, whether they are preceded by compassion, dedicated to enlightenment, or [carried out] for the sake of [attaining rebirth in] a celestial realm, should be understood as always being [instances in which] one’s own aim is related to others.[179] Therefore, excluding those types [of activities] that were presented [earlier], all other [forms of the pursuit of] one’s own aim that are the opposite of those [examples] should be understood as [instances in which one’s own aim] is related to the aims of others.[180]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i gzhan gyi don 'ba' zhig yin pas/ byang chub sems dpas yongs su shes par byas nas spang bar bya ba ni 'di yin te/ lta ba log par zhugs pa dang / 'ong ba ma mthong ba dang / 'bras bu ma mthong ba'i sbyin pa dang / tshul khrims nyams pa dang / sgrub pa med pa gzhan dag la chos ston pa dang /

The following [two cases] are [examples of] a bodhisattva’s activities that exclusively carry out the aims of others and that a bodhisattva should fully understand and reject: (1) the generosity of [a bodhisattva] who holds a mistaken view, who does not consider that anything will come [in future lives from acts of generosity], and who does not believe [that the act of generosity will yield any] fruit; and (2) the teaching of Dharma to others by [a bodhisattva] whose morality has been damaged and who does not [him- or herself] cultivate the practice.

sa 'og ma las yang dag par 'das pa/ sa 'og ma'i dge ba'i chos sgrub pa dang / bsam gtan bsgyur ba la mkhas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de 'di ltar bsam gtan dag gis gnas nas bsam gtan bsgyur te/ smon lam btab na 'dod pa'i khams gang du 'dod pa der skye bar 'gyur ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' dbang thob pa phyogs bcu dag tu sprul pa sna tshogs pa dag gis sems can sna tshogs dag gi don byed pa dang / thub pa de de bzhin gshegs pa rang gi don mdzad zin pa stobs dang / mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos ma 'dres pa thams cad la brten nas/ sems can tshad med pa dag la don tshad med pa mdzad pa de yang gzhan gyi don 'ba' zhig yin par rig par bya'o/ /

The following should also be understood as [examples in which] the aims of others are being pursued exclusively: (1) the carrying out of virtuous qualities that relate to a lower stage by [a bodhisattva] who has transcended such a lower stage,[181] as well as (2) [the carrying out of virtuous qualities that are related to a lower stage] by a bodhisattva who is skilled at turning back[182] the meditative absorptions. In the latter case, even after having remained in the meditative absorptions, such [a bodhisattva] can avert [the natural power of] the meditative absorptions [to bring about rebirth in the higher realms] and, through [the power of] prayer, be born anywhere in the desire realm that he or she may wish [to be born]. [Two more examples are] (3) the performance of beneficial activities for the sake of manifold sentient beings by a bodhisattva who has attained mastery of the controlling powers[183] and [who carries out those activities] by [sending forth] a great variety of emanations into the ten directions; and (4) the performance of immeasurable forms of beneficial activities for the sake of an immeasurable number of sentient beings by a muni and a tathāgata who has completed [the perfection of] his own aim and [who carries out those activities] on the basis of the [one hundred and forty] unique qualities of a buddha,[184] which include the [ten] powers, the [four] forms of intrepid confidence, and so forth.

de la gzhan gyi don 'ba' zhig yin pa ji skad bstan pa snga ma gnyis ni byang chub sems dpas yongs su shes par byas nas spang bar bya ba yin no/ / de ma yin pa'i gzhan gyi don 'ba' zhig pa la ni lhur bslab par bya'o/ / rnam pa de dag las ma gtogs pa dang / de dag las bzlog pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gzhan gyi don thams cad ni bdag gi don dang 'brel pa yin te/ de la yang byang chub sems dpas bslab par bya'o/ /

Regarding these [six activities that accomplish the aims of others in an exclusive manner], the first two that were presented are [instances] that should be fully understood by a bodhisattva and rejected. However, [a bodhisattva] should train [him- or herself] with an ever-increasing degree of diligence in relation to the other [four examples that accomplish] the aims of others in an exclusive manner. Therefore, with the exception of those [six] types [of activities], all [other instances in which] bodhisattvas [pursue] the aims of others—including those that are the opposite [of the first two examples[185]]—represent [activities] that are also related to one’s own aim. [And, as such,] a bodhisattva should train [him- or herself] in relation to them as well.
don phan pa'i rgyu
THE QUALITY OF BEING LINKED TO WHAT IS BENEFICIAL [I.3.3]
byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don phan pa'i rgyu gang zhe na/
What is a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked to what is beneficial?

mdor bsdu na rnam pa lnga yod par rig par bya ste/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i mtshan nyid dang / phan 'dogs pa'i mtshan nyid dang / tshe 'di pa dang / tshe gzhan pa dang / zhi bar byed pa'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa' ni bdag kyang dge ba yongs su bzung ba dang / dge ba sogs pa che yang rung chung yang rung ste/ gang ci yang rung byed pa dang / gzhan yang dge ba yongs su bzung ba dang / dge ba sogs pa che yang rung chung yang rung ba yang dag par 'dzin du 'jug / 'dul bar byed/ 'dzud par byed/ 'jog par byed pa de dag ni byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don phan pa'i rgyu kha na ma tho ba med pa'i mtshan nyid yin par rig par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' bdag gam gzhan la yo byad kyi bde ba'am/ bsam gtan la gnas pa'i bde ba yang rung ste/ nyon mongs pa can spangs pa'i bde ba gang ci yang rung / nye bar sgrub pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don phan pa'i rgyu phan 'dogs pa'i mtshan nyid yin par rig par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don tshe 'di la phan pa la/ tshe gzhan na de lta bu ma yin pa yang yod/ tshe gzhan na phan la tshe 'di la de lta ma yin pa yang yod/ tshe gzhan la yang phan la tshe 'di la yang phan pa yang yod/ tshe gzhan na yang gnod la/ tshe 'di la yang gnod pa yang yod de/ bdag dang gzhan gyi don rnam pa bzhi po de yang chos yang dag par blang ba bzhi po dag tu go rim bzhin du ci rigs su blta bar bya'o/ /

In brief, it should be understood to have five aspects: (1) the characteristic of being irreproachable, (2) the characteristic of being favorable, (3) [the form that] relates to this life, (4) [the form that] relates to future lives, and (5) [the form that] promotes tranquility. Regarding these, whatever acquisition of virtue or accumulation of virtue, whether small or great, that a bodhisattva carries out, as well as [whatever] acquisition of virtue or accumulation of virtue, whether small or great, that he or she causes others to adopt, leads them [to carry out], introduces them to, and establishes them in, should be understood as the characteristic of being irreproachable as it relates to a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked to what is beneficial. Whatever happiness a bodhisattva might provide for him- or herself or for another that is free of affliction, whether it be a state of happiness that arises from the providing of assistance[186] or a state of happiness [that arises from any] of the meditative absorptions, this should be understood as the characteristic of being favorable as it relates to a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked to what is beneficial. There are [forms of] a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that are beneficial to this life but not future lives; [forms that are beneficial] to future lives but not this one; [forms that are beneficial] both to this life and to future lives; and [forms that are] beneficial neither to this life nor to future lives. These four [forms of a bodhisattva’s pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims should be recognized, in the same order and in the appropriate manner, as being related to the four ways of taking up what is right.
chos yang dag par blang ba bzhi po dag gang zhe na/
What are the four ways of taking up what is right?[187]

chos yang dag par blang ba da ltar byung ba na bde la phyi ma la rnam par smin pa sdug bsngal bar 'gyur ba yang yod/ chos yang dag par blang ba da ltar byung ba na sdug bsngal la/ phyi ma la yang rnam par smin pa bde ba yang yod/ da ltar byung ba na yang bde la/ phyi ma la yang rnam par smin pa bde ba yang yod/ da ltar byung ba na yang sdug bsngal la/ phyi ma la yang rnam par smin pa sdug bsngal ba yang yod de/ de dag gi rnam par dbye ba ni mdo las ji skad 'byung ba kho na bzhin du blta bar bya'o/ / de la mya ngan las 'das pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa yang dag par thob par byed pa dag dang / mya ngan las 'das pa'i phyogs 'jig rten pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos de dag ni mdor bsdu na byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don phan pa'i rgyu zhi bar byed pa zhes bya ba yin te/ thams cad las khyad par du 'phags pa bla na med pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

There are ways of taking up what is right that bring happiness in the present but have a ripening in the future that consists of suffering;[188] [ways of taking up what is right] that bring suffering in the present but have a ripening in the future that consists of happiness;[189] [ways of taking up what is right] that bring happiness in the present and also have a ripening in the future that consists of happiness;[190] and [ways of taking up what is right] that bring suffering in the present and also have a ripening in the future that consists of suffering.[191] These categories should be understood in the manner [in which they are presented] in the sutras. Regarding this [topic], in brief the worldly and transcendent [spiritual] qualities that either constitute nirvana, cause nirvana to be attained, or are conducive to [the attainment of] nirvana constitute [the fifth aspect of] a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked to what is beneficial—[namely, the one described as the form that] promotes tranquility. [Moreover, this aspect] should be understood as the most outstanding and unsurpassed [of the five].
[don bde ba'i rgyu]
THE QUALITY OF BEING LINKED TO HAPPINESS [I.3.4]
byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don bde ba'i rgyu gang zhe na/
What is a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of both] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked to a state of happiness?

mdor bsdu na bde ba rnam pa lngar bsdu bar rig par bya ste/ de la bde ba rnam pa lnga po ni 'di dag yin te/ rgyu bde ba dang / tshor ba bde ba dang / sdug bsngal gyi gnyen po'i bde ba dang / tshor ba'i rgyun chad pa'i bde ba dang / gnod pa med pa'i bde ba dang lnga'o/ /

In brief, it should be understood as being made up of five types of happiness. The five types of happiness are (1) the causal [aspect of] happiness; (2) the experiential [aspect of] happiness; (3) the [aspect of] happiness that is an antidote to suffering; (4) the [aspect of] happiness that cuts off feelings; and (5) the [aspect of] happiness that is freedom from harm.

de la bde ba'i phyogs kyi dbang po dang / yul gnyis dang / rgyu de las byung ba'i bde ba'i tshor bar 'gyur ba'i reg pa gang yin pa dang / tshe 'di'am tshe rabs gzhan du 'dod pa'i 'bras bu 'byung ba'i las gang yin pa ci yang rung / de thams cad gcig tu bsdus pa ni rgyu bde ba zhes bya ste/ 'di las gong na yang med/ 'di las lhag pa yang med do/ /

Regarding [the first of] these, the two types of faculty and object that are related to pleasant experiences, the contact that is caused by them[192] and that will lead to a pleasant experience, and any form of karma that will have a desirable result either as a seen event[193] or in some future life—all taken together as one—are called “the causal [aspect of] happiness.” There are no [causal elements] beyond these [three] and no more than these.

sdug bsngal rab tu zhi ba la mi ltos par rgyu bde bar bsdus pa'i rgyu gsum po de dag nyid las byung ba lus dang sems la phan 'dogs pa'i myong ba ni tshor ba bde ba zhes bya ste/ de yang mdor bsdu na rnam pa gnyis te/ zag pa dang bcas pa dang / zag pa med pa'o/ / de la zag pa med pa gang yin pa de ni slob pa dang / mi slob pa'i zag pa dang bcas pa ni khams gsum pa'i ste/ 'dod pa dang / gzugs dang / gzugs med pa dang ldan pa'o/ / de yang ci rigs par khams gsum pa thams cad kyi skye mched rnam pa drug gi bye brag las mig gi 'dus te reg pa las byung ba nas/ yid kyi 'dus te reg pa las byung ba'i bar dag go/ / rnam pa drug po de dag kyang rnam pa gnyis su 'gyur te/ lus kyi dang sems kyi'o/ / de la rnam par shes pa'i tshogs lnga dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i lus kyi'o/ / yid kyi rnam par shes pa dang mtshungs par ldan pa ni sems kyi'o/ /

The experience[194] that is favorable to body and mind and is produced by those very three causes included in the causal aspect of happiness, irrespective of the abatement of suffering,[195] is called “the experiential [aspect of] happiness.” Moreover, it is of two types: (1) that which is related to the outflows and (2) that which is free of the outflows.[196] Regarding them, [pleasant experiences] that are free of the outflows can be both a quality of [an ārya] who is still undergoing training[197] and a quality of [an arhat] who is beyond [the need to undergo any further] training.[198] Further, [pleasant experiences] that are related to the outflows are those of the three realms—[that is to say,] those that are related to the desire, form, and formless realms. All these [feelings] of the three realms can further be distinguished, in the appropriate manner, as being of six types according to the basis[199] [from which they arise], ranging from those that arise from contact with the eye to those that arise from contact with the mind.[200] These six types [of feelings] are also [understood as being subsumed within] two types: corporeal and mental. Regarding [this latter classification], [the feelings] that are related to the five collections of [sense] consciousness are corporeal, and the ones that are related to mind consciousness are mental.[201]

grang ba dang tsha ba dang / bkres pa dang / skom pa la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal rnam pa du ma dang / sna tshogs pa mang po 'byung ngo cog la/ grang ba dang / tsha ba dang / bkres pa dang / skom pa la sogs pa sdug bsngal gnyen pos zhi bar byas te/ sdug bsngal zhi bar gyur pa tsam po de nyid la bde ba'i blo skye ba gang yin pa de ni sdug bsngal gyi gnyen po'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ /

The notion of well-being that arises in relation to the mere quieting of an unpleasant experience, due to the abatement of [any of] the many diverse and varied forms of unpleasant [experiences] that can occur—such as cold, heat, hunger, thirst, and the like—through counteracting that cold, heat, hunger, thirst, and the like, is called “the aspect of happiness that is an antidote to suffering.”
'du shes dang tshor ba 'gog pa la snyoms par 'jug pa ni tshor ba'i rgyun chad pa'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ /
The state of composure that causes the cessation of conceptions and feelings[202] is called “the aspect of happiness that cuts off feelings.”

gnod pa med pa'i bde ba ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa bzhir rig par bya ste/ mngon par 'byung ba'i bde ba dang / rab tu dben pa'i bde ba dang / nye bar zhi ba'i bde ba dang / rdzogs par byang chub pa'i bde ba'o/ /

In brief, the happiness that is freedom from harm is of four types: (1) the happiness of departure; (2) the happiness of separation; (3) the happiness of tranquility; and (4) the happiness of complete enlightenment.

de la dad pas khyim nas khyim med par legs pa kho nar rab tu byung ste/ khyim so'i sdug bsngal rnam pa sna tshogs las nges par thar pa ni mngon par byung ba'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ / 'dod pa dang / sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos spangs te dben pas bsam gtan dang po la dben pa las skyes pa'i dga' ba dang / bde ba ni rab tu dben pa'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ / bsam gtan gnyis pa la sogs pa la rtog pa dang / dpyod pa nye bar zhi ba ni nye bar zhi ba'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ / nyon mongs pa thams cad dang gtan bral ba dang / shes bya'i dngos po yang dag par ji lta ba bzhin du mngon par rdzogs par byang chub pas bde ba gang yin pa de ni rdzogs par byang chub pa'i bde ba zhes bya'o/ /

[The happiness] of a person who has left home properly and entered the homeless state [motivated] by faith, and who has thereby gained freedom from the multiple forms of suffering that arise from attachment to the householder state, is called “the happiness of departure.” The joy and ease that is born of separation [from the desire realm and that occurs] in the first meditative absorption through the separation [that comes about] through having abandoned the objects of desire[203] as well as evil and nonvirtuous qualities, is called “the happiness of separation.” [The happiness that occurs] in the second meditative absorption and above, through having quelled [both] deliberation and reflection,[204] is called “the happiness of tranquility.” The happiness that arises both through having permanently freed oneself from all the mental afflictions and through having attained complete and perfect realization of [all] entities that need to be known as they truly are is called “the happiness of complete enlightenment.”

de la rgyu bde ba ni bde ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i phyir bde ba yin gyi/ ngo bo nyid kyis ni ma yin no/ / tshor ba'i bde ba ni rgyu'i dngos pos ni ma yin gyi ngo bo nyid kho nas so/ / sdug bsngal gyi gnyen po'i bde ba ni rgyu'i dngos pos kyang ma yin la/ ngo bo nyid kyis kyang ma yin te/ sdug bsngal zhi bar gyur pa tsam dang / sdug bsngal ba bsal bas bde ba yin no/ / tshor ba'i rgyun chad med pa'i bde ba ni/ rgyu'i dngos pos kyang ma yin/ ngo bo nyid kyis kyang ma yin/ sdug bsngal bsal bas kyang ma yin gyi/ 'di la tshor ba gang ci yang rung ba de ni sdug bsngal ba yin la/ yang dag par sdug bsngal ba/ dus de tsam zhig gnas pas zhi bar gyur pa ni bde ba ste/ gnod pa med pa'i bde bar gtogs so/ / tha ma rdzogs par byang chub kyi bde ba ni phyi ma la yang yang dag par sdug bsngal ba de ni gtan du zhi bar gyur la tshe 'di la yang nyon mongs pa'i phyogs kyi gnas ngan len rten la yod pa thams cad gtan med par gyur pa'i phyir bde ba yin no/ / gnod pa med pa de'i lhag ma rnams kyang tha ma de dang mthun pa dang / de'i phyogs yin pa dang / de 'dren pa yin pa'i phyir gnod pa med pa'i bde ba yin par rig par bya'o/ /

The causal aspect of happiness is identified as [a form of] happiness in that it is the cause of happiness; it does not represent happiness in terms of its essential nature. The experiential aspect of happiness is not [a form of happiness] by virtue of its causal nature; however, [it does represent happiness] in terms of its essential nature. The aspect of happiness that is an antidote to suffering is not [a form of happiness] either by virtue of its causal nature or in terms of its essential nature; rather, it is [a form of] happiness only in the sense of quieting [some form of] suffering—[which is to say,] by virtue of the fact that it brings about the removal of [some specific instance of] suffering. The aspect of happiness that cuts off feelings is not [a form of happiness] either by virtue of its causal nature, in terms of its essential nature, or in the sense of bringing about a removal of suffering; however, it is [a form of] happiness in that it is a state [of meditative composure] that one abides in for a limited period of time and that constitutes the cessation of suffering in its highest sense, as [indicated by Buddha] in the phrase: “Whatever feeling [is experienced] here is [a form of] suffering.” The final form[205] included in the [category of] happiness that is [described as] freedom from harm—that is, the happiness of complete enlightenment—represents happiness in the sense that it is the permanent cessation in the future[206] of that very same suffering in its highest sense [that was just mentioned] and, as a seen event,[207] the permanent removal of the forms of indisposition present in one’s being[208] that are related to the mental afflictions. The remaining [three forms] of [the category of] happiness that is [described as] freedom from harm should be understood as the happiness that is freedom from harm in that they conform to, are supportive of, or are conducive to that very [fourth and] final form.

de la byang chub sems dpa' ni phan pa'i phyogs kyi bde ba gang yin pa de nyid sems can rnams la sgrub par byed kyi/ gnod pa'i phyogs ni ma yin no/ / gnod pa'i phyogs kyi bde ba ni yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis yongs su shes par byas shing / yongs su shes par byas la/ de la sems can rnams 'dun pa bzlog par bya ste/ ci nus kyis de las bzlog cing bsal ba'i phyir 'bad par bya'o/ / phan par 'gyur ba gang yin pa de ni sdug bsngal dang 'brel du zin kyang byang chub sems dpa' thabs mkhas pa la brten nas sdug bsngal dang bcas pa dang / yid mi bde ba dang bcas par sems can rnams la mi 'dod bzhin du bsgrub par bya'o/ / mi phan par 'gyur ba gang yin pa de ni bde ba dang 'brel du zin kyang thabs mkhas pa la brten nas/ bde ba dang bcas pa dang yid bde ba dang bcas par sems can rnams mi dga' bzhin du bzlog par bya zhing drang bar bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], the bodhisattva should provide for sentient beings [those forms of] happiness that support what is beneficial, not [those forms] that support what is harmful. Moreover, after having fully and accurately realized with his or her wisdom the [forms of] happiness that support what is harmful, [a bodhisattva] should cause beings to give up any desire for them and, to the best of his or her ability, strive to draw them away and divert them from them. Through reliance upon skillful means, a bodhisattva should also provide for sentient beings what is beneficial [for them], even though it may be followed by [some form of] unpleasantness [in the near term] and they might not desire it because it is accompanied by [physical] pain and mental unhappiness. [Similarly,] through reliance upon skillful means, [a bodhisattva] should also draw sentient beings away from and divert them from what is harmful [for them], even though it is followed by [some form of] pleasantness [in the near term] and they might desire it because it is accompanied by [physical] pleasure and mental satisfaction.
de ci'i phyir zhe na/
What is the reason for this?

sdug bsngal dang bcas pa'i bde ba sgrub pa gang yin pa de dang bde ba dang bcas pa'i mi phan pa las bzlog pa de ni sems can rnams la phyis bde ba kho na yin par nges par rig par bya ba'i phyir ro/ / de bas na byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams la phan par 'dod pa gang yin pa de ni don gyis na bde ba 'dod pa yin par shes par bya'o/ / phan pa'i sbyin pa gang yin pa de ni bde ba sbyin pa yin par shes par bya ste/ 'di ltar phan pa ni rgyu lta bu yin la/ bde ba ni 'bras bu lta bu yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de lta bas na gang la la sems can rnams la phan pa dang ldan pa de ni bde ba dang ldan pa nyid yin par rig par bya'o/ /

It should be understood with certainty that providing for [sentient beings] what is beneficial [for them even though] it is accompanied by [some form of] unpleasantness and turning them away from what is harmful [for them even though] it is accompanied by [some form of] pleasantness is [done] so that sentient beings [will experience greater forms of] happiness in the future. Therefore, it should be recognized that the bodhisattva who desires what is beneficial for sentient beings also, in fact, desires happiness [for them]. Whoever provides what is beneficial [for beings] should also be recognized as providing [them with] happiness, because what is beneficial represents a cause and what is happiness represents a result. Therefore, anything that possesses [the quality of] being beneficial for sentient beings should be understood as possessing [the quality of] bringing them happiness.

de la tshe 'di dang tshe rabs gzhan du 'dod pa'i 'bras bur 'gyur ba'i las rgyu bde bar gtogs pa gang yin pa dang / sdug bsngal gyi gnyen po'i bde ba gang yin pa dang / tshor ba'i rgyun chad pa'i bde ba gang yin pa dang / gnod pa med pa'i bde ba gang yin pa de dag ni phan 'dogs pa dang / kha na ma tho ba med pa yin pas de dag byang chub sems dpas sems can rnams la spyad pa'i phyir dgos par nges par bsgrub par bya'o/ / tshor ba'i bde ba dang / rgyu bde ba dbang po dang / yul dang reg pas bsdus pa kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur ba dang / nyon mongs pa can dang / kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa mi phan pa dang mi 'phrod pa gang yin pa de ni bsgrub par mi bya'o/ / kun nas nyon mongs par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa can ma yin pa dang / kha na ma tho ba med pa phan pa dang / 'phrod pa gang yin pa de ni byang chub sems dpas sems can rnams la ci nus ci lcogs pa bzhin du bsgrub par bya'o/ / bdag nyid kyis kyang de bzhin du yang dag par spyad par bya'o/ / bslab par bya/ nyams su myong bar bya'o/ / 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bdag dang gzhan gyi don phan pa dang bde ba'i rgyu yin par rig par bya ste/ 'di las gong na yang med 'di las lhag pa yang med do/ /

With regard to this [overall topic], a bodhisattva should, unhesitatingly and [with unwavering devotion to this] as one’s sole aim, [seek to] provide sentient beings with whatever [forms of] karma both [are recognized as] having a desirable result—either as a seen event or in a future life—and are included in the causal aspect of happiness; with whatever [forms of] happiness are [of the type that is] an antidote to suffering; with whatever [forms of] happiness are [of the type that] cuts off feelings; and with whatever [forms of] happiness are [of the type that] is freedom from harm. [The reason for this is that] these [forms of happiness] are both beneficial and free of reproach. [A bodhisattva] should not, however, provide [sentient beings] with either [those forms of] the experiential aspect of happiness or [those forms of] object, faculty, or contact contained within the causal aspect of happiness that are afflicted [in nature] in [the sense] that they will lead to a state of affliction, and that are, [therefore,] reprehensible,[209] harmful, and unwholesome. On the other hand, a bodhisattva should, to the utmost of [his or her] ability and strength, pursue [for others] whatever [forms of the experiential aspect of happiness and whatever forms of object, faculty, or contact contained within the causal aspect of happiness] are not afflicted [in nature] in [the sense] that they will lead to a state of affliction, [and that are, therefore,] free of reproach, beneficial, and wholesome. Similarly, [a bodhisattva] should also engage in them him- or herself, train him- or herself in them, and experience them for him- or herself. This should be understood as the bodhisattvas’ [pursuit of] one’s own and others’ aims that is linked both to what is beneficial and to what [represents a state of] happiness. There are no [points relating to this topic] beyond these, and there are no [points] other than these.
[don rgyu dang 'bras bur bsdus pa]
THE ASPECTS OF BEING INCLUDED WITHIN A CAUSE OR A RESULT [I.3.5–6]
de la byang chub sems dpa'i bdag dang gzhan gyi don rgyu dang 'bras bur bsdus pa gang zhe na/
What are [the aspects of] a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of] one’s own and others’ aims that are included within a cause or a result?

mdor bsdu na rgyu yang rnam pa gsum yod la/ 'bras bu yang rnam pa gsum yod par rig par bya ste/ rnam par smin pa'i rgyu dang / rnam par smin pa'i 'bras bu dang / bsod nams kyi rgyu dang / bsod nams kyi 'bras bu dang / ye shes kyi rgyu dang / ye shes kyi 'bras bu'o/ /

In brief, it should be understood that there are three types of causes and three types of results: (1) the causes of the maturations, (2) the results of the maturations, (3) the causes of merit, (4) the results of merit, (5) the causes of wisdom, and (6) the results of wisdom.
[rnam par smin pa]
THE EIGHT MATURATIONS [I.3.5.1, I.3.6.1]
de la rnam par smin pa gang zhe na/
What are the maturations?

mdor bsdu na rnam par smin pa ni brgyad de/ tshe phun sum tshogs pa dang / kha dog phun sum tshogs pa dang / rigs phun sum tshogs pa dang / dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa dang / tshig btsun pa dang / dbang che bar grags pa nyid dang / skyes bu nyid dang / brgyad pa stobs phun sum tshogs pa nyid do/ /

In brief, there are eight kinds of [karmic] maturation: (1) excellence of life span; (2) excellence of physical appearance;[210] (3) excellence of family; (4) excellence of power; (5) the quality of having one’s speech accepted; (6) the quality of being regarded as eminent;[211] (7) the quality of being a man; and (8) the eighth is [excellence of] strength.

de la byang chub pa'i tshe phun sum tshogs pa ni tshe ring zhing yun ring du gnas pa nyid do/ / kha dog phun sum tshogs pa ni gzugs bzang zhing blta na sdug la mdzes pa nyid do/ / rigs phun sum tshogs pa ni rigs mthon po rnams su skye ba'o/ / dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa ni longs spyod che ba dang / rtsa 'jing che ba dang / 'khor phal che ba yin no/ / tshig btsun pa ni yid brtan du rung zhing yid ches pa yin te/ sems can rnams kyi rtsod pa byung ngo cog du tshad mar gzhog par 'os la/ gzhal glugs la g.yo byed pa dang / 'jal ba la g.yo byed pa la sogs pa dang / g.yo sgyu dang nor gtams pa la g.yo mi byed cing slu bar mi byed de/ gzhi des sems can rnams kyis tshig 'dzin par 'gyur ba de ni tshig btsun pa zhes bya'o/ / dbang che bar grags pa ni de'i grags pa chen po dang snyan pa 'di lta ste/ dpa' ba'am/ brtson pa'am/ brtan pa'am/ mkhas pa'am/ shes nyen che ba'am/ ngang tshul bzang ba'am/ bzo dang las kyi gnas rnam pa sna tshogs dag la lhag par rab dang phul du mkhas pa yan chad kyis 'jig rten du grags pa yin te/ gzhi des skye bo'i tshogs chen po'i bla mar gyur zhing / bkur stir bya ba dang / btsun par bya ba dang / ri mor bya ba dang / mchod par bya ba'i gnas su gyur pa de ni dbang che bar grags pa zhes bya'o/ / skyes pa nyid ni pho'i dngos po dang / pho'i dbang po dang ldan pa yin no/ / rang bzhin gyis stobs phun sum tshogs pa ni gnod pa chung ba dang / nad med pa'i rang bzhin can dang / spro ba che ba yin no/ /

A bodhisattva’s excellence of life span is the quality of possessing a long life span and the condition of remaining [alive] for a long period of time. Excellence of physical appearance is the qualities of having a superior physical form, being very good-looking, and having a pleasing appearance. Excellence of family is the quality of being born into an eminent family. Excellence of power is the quality of possessing much property and the condition of having a large number of supporters as well as that of having a large retinue.[212] To be trustworthy and credible, to be considered an authoritative arbiter for persons who are involved in every manner of legal dispute, to be someone who does not cause any loss to property that has been entrusted [to him or her] because [he or she] is free of deceit and guile and would not commit fraud by [misrepresenting] brass [as something more valuable than it actually is] or commit theft by [using false] weights, and the like, to be someone who does not break [his or her] word—and for these reasons to be someone whose word is [well] received by others—is called “the quality of having one’s speech accepted.” For [a bodhisattva] to have great fame and renown, and to be recognized in the world for such things as prowess, strength, steadfastness, skill, proficiency, good conduct, or [for being] the most exceptionally accomplished at [any of] various categories of crafts and occupations—and for these reasons to be esteemed, shown respect, venerated, honored, and revered by a great multitude of persons—is called “the quality of being regarded as eminent.” The quality of being a man is the state of being a male [human being] and [the condition of being a person] who possesses the male [sex] faculty. The excellence of strength that occurs naturally [includes] the qualities of [being someone who experiences] few troubles, being a type [of person] who is free of illness, and [being someone who can put forth] great exertion.
[rnam par smin pa'i rgyu]
THE CAUSES OF THE EIGHT MATURATIONS [I.3.5.1.1]
rnam par smin pa'i rgyu gang zhe na/
What are the causes of the maturations?

sems can rnams la mi 'tshe ba dang / mi 'tshe ba'i bsam pa ni tshe phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin no/ / snang ba dang gos sar pa sbyin pa ni kha dog phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin no/ / sems can rnams la nga rgyal legs par bcom pa ni rigs phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin no/ / slong ba rnams dang yo byad mi bdog pa rnams la sbyin pa ni dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin no/ / bden pa'i tshig dang ldan zhing phra ma med pa dang / tshig rtsub po med pa dang / tshig kyal pa med pa la goms pa ni tshig btsun pa'i rgyu yin no/ / tshe phyi ma la bdag nyid la yon tan rnam pa sna tshogs sgrub par smon lam 'debs shing / dkon mchog gsum la mchod pa byed pa dang / bla ma la mchod pa byed pa ni dbang che bar grags pa nyid kyi rgyu yin no/ / skyes pa'i dngos po la mngon par dga' zhing bud med kyi dngos po la mi dga' ste/ de la nyes dmigs su lta ba dang / bud med rnams kyi bud med kyi dngos po la mngon par dga' ba rnams kyang bud med kyi dngos po las 'dun pa bzlog pa dang / pho'i dbang po bcad pa'i phyir bzung ste/ khrid pa'i mi rnams chos dang mthun pas nges par rnam par thar par byed pa'i rgyu gnyis kyis gzhan dag la skyes pa nyid sgrub pa ni skyes pa nyid kyi rgyu yin no/ / lus kyis sems can rnams kyi bya ba byung ngo cog la chos dang mthun pa dang / gzu lums med par ci nus ci lcogs pa bzhin du zhal ta byed pa dang / grogs byed pa dang / 'bras chan dang / skyo ma dang / thug pa btung ba dang / brta bar 'gyur ba dang / spro ba skyed par byed pa'i zas dang / skom dag sems can rnams la sgrub pa ni stobs phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin te/ de ltar de dag gi rnam par smin pa rnam pa brgyad kyi rgyu rnam pa brgyad yin par rig par bya'o/ /

[Practicing] avoidance of harm[213] toward beings and [developing] the attitude of [wanting to] avoid doing harm are causes for [obtaining] excellence of life span. Giving light and [giving] bright[214] clothing are causes for [obtaining] excellence of physical appearance. Overcoming pride toward beings is a cause for [obtaining] excellence of family. Giving to beggars and to those who lack material necessities[215] is a cause for [obtaining] excellence of power. Speaking the truth and cultivating the avoidance of divisive speech, harsh speech, and idle talk are causes for [obtaining] the quality of having one’s speech accepted. Veneration of the Three Jewels and veneration of those worthy of honor[216] by one who has made prayers of aspiration[217] that he or she might gain a variety of spiritual qualities in the future are causes for [obtaining] the quality of being regarded as eminent. Admiration for male qualities and aversion toward the female state, regarding that [female state] as having disadvantages, and instilling in others the two causes for attaining the male state—[namely,] (1) reversing the desire for the female state that is held by women who delight in female qualities and (2) [causing others], in a proper manner,[218] to set free those men who have been seized and are being led away to have their male faculty destroyed—are causes for [obtaining] the quality of being a man. Physically carrying out yourself on behalf of others whatever duties they may have or assisting them [in their work], with all your strength and ability, in a proper manner, and without being careless; and providing beings with food [such as] boiled grain, porridge, rice gruel, and drink that will strengthen and invigorate them, are causes for [obtaining] excellence of strength. These should be understood as the eight types of causes for [obtaining] the eight types of [karmic] maturation.
[rgyu gsum po]
THE CONDITIONS THAT INSURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CAUSES [I.3.5.1.2]
rgyu de dag kyang mdor bsdu na rgyu gsum gyis rnam par smin pa yongs su rdzogs pa dang / brtas pa dang / rgya che ba mngon par 'grub par 'gyur ba'i phyir rgyas par 'gyur te/
Furthermore, there are, in brief, three conditions that augment these causes so that they will bring about an acquisition of maturations that are complete, abundant, and extensive.
rgyu gsum po dag gang zhe na/
What are the three conditions?

sems rnam par dag pa dang / sbyor ba rnam par dag pa dang / zhing rnam par dag pa'o/ / de la bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag yongs su bsngos pas bsam pa dag par gyur pa gang yin pa dang / snying thag pa nas lhag pa'i bsam pa rgya che zhing dang pas spyod pa'i phyir/ bsam pa drag por gyur pa gang yin pa dang / de dang chos mthun par spyod pa mthong na/ mngon par dga' ba gang yin pa dang / nyin gcig bzhin du skad cig re re la de dang mthun pa'i chos kho na la lan mang du rtog cing dpyod pa gang yin pa de ni sems rnam par dag pa zhes bya'o/ / de la yun ring por goms par byed cing rgyun du byed la grims par byed pa dang / dge ba de yang dag par ma blangs pa gzhan dag la yang yang dag par len du gzhug pa'i phyir bsngags pa brjod pa dang / yang dag par blangs pa rnams la yang yang dag par dga' ba bskyed pa'i phyir bsngags pa brjod pa dang / de dag nyid dge ba'i rtsa ba de la 'dzud pa dang / 'god par byed pa gang yin pa de ni sbyor ba rnam par dag pa zhes bya'o/ / de la mdor bsdu na sbyor ba yang dag par bsgrub pa dang / yang dag par sbyor ba de nyid kyi 'bras bu la gnas pa'i phyir/ zhing rnam par dag pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

They are (1) purity of mind, (2) purity of application, and (3) purity of field. Regarding these, the purity of attitude, in the sense of dedicating these virtue roots[219] to unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment; the intensity of attitude, in the sense of carrying out [these virtue roots] with deep sincerity and great clarity[220] [of mind]; the joy [that arises] at the sight of one who is an exemplary Dharma follower; and the extensive reflection and deliberation, at every moment of each day, upon just those things that are in accord with these [virtue roots] are what is called purity of mind. Regarding these [conditions], cultivating [these virtue roots] for a long period of time, performing them continually, performing them diligently, extolling [them] to others in order to cause them to take up those virtuous acts that have not been undertaken, extolling [them to others] in order to encourage [them to continue performing] those [virtuous acts] that have been undertaken, causing those very persons to settle into [the performance of] these virtue roots, and causing them to become firmly established in [their performance] are what is called purity of application. Regarding [these conditions], in brief it should be understood that the purity of field [comes about] through (1) the correct performance of the application and (2) the stability of the properly [executed] application in relation to [the generating of] a result.[221]
[rnam par smin pa'i 'bras bu]
THE RESULTS THAT CAN BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THE MATURATIONS [I.3.6.1.1]
de la rnam par smin pa'i 'bras bu gang zhe na/
Regarding this [topic], what are the results of the maturations?

byang chub sems dpa' tshe phun sum tshogs par gyur na/ bdag gi don dang / gzhan gyi don las brtsams nas yun ring por dge ba'i phyogs la sbyor ba dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba mang po sogs par byed pa 'di ni tshe phun sum tshogs pa'i 'bras bu yin no/ /

A bodhisattva who is endowed with excellence of life span [is able to] apply him- or herself for a long period of time to [everything] that pertains to virtue[222] and to accumulate a great quantity of the virtue roots that pertain to one’s own aim and that of others. This is the result that relates to excellence of life span.

byang chub sems dpa' kha dog phun sum tshogs par gyur na/ skye bo'i tshogs chen po'i snying du sdug par 'gyur te/ snying du sdug na drung du 'du bar 'gyur la/ gzugs yid du 'ong ba dang / mngon du phrad par gyur pas skye bo'i tshogs chen po dag de'i tshig mnyan pa dang / bya bar sems te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i kha dog phun sum tshogs pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is endowed with excellence of physical appearance is liked by a great multitude of persons. Because of this quality of being liked, he or she becomes someone whom others wish to approach. And since the quality of having an attractive physical form causes [others] to come directly into his or her presence, a great multitude of persons will also regard his or her speech as something that ought to be heard. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s excellence of physical appearance.

byang chub sems dpa'i rigs phun sum tshogs par gyur na/ skye bo'i tshogs chen pos bkur ba dang / mchod pa dang bsngags par 'gyur ro/ / bkur zhing mchod la bsngags na/ sems can rnams don gang dang gang la 'dzud pa de dang de la de dag gzi byin gyis non pas myur du 'jug par 'gyur te/ mi bya'o zhes zlog par mi byed/ log par mi byed pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i rigs phun sum tshogs pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is endowed with excellence of family is thought highly of by a great multitude of persons and is also revered and praised. Because of being thought highly of, revered, and praised, whatever matter [that bodhisattva] urges beings to undertake, they are overwhelmed by his or her majesty and set about doing it quickly; they do not voice [any] opposition or take action to avoid doing it. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s excellence of family.

byang chub sems dpa' dbang phyug phun sum tshogs par gyur na/ sbyin pas sems can rnams sdud cing yongs su smin par byed de/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is endowed with excellence of power attracts beings and [spiritually] ripens them through [practicing] generosity. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s excellence of power.

byang chub sems dpa'i tshig btsun par gyur na snyan par smra ba dang / don spyod pa dang / don mthun pas sems can rnams sdud cing yongs su smin par byed de/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i tshig btsun pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva whose speech is accepted attracts beings and [spiritually] ripens them through [practicing] agreeable speech, beneficial conduct, and sameness of purpose.[223] This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s quality of having his or her speech accepted.

byang chub sems dpa' dbang che bar grags par gyur na/ bya ba byed pa rnam pa sna tshogs dag gis sems can gyi grogs byed du 'gro zhing phan 'dogs par byed do/ / phan btags pa des na/ sems can rnams kyi sems dang 'brel par 'gyur bas de la gus pa dang / byas pa gzo bar gyur nas/ bkur sti dang / gus pa dang bcas pas myur ba myur bar bsgo ba bzhin du nyan par byed de/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i dbang che bar grags pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is regarded as eminent benefits beings by assisting them with a variety of activities that need to be done. Because of this benefit, beings feel a sense of obligation and, out of respect and gratitude toward [that bodhisattva], they very quickly carry out his or her bidding in a courteous and respectful manner. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s quality of being regarded as eminent.

byang chub sems dpa' skyes pa nyid du gyur na/ pho'i dbang po dang ldan pas/ yon tan thams cad dang btsal ba thams cad dang / shes bya thams cad rab tu rnam par 'byed pa dag gi snod du gyur pa yin te/ 'jigs pa med par gyur la/ dus thams cad du sems can thams cad dang 'gro ba'am/ smra ba'am/ 'grogs pa'am/ longs spyod pa'am/ dben pa dben par gnas pa rnams la 'jug pa/ sgrib pa med pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i skyes pa nyid kyi 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is a male and who possesses the male faculty is a [suitable] vessel for [the development of] all [spiritual] qualities, [for carrying out] all [the forms of spiritual] activities [that require] strenuous exertion, and [for generating] all [the forms of] discernment[224] that pertain to [entities] that need to be known. He also is dauntless and his movements are not restricted with regard to traveling, conversing, residing,[225] and sharing meals with other persons at any time, [as well as] with regard to dwelling alone in secluded places. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s quality of being a male.

byang chub sems dpa' stobs phun sum tshogs par gyur na/ dge ba'i chos sgrub pa'i sbyor ba dang sems can la phan gdags pa'i sbyor bas mi skyo bar 'gyur la/ brtson 'grus rtsom par 'gyur zhing / brtson 'grus brtan pa dang / mngon par shes pa myur bar 'gyur te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i stobs phun sum tshogs pa'i 'bras bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva who is endowed with excellence of strength does not become weary from undertaking to acquire virtuous qualities or from undertaking to help sentient beings. He or she is one who has developed effort, one whose effort is strong, and one whose supernatural knowledge[226] takes effect swiftly. This should be understood as the result that relates to a bodhisattva’s excellence of strength.

de ltar 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rnam par smin pa rnam pa brgyad kyi 'bras bu rnam pa brgyad yin te/ de yod na sems can rnams la yang phan pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams skye ba la yang mthun cing 'phrod pa yin te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par smin pa'i 'bras bu 'di la gnas na/ bdag nyid kyang sems can rnams kyi don sna tshogs mang po bya ba la nus shing lcogs par 'gyur la/ des gdul bar bya ba de dag kyang 'di lta ste/ rang gi don bya ba yan chad la ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du bya ba dag la bsgo ba bzhin du nyan par 'gyur ro/ / gal te byang chub sems dpa' de bdag nyid kyis lcogs su zin kyang gdul byar bya ba des bsgo ba bzhin du mi nyan par gyur na/ de lta na yang de'i gzhan gyi don bya ba las don che ba ma yin mthun pa ma yin te/ des na des gzhan gyi don byed mi nus so/ / gal te byang chub sems dpa' de bdag nyid kyis ni mi nus mi lcogs la/ des gdul bar bya ba rnams ni rang gi don bya ba yan chad la bsgo ba bzhin du nyan par gyur na/ de lta na yang byang chub sems dpa'i gzhan gyi don bya ba las don che ba ma yin mthun pa ma yin te/ des na des gzhan gyi don byed mi nus so/ / de lta bas na de gnyi ga tshogs la gnyi ga 'byor par gyur na/ byang chub sems dpa'i sems can gyi don bya ba la las don che zhing mthun par 'gyur te/ des na gzhan gyi don byed nus par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar gyur na byang chub sems dpa' des bdag nyid kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams dang / sems can rnams kyang theg pa gsum la myur ba nyid du yongs su smin par byed la/ bdag nyid kyang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur zhing / sems can yongs su smin pa rnams kyang rnam par grol bar byed do/ /

These are the eight results of the eight [karmic] maturations that favor and support bodhisattvas [in their efforts] to benefit sentient beings and to develop the [spiritual] qualities of a buddha. The bodhisattva who has become established in the maturation results is also competent and able to accomplish a great number and variety of aims that pertain to sentient beings. [Other beings] will also become disciples who are willing to be directed to carry out activities according to his or her wishes—that is to say, [to carry out activities] that relate to the accomplishing of their own aims. [On the other hand,] if a bodhisattva is able [to help beings], but his or her disciples are unwilling to act as they have been directed, then the activities that he or she performs on behalf of [other] beings will be neither abundant nor favorable, and he or she will be unable to accomplish the aims of others. [Similarly,] if a bodhisattva is neither competent nor able, then even though other beings become disciples who are willing to be directed [by him or her] to carry out activities that relate to the accomplishing of their own aims, the activities that [such a] bodhisattva performs on behalf of [other] beings will be neither productive nor favorable, and he or she will be unable to accomplish the aims of others. Therefore, it is [only] when both [of these conditions] are present and both [of these conditions] exist that a bodhisattva’s activities on behalf of beings will be productive and favorable such that he or she is capable of accomplishing the aims of others. A bodhisattva who finds him- or herself in circumstances [where both of these conditions are present] will quickly ripen the qualities of a buddha in him- or herself, and he or she will quickly ripen [other] beings in relation to the three vehicles. He or she will also attain unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment and liberate those sentient beings who have been [spiritually] ripened.

de bas na rnam grangs des gang gi phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rnam par smin pa'i 'bras bu rnam pa brgyad po dag sems can rnams la phan pa dang / bde bar 'gyur ba de'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi 'khor ba'i tshe 'bras bu med cing don med pa de yang de dag la 'bras bu yod pa dang don che bar 'gyur ro/ /

Because the eight types of maturation results enable bodhisattvas to bring about the benefit and happiness of sentient beings in this way, the samsara that for all [other] sentient beings is barren and meaningless becomes something that for [bodhisattvas] is productive and endowed with great meaning.
bsod nams dang ye shes
MERIT AND WISDOM [I.3.5.2, I.3.6.2]
de la bsod nams ni gang yin/ ye shes ni gang yin zhe na/
What is merit? What is wisdom?

bsod nams zhes bya ba ni mdor bsdu na pha rol tu phyin pa gsum ste/ sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa dang / tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / ye shes ni pha rol tu phyin pa gcig pu ste/ 'di lta ste/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa ni bsod nams kyi phyogs dang / ye shes kyi phyogs su rig par bya ste/

In brief, three of the [six] perfections are called “merit”: (1) the perfection of generosity, (2) the perfection of morality, and (3) the perfection of patience. Wisdom, however, is made up of [only] one of the perfections—that is, the perfection of wisdom. The perfection of effort and the perfection of meditative absorption should [both] be understood to have [forms that] promote merit and [forms that] promote wisdom.[227]

brtson 'grus la brten nas sbyin pa sbyin pa dang / tshul khrims yang dag par len cing bsrung ba dang / byams pa la sogs pa tshad med pa rnams bsgom pa 'am/ de lta bu dang mthun pa gang yin pa de ni bsod nams kyi phyogs kyi brtson 'grus so/ / brtson 'grus la brten nas thos pa dang / bsam pa dang / bsgom pa'i shes rab la sbyor bar byed cing phung po la mkhas pa dang / khams la mkhas pa dang / skye mched la mkhas pa dang / rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba la mkhas pa dang / gnas dang gnas ma yin pa la mkhas par byed pa dang / sdug bsngal ba la ni sdug bsngal bar/ kun 'byung ba la ni kun 'byung bar/ 'gog pa la ni 'gog par/ lam la ni lam du so sor rtog pa'am/ dge ba dang mi dge ba'i chos rnams dang / kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa dang / kha na ma tho ba med pa dang / bsten par bya ba dang / bsten par bya ba ma yin pa dang / ngan pa dang / bzang po dang / nag po dang / dkar po'i chos rnams dang / rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba rab tu rnam par dbye ba dang bcas pa'i chos rnams yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu rnam par 'byed cing / so sor rtog pa 'di ni ye shes kyi phyogs kyi brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

The [forms of] effort that are relied upon to practice generosity, to undertake and preserve morality, to cultivate the [four] immeasurable [practices] of loving-kindness and the rest, and [other forms] that are of the same kind [as these] make up the effort that promotes merit. On the other hand, (1) the [form of] effort that is relied upon to apply oneself to the [three types of] wisdom—[namely,] those that derive from learning, reflection, and meditation; (2) [the form of effort that is relied upon] to develop skill regarding the heaps,[228] skill regarding the constituents,[229] skill regarding the bases,[230] skill regarding dependent origination, and skill regarding [what constitute] proper and improper conditions;[231] (3) [the form of effort that is relied upon] to investigate [the noble truth of] suffering as to the way in which it constitutes suffering, [the noble truth of] origination as to the way in which it constitutes origination, [the noble truth of] cessation as to the way in which it constitutes cessation, and [the noble truth of] the path as to the way in which it constitutes the path; and (4) [the form of effort that is relied upon] to examine and investigate, as they truly are, those entities that are virtuous or nonvirtuous, [as well as] those entities that arise dependently and are [variously] classified as being black or white, blameworthy or beyond reproach, [qualities] to which one ought to devote oneself or to which one ought not to devote oneself, and [qualities] that are inferior or excellent are the ones that are called the effort that promotes wisdom.

bsam gtan la brten nas sbyin pa sbyin pa dang / tshul khrims yang dag par len cing bsrung ba'am/ byams pa la sogs pa tshad med pa rnams bsgom pa'am/ de lta bu dang mthun pa gang yin pa de ni bsod nams kyi phyogs kyi bsam gtan yin no/ / bsam gtan la brten nas thos pa dang / bsam pa dang / bsgom pa'i shes rab la sbyor bar byed cing / phung po la mkhas pa nas/ sngar brtson 'grus kyi skabs su ji skad bstan pa de bzhin du thams cad brjod par bya ste/ 'di ni ye shes kyi phyogs kyi bsam gtan yin no/ /

The [forms of] meditative absorption that are relied upon to practice generosity, to undertake and preserve morality, to cultivate the [four] immeasurable practices of loving-kindness and the rest, and [other forms of meditative absorption] that are of the same kind [as these] make up the meditative absorption that promotes merit. On the other hand, (1) the [form of] meditative absorption that is relied upon to apply oneself to the [three types of] wisdom—[namely,] those that derive from learning, reflection, and meditation; (2) [the form of meditative absorption that is relied upon] to develop skill regarding the heaps, etc.—[that is, the remainder of] the entire [description] is to be stated in the same manner as was previously done with regard to effort.
bsod nams dang / ye shes de yang mdor bsdu na rnam pa drug yod do/ / de re re'i rnam par dbye ba ni/ tshad med par rig par bya'o/ /

This represents a brief [presentation] of the six types of merit and wisdom. However, it should be understood that [the description] would be immeasurably large if an [exhaustive] classification of every one of their individual forms was made.
[bsod nams dang ye shes kyi rgyu]
THE CAUSES OF MERIT AND WISDOM [I.3.5.2.1]
bsod nams dang ye shes kyi rgyu gang zhe na/
What are the causes of merit and wisdom?

bsod nams dang ye shes kyi rgyu ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa gsum yod par rig par bya ste/ bsod nams dang / ye shes thob pa dang / gnas pa dang 'phel bar 'gyur ba la 'dun pa gang yin pa dang / mthun la mi mthun pa med pa'i rkyen dang / sngon yang bsod nams dang ye shes la goms pa'o/ / de la mi mthun pa med pa'i rkyen ni 'di yin te/ phyin ci log gi rkyen ni nye bar mi gnas shing / nye bar ma gyur la/ phyin ci ma log pa'i rkyen ni nye bar gnas shing / nye bar gyur pa gang yin pa'o/ /

In brief, it should be understood that there are three causes of [both] merit and wisdom: (1) the aspiration to acquire, maintain, and increase merit and wisdom; (2) the conditions that are advantageous and favorable [to the acquisition, etc., of merit and wisdom]; and (3) the prior cultivation of merit and wisdom. With regard to these [causes], the conditions that are favorable [to the acquisition, etc., of merit and wisdom] are the state in which adverse conditions are not present or near at hand as well as the state in which propitious conditions are present or near at hand.

de la sdig pa'i grogs po dang phrad nas bsod nams dang ye shes phyin ci log tu bstan pa'am/ phyin ci log gi yid la byed pas/ phyin ci log tu bzung ba de ni phyin ci log gi rkyen nye bar gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / de las bzlog pa dkar po'i phyogs ni phyin ci ma log pa'i rkyen nye bar gyur pa ma yin par rig par bya'o/ / bsod nams dang / ye shes 'thob pa dang / gnas pa dang 'phel bar bya ba'i phyir sbyor ba la bar du gcod pa gang yin pa de dag spong zhing mi skyed pa 'di yang byang chub sems dpa'i bsod nams dang ye shes kyi mi mthun pa med pa'i rkyen zhes bya'o/ / rgyu gsum po 'di dag las gang yang rung ba cig ma tshang na yang bsod nams kyang skye bar mi 'gyur la/ ye shes kyang skye bar mi 'gyur bar rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [point], erring instructions about merit and wisdom that occur through having met with an evil companion or erring notions that come about through erring forms of attention[232] are called “the presence of adverse conditions.” [The conditions that are] the opposite of this and that represent the side of [spiritual] purity[233] should be understood to constitute the presence of propitious conditions. In addition, those conditions that remove and prevent the arising of obstacles for someone who has undertaken to acquire, maintain, and increase merit and wisdom are said to be “the favorable conditions” for a bodhisattva’s [pursuit of] merit and wisdom. It should be understood that the absence of any of these three causes prevents merit or wisdom from being generated.
[bsod nams dang ye shes kyi 'bras bu]
THE RESULTS OF MERIT AND WISDOM [I.3.6.2.1]
bsod nams dang ye shes kyi 'bras bu gang zhe na/
What are the results of merit and wisdom?
