For its part, the bodhisattva’s effort that acts on behalf of sentient beings should be understood as being made up of eleven categories, which are the same as the ones that were described in the chapter on morality. What was referred to there as morality should here be called effort.[878] That is the [only] difference.
THE EFFORT THAT IS DIFFICULT TO CARRY OUT [I.12.3]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i brtson 'grus gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gsum du blta bar bya ste/ 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' ni gos kyi 'du shes dang / zas kyi 'du shes dang / mal cha dang / stan gyi 'du shes dang / bdag tu 'du shes kyang mi byed par dge ba'i chos rnams sgom pa la rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par zhugs pa yin te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i brtson 'grus dang po'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' ni ris mthun pa ma dor gyi bar du dus thams cad du brtson 'grus rtsom pa de lta bu des zhugs pa yin te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i brtson 'grus gnyis pa'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' ni mnyam pa nyid khong du chud pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa/ ha cang zhum pa yang ma yin/ ha cang brtun ngas pa yang ma yin la/ phyin ci ma log cing don dang ldan pa'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa yin te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i brtson 'grus gsum pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dka' ba'i brtson 'grus 'di sdud pa'i rgyu ni stobs dang / sems can rnams la snying rje ba dang / shes rab yin par rig par bya'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s effort that is difficult to carry out? It should be regarded as being of three types. [The quality by means of] which a bodhisattva remains engaged in meditation upon virtuous qualities uninterruptedly and continually without forming any notion[879] of monastic robes, alms food, a bed and seat, or a self [should be understood as] the first form of a bodhisattva’s effort that is difficult to carry out. Moreover, [while exerting him- or herself] with this form of effort, [the quality by means of which] a bodhisattva remains engaged at all times [in the practice of virtuous qualities] until his or her class affiliate has been abandoned[880] [should be understood as] the second form of a bodhisattva’s effort that is difficult to carry out. In addition, [the quality by means of which] a bodhisattva gains a [form of] effort that is accompanied by the attribute of having attained equanimity[881] and [therefore] is neither overly listless nor overly energetic, and that it is directed toward an unerring object, should be understood as the third form of a bodhisattva’s effort that is difficult to carry out. Now then, it should be understood that compassion toward sentient beings and wisdom are the acquiring causes[882] [by means of which] bodhisattvas [obtain] the strength that relates to the effort that is difficult to carry out.
THE EFFORT THAT IS DIRECTED EVERYWHERE [I.12.4]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thams cad kyi sgo nas brtson 'grus gang zhe na/ 'di ni rnam pa bzhir blta bar bya ste/ nyon mongs pa can gyi chos rnam par spong bar byed pa dang / dkar po'i chos sgrub par byed pa dang / las yongs su dag par byed pa dang / shes rab rnam par 'phel bar byed pa'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus nyon mongs pa can gyi chos rnam par spong bar byed pa ni kun tu sbyor ba dang / 'ching ba dang / bag la nyal ba dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa dang / kun nas dkris pa ma skyes pa rnams mi skye bar byed pa dang / skyes pa rnams spong bar byed pa'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus dkar po'i chos sgrub par byed pa ni dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa rnams bskyed pa'i brtson 'grus gang yin pa dang / skyes pa rnams gnas par byed pa dang / mi nyams par byed pa dang / 'phel zhing rgyas par byed pa'i brtson 'grus gang yin pa'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus las yongs su dag par byed pa ni las rnam pa gsum po lus kyi las dang / ngag gi las dang / yid kyi las dge ba rnam par dag par byed pa dang / sdud par byed pa gang yin pa'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus shes pa rnam par 'phel bar byed pa ni thos pa dang / bsam pa dang / bsgom pa las byung ba'i shes rab yang dag par 'grub pa dang / rnam par 'phel bar byed pa gang yin pa'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s effort that is directed everywhere? It should be regarded as being of four types: (1) that which avoids afflicted qualities; (2) that which gains possession of pure qualities; (3) that which refines deeds; and (4) that which increases knowledge. Concerning this [topic], a bodhisattva’s effort that avoids afflicted qualities is [the form of effort that strives] to prevent the arising of those fetters,[883] bonds,[884] latencies,[885] secondary mental afflictions,[886] and perturbations[887] that have not yet arisen and to abandon those that have arisen. Concerning this [topic], a bodhisattva’s effort that gains possession of pure qualities is [the form of effort that strives] to generate those virtuous entities that have not yet arisen and to maintain [possession of], avoid indistinctness about, and increase and augment those [virtuous entities] that have arisen. Concerning this [topic], a bodhisattva’s effort that refines deeds is [the form of effort that strives] to refine and collect the three types of deeds—that is, the virtuous deeds of body, speech, and mind. Concerning this [topic], the form of a bodhisattva’s effort that increases knowledge [is the form of effort that] promotes the attainment and development of the forms of wisdom that derive from learning, reflection, and meditation.
THE EFFORT OF A TRUE SPIRITUAL BEING [I.12.5]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i skyes bu dam pa'i brtson 'grus gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa lngar blta bar bya ste/ 'dun pa dang sbyor ba thams cad thams cad du mi gtong ba'i phyir ma btang ba dang / ji ltar blangs pa bzhin du mtshungs pa 'am/ lhag par brtson 'grus rjes su 'phel bar byed pa'i phyir nyams pa med pa dang / sbyor ba dang / yun ring ba dang / rgyun mi 'chad par brtson 'grus rtsom pa la sems mi 'gong zhing sgyid lug pa med pa'i phyir zhum pa med pa dang / don dang ldan pa'i thabs kyis yongs su zin pa'i phyir phyin ci ma log pa dang / bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu rings pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi brtson 'grus brtun te sbyor ba'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s effort of a true spiritual being? It should be regarded as being of five types: (1) the effort of bodhisattvas that has not been rejected due to the fact that no form of aspiration and practice is ever rejected; (2) [the effort of bodhisattvas] that is not deficient due to the development of a form of effort whose strength is equal to or greater than [what is needed for] the task that is undertaken; (3) [the effort of bodhisattvas] that is not subject to dejection due to having a state of mind that does not become timid or despondent about having to exert strenuous effort continuously and for a long time; (4) [the effort of bodhisattvas] that is unerring due to being governed by a type of means that is directed toward a [genuine] aim; and (5) [the effort of bodhisattvas] whose application is fervent[888] in that it [strives after] unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment with a heightened sense of urgency.
EFFORT OF EVERY FORM [I.12.6]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rnam pa thams cad kyi brtson 'grus gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa drug dang / rnam pa bdun te gcig tu bsdus na rnam pa bcu gsum du rig par bya ste/ rgyun du sbyor ba'i phyir rtag pa'i brtson 'grus dang / lhur sbyor ba'i phyir gus pa'i brtson 'grus dang / sngon gyi rgyu'i stobs kyis bskyed pa'i phyir rgyu mthun pa'i brtson 'grus dang / so sor brtags shing brtags shing dge ba'i phyogs la sbyor ba'i phyir sbyor ba las byung ba'i brtson 'grus dang / sdug bsngal gyi gnod pa thams cad kyis mi 'khrugs shing gzhan du bsgyur du med pa'i phyir mi 'khrugs pa'i brtson 'grus dang / khyad par thob pa chung ngu dang / ngan don tsam gyis chog mi shes pa'i phyir chog mi shes pa'i brtson 'grus so/ / 'di ni re zhig rnam pa thams cad kyi brtson 'grus rnam pa drug ste/ de dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i chos rnams la brtson 'grus brtsams pa dang / mthu dang ldan pa dang / brtson 'grus dang ldan pa dang / spro ba dang ldan pa dang / brtun pa brtan pa dang / brtson pa mi gtong ba zhes bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s effort of every form? It should be understood as the thirteen forms [of effort that result from] combining together six forms and seven forms. [The first six are] (1) continuous effort, in that it is practiced at all times; (2) zealous effort, in that it is applied earnestly;[889] (3) effort that is a natural consequence, in that it is generated on the strength of being caused by a former effort; (4) effective[890] effort, in that it is applied to [everything] that pertains to virtue after having made careful consideration; (5) imperturbable effort, in that it cannot be disturbed by any painful experience and because it has attained the quality of being unalterable; and (6) insatiable effort, in that it is not satisfied by merely attaining distinctive qualities that are small or insignificant. These six types of the effort of every form cause a bodhisattva who possesses them to be described in relation to virtuous qualities as “one who has taken hold of effort,” “one who possesses strength,” “one who possesses vigor,” “one who is energetic,” “one whose courage is firm,” and “one whose obligation has not been relinquished.”[891]

rnam pa bdun ni phyi phyir zhing bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu shas cher 'dun pa dang / smon pa rjes su 'phel bar byed pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus 'dun pa dang ldan pa dang / brtson 'grus gang gis byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i chos rnams la mthun zhing rnal 'byor du gnas par 'gyur la/ nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang yang rung bas sems nyon mongs pa can du ma gyur zhing / kun nas dkris pa med pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus gang mthun pa dang ldan pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang yang rung bas sems nye ba'i nyon mongs pa can du gyur cing / sems kun nas dkris pa'i nye ba'i nyon mongs pa de spang ba'i phyir mgo la me 'bar ba gsod pa lta bu'i brtson 'grus gang yin pa byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus khyad par can dang / rig pa'i gnas thams cad yongs su tshol ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus tshol ba dang / yongs su btsal ba'i chos de dag nyid la ji ltar mthun pa dang / ji ltar 'os par chos kyi rjes su mthun pa'i chos nan tan gyis bsgrub pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i brtson 'grus dang / byang chub sems dpa'i pha rol gyi don byed pa'i brtson 'grus ni snga ma bzhin du rnam pa bcu gcig tu blta bar bya'o/ / bdag nyid kyi yang dag pa'i sbyor ba kun nas bsrung ba dang / 'khrul pa chos bzhin du phyir 'chos pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus bdun pa yin te/ rnam pa bcu gsum po de dag ni byang chub sems dpa'i rnam pa thams cad kyi brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

In addition, [the remaining] seven types [of a bodhisattva’s effort of every form are as follows]: (1) A bodhisattva’s effort is one that is accompanied by aspiration in that it is strengthened by repeated and fervent aspiration for and dedication to unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment. (2) A bodhisattva’s effort that is endowed with equipoise is [the effort] of one who remains unperturbed by keeping his or her mind from becoming afflicted by any of the root or mental afflictions [and] it is a [form of] effort by means of which a bodhisattva becomes one who abides in [a state of] equal suitability toward [all] virtuous qualities. (3) A bodhisattva’s exceptional effort is that which, in order to abandon any secondary mental affliction that may have afflicted and perturbed his or her mind, resembles the effort of a person whose head has caught fire to put out the flames. (4) A bodhisattva’s effort is one that seeks in that it pursues all the branches of learning. (5) A bodhisattva’s effort is one that pertains to the training in that it accomplishes the practice that accords with the Dharma, suitably and appropriately, with regard to those very qualities that are being sought. (6) A bodhisattva’s effort that accomplishes the aims of others should be understood as being of eleven types in the manner that was described earlier. (7) A bodhisattva’s seventh [form of] effort [strives] to safeguard his or her own correct practice and to counteract his or her errors in a manner that accords with Dharma. These thirteen types of a bodhisattva’s effort are called “the effort of every form.”
THE EFFORT THAT RELATES TO THE DISTRESSED AND WHAT THEY WANT AND THE EFFORT THAT BRINGS HAPPINESS HERE AND IN THE NEXT WORLD [I.12.7–8]

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi phongs shing 'dod pa'i brtson 'grus dang / 'di dang gzhan du bde bar 'gyur ba'i brtson 'grus ni bzod pa bzhin du blta bar bya'o/ / de la bye brag ni 'di yod de/ der bzod pa zhes bya ba gang yin pa de 'dir brtson 'grus mngon par spro ba zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

[The descriptions of] the effort of bodhisattvas that relates to the distressed and what they want and the effort [of bodhisattvas] that brings happiness here and in the next world should be regarded as being like [the descriptions that were given for the corresponding forms of] patience. The difference between them is this. What was [described as] patience [in the previous chapter] should be described here as effort [and] exertion.
PURE EFFORT [I.12.9]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dag pa'i brtson 'grus gang zhe na/ de ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa bcur rig par bya ste/ 'tsham pa dang / goms pa dang / mi g.yel ba dang / legs par zin pa dang / dus su goms par brtson pa dang / mtshan ma rtogs pa dang ldan pa dang / zhum pa med pa dang / mi ldan pa med pa dang / snyoms pa dang / byang chub chen por yongs su bsngo ba ste/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang dang gang gis shin tu gnod par gyur pa'i nyes pa'i nyon mongs pa de dang de spang ba'i phyir 'tsham pa'i gnyen po bsten te/ 'dod pa la 'dod chags kyi gnyen por mi sdug pa sgom pa dang / gnod sems kyi gnyen por byams pa dang / gti mug gi gnyen por rkyen 'di pa nyid kyi rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba sgom pa dang / rnam par rtog pa'i gnyen por dbugs dbyung ba dang / rngub pa dran pa dang / nga rgyal gyi gnyen por khams rab tu dbye ba sgom pa dang / de lta bu dang mthun pa rnams ni byang chub sems dpa'i 'tsham pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s pure effort? In brief, it should be understood as being of ten types. [They are effort that is] (1) appropriate, (2) experienced, (3) free of laxness, and (4) well informed; (5) [effort in which] the practice is applied according to the occasion; and [effort that is] (6) accompanied by the perception of signs, (7) free of dejection, (8) not deficient, (9) balanced, and (10) dedicated to great enlightenment. Whichever one of the secondary mental afflictions greatly distresses a bodhisattva here, he or she cultivates the appropriate antidote for that secondary mental affliction in order to abandon it. One meditates on unattractiveness as the antidote for attachment to sense pleasures. [One meditates] on loving-kindness as the antidote for malice. One meditates on the principles of conditionality [taught in the doctrine of] dependent origination as an antidote for ignorance. One meditates on recollection of the breath as an antidote for discursive thoughts. One meditates on the diversity of the constituents[892] as an antidote for pride. This kind [of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “appropriate effort.”

'di lta ste gdams pa dang / rjes su bstan pa la sems gnas par bya ba'i phyir/ byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa las thog ma pa'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa ma yin te/ sbyor ba goms pa yin zhing / sbyor ba 'dris pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i goms pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Here a bodhisattva does not possess the effort of a novice and a beginning practitioner—that is, [when striving] to fix the mind upon the instruction and counsel. He or she [strives] in no other way than as one who has repeatedly practiced the application and one who has become familiar with the application. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “experienced effort.”

byang chub sems dpa'i gdams pa dang / rjes su bstan pa la sems gnas pa las brtsams te/ sbyor ba la goms pa ma yin zhing / byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa nyid yin bzhin du/ rtag tu gus par sbyor ba'i phyir/ sbyor ba de la mi g.yel bar sbyor ba yin te/ 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i mi g.yel ba'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva also is not one who has finished repeatedly practicing the application that relates to fixing his or her mind upon the instruction and upon counsel. Rather, the bodhisattva is [one who resembles] a novice whose application is free of laxness with regard to this [form of] application in the sense that one applies oneself continuously and zealously. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “effort that is free of laxness.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' bla ma rnams las sam/ bdag nyid kyis mang du thos pa'i stobs bskyed pas phyin ci ma log par zin pas sems gnas par bya ba'i phyir/ brtson 'grus rtsom pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i legs par zin pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, [a bodhisattva] initiates effort in order to fix his or her mind by means of an unerring form of understanding, whether it is [gained] from venerable beings or due to the bodhisattva’s own kindling of the strength of extensive learning. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “well-informed effort.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' de ltar phyin ci ma log par zin pas zhi gnas kyi dus su ni zhi gnas sgom la/ rab tu 'dzin pa'i dus su ni sems rab tu 'dzin cing / btang snyoms kyi dus su ni btang snyoms sgom pa 'di ni de'i dus su brtson pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, the bodhisattva who possesses such an unerring understanding meditates on quiescence at a time [when the goal is to develop] quiescence, takes hold of the mind at a time [when the goal is to develop the quality of] retention,[893] and meditates on equanimity[894] at a time [when the goal is to maintain] equanimity. This [type of effort] is called [a bodhisattva’s] “effort that is applied according to the occasion.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' zhi gnas dang / rab tu 'dzin pa dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma rnams dang ting nge 'dzin la 'jug pa dang / ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa dang / ldang ba'i mtshan ma rnams shes pa dang / mi brjed pa dang / rtogs par bya ba'i phyir rtag tu byed cing / gus par byed pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i mtshan mar rtogs pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, a bodhisattva exerts him- or herself continually and zealously to observe, to avoid becoming inattentive about, and to achieve the signs of quiescence, retention, and equanimity as well as [to observe, to avoid becoming inattentive about, and to achieve] the signs of developing, maintaining, and arising from one-pointed concentration. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “effort [that is accompanied by] the perception of signs.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi brtson 'grus rtsom pa mchog tu rgya che zhing mchog tu zab la/ bsam gyis mi khyab cing / dpag tu med pa dag bstan pa thos na/ bdag nyid la khyad du mi gsod cing / sems zhum par yang mi byed la/ khyad par thob pa chung ngu tsam dang / ngan ngon tsam gyis kyang chog par mi 'dzin te/ gong du mi 'bad par mi byed pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i zhum pa med pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, having heard the most extensive, most profound, inconceivably great, and immeasurable instructions on the undertaking of effort that is carried out by bodhisattvas, a bodhisattva does not disparage him- or herself, does not become disheartened, and is not satisfied merely by attaining a small or insignificant distinctive quality. He or she does not strive for something that is not superior. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “effort that is free of dejection.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' dus dus su dbang po'i sgo rnams srung zhing / zas kyi tshod rig pa dang / nam gyi cha stod dang nam gyi cha smad la mi nyal bar rjes su brtson pa dang / shes bzhin du gnas pa dang / de lta bu dang mthun pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi tshogs rnams yang dag par blangs te/ 'dug cing de rnams la brtson par yang byed cing phyin ci ma log pa'i don dang ldan pa thams cad la 'bad pa rtsom pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i mi ldan pa med pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, regularly and at the appropriate time, a bodhisattva takes up and attends to [the practices of] guarding the doors of the senses, observing moderation with regard to food, maintaining wakefulness during the first and last parts of the night, remaining vigilant, and other similar forms of the requisites for one-pointed concentration.[895] He or she also applies him- or herself to them zealously. He or she initiates an unerring exertion that is directed toward a [genuine] aim in all situations. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “effort that is not deficient.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' ha cang yang mi zhum/ ha cang yang brtun mi ngas par brtson 'grus rtsom ste/ sbyor ba snyoms par byed cing / brtsam par bya ba thams cad la snyoms par gus par byed pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i snyoms pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, a bodhisattva initiates a form of effort that is neither overly listless nor overly strained. He or she applies a method in a balanced manner. He or she also acts carefully and in a balanced manner with regard to all forms of exertion that need to be carried out. This [type of effort] is referred to as a bodhisattva’s “state of balanced effort.”

yang byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus rtsom pa mngon par 'du byed pa thams cad bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo ba 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i yang dag pa'i yongs su bsngo ba'i brtson 'grus zhes bya ba ste/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi brtson 'grus/ brtson 'grus kyi ngo bo nyid nas rnam par dag pa'i bar gyi brtson 'grus 'di dag ni byang chub chen po'i 'bras bu 'byung ba ste/ de la brten nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par byas te/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas so/ / mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro/ / mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o/ /

Moreover, a bodhisattva dedicates all forms of effort that are initiated and generated to unsurpassed and complete enlightenment. This [type of effort] is called a bodhisattva’s “effort that is correctly dedicated.” This [discussion of] the effort that is practiced by bodhisattvas—beginning with the essence of effort, etc., and ending with pure effort—[describes a spiritual quality] that has great enlightenment as its fruit and [it is a spiritual quality] on the basis of which bodhisattvas, after completing the perfection of effort, have attained, shall attain, and are currently attaining unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment.
byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i gzhi'i rnal 'byor gyi gnas las brtson 'grus kyi le'u ste bcu gnyis pa'o// //
Within [Book I of] The Stage of a Bodhisattva, [known as] “The Object of Mental Application That Relates to the Support,” this completes the twelfth chapter, entitled “Effort.”
[bsam gtan]
13. MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION
THE ESSENCE OF MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION [I.13.1]
sdom ni snga ma bzhin du rig par bya'o/ /
The summary verses should be understood in the same manner as before.

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan gyi ngo bo nyid gang zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod thos pa dang / bsam pa sngon du 'gro ba'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sems rtse gcig pa dge ba'i sems gnas pa zhi gnas kyi phyogs sam/ lhag mthong gi phyogs sam/ zung du 'brel par 'jug pa'i lam de gnyi ga'i phyogs gang yin pa ste/ 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan gyi ngo bo nyid du rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is the essence of a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption? It is a virtuous one-pointedness of mind that is possessed by bodhisattvas and is preceded by listening to and reflecting upon the collection of bodhisattva scriptures. It can be either mundane[896] or transcendent[897] in nature. [Moreover,] it is a state of mental stability that pertains to quiescence, insight, or both of them in that it constitutes a path in which the two [forms of meditation] are practiced in combination. This should be understood as the essence of the meditative absorption[898] that is practiced by bodhisattvas.
ALL-INCLUSIVE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION [I.13.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan thams cad gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gnyis su rig par bya ste/ 'jig rten pa'i dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i'o/ / de yang ci rigs par rnam pa gsum du rig par bya ste/ tshe 'di la bde bar gnas par bya ba'i bsam gtan dang / byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi yon tan sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / sems can gyi don bya ba'i bsam gtan no/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s all-inclusive meditative absorption? It should be regarded as being of two types: mundane and transcendent. In addition, it should be understood, according to circumstances, as being of three types: (1) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to abide in a state of ease during this life, (2) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to obtain for a bodhisattva qualities that relate to one-pointed concentration, and (3) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to act on behalf of sentient beings.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT ENABLES ONE TO ABIDE IN A STATE OF EASE DURING THIS LIFE [I.13.2.1]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan rnam par rtog pa thams cad dang bral ba/ lus dang sems kyis shin tu sbyangs ba skyed pa/ mchog tu rab tu zhi ba/ rlom sems dang bral ba/ ro myang ba med pa dang / mtshan ma thams cad dang bral ba gang yin pa 'di ni de dag gi tshe 'di la bde bar gnas pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], the meditative absorption of bodhisattvas that is free of all conceptual thought,[899] that gives rise to physical and mental agility,[900] that is a state of extreme tranquility,[901] that is free of [mistaken] conjecture,[902] that is not relished,[903] and that is free of all signs[904] should be understood as [the form of meditative absorption that is cultivated by bodhisattvas] in order to abide in a state of ease during their current life.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT GAINS THE SPIRITUAL QUALITIES RELATED TO ONE-POINTED CONCENTRATION [I.13.2.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan stobs bcu'i rigs kyis bsdus pa'i ting nge 'dzin rnam pa sna tshogs bsam gyis mi khyab cing tshad med pa sgrub par byed pa gang yin pa dang / ting nge 'dzin gang dag nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas rnams kyis kyang ming yang mi shes na snyoms par 'jug par lta ga la 'gyur ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnam par thar pa dang / zil gyis non pa'i skye mched dang / zad par gyi skye mched rnams dang / so so yang dag par rig pa dang / nyon mongs pa med pa dang / smon gnas shes pa la sogs pa'i yon tan nyan thos dang / thun mong pa rnams mngon par sgrub par byed pa gang yin pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi yon tan sgrub pa'i bsam gtan yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], the meditative absorption of bodhisattvas that is conducive to the acquisition of those manifold, inconceivable, and immeasurable forms of one-pointed concentration that are included within the lineages of the ten powers[905]—forms of one-pointed concentration that listeners and solitary realizers do not even know the names of, much less actually attain—as well as [the meditative absorption] that is conducive to the acquisition of those spiritual qualities that are possessed by bodhisattvas in a form that is not common to listeners, such as the [eight] deliverances,[906] the [eight] bases of mastery,[907] the [ten] universal bases,[908] the avoidance of conflict,[909] knowledge by resolve,[910] etc., should be understood as [the form of meditative absorption that is cultivated by bodhisattvas] in order to obtain a bodhisattva’s qualities that relate to one-pointed concentration.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT RELATES TO ACTING ON BEHALF OF SENTIENT BEINGS [I.13.2.3]

byang chub sems dpa'i sems can gyi don bya ba'i bsam gtan ni rnam pa bcu gcig ste/ snga ma bzhin du rig par bya'o/ / bsam gtan gang la brten na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams kyi bya ba don dang ldan pa dag la grogs su 'gro ba dang / sems can sdug bsngal ba rnams kyi sdug bsngal sel ba dang / rigs par ston pa dang / byas pa gzo zhing byas pa tshor ba ste/ phan 'dogs pa rnams la lan du phan 'dogs pa dang / 'jigs pa rnams las srung ba dang / sdug bsngal bar gnas pa rnams kyi mya ngan sel ba dang / yo byad med pa rnams la yo byad stobs pa dang / yang dag pa'i 'khor legs par sdud pa dang / sems dang mthun par 'jug pa dang / yang dag pa'i yon tan rnams kyis dga' bar byed pa dang / legs par tshar gcod pa dang / rdzu 'phrul gyis skrag par byed pa dang / 'dun par byed pa ste/

The meditative absorption that relates to acting on behalf of sentient beings should be understood as being of eleven types, in the manner that they were described earlier. [They are] (1a) the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon to assist beings with a variety of meaningful activities; (1b) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to remove the suffering of those who are experiencing suffering; (2) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to give instruction [to others] regarding what is proper; (3) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva] who feels a sense of gratitude and appreciation [relies upon] to do something in return for the favors [that he or she has received from others]; (4) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to protect [beings] from danger; (5) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to dispel the grief of those who are abiding in [a state of] misfortune; (6) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to provide objects that are a means of subsistence to those who lack them; (7) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to lead an assembly [of practitioners]; (8) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to comply with the minds [of others]; (9) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to encourage [others] by [declaring] their genuine good qualities; (10) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to suppress in a correct manner [those who engage in misconduct]; and (11) [the meditative absorption that a bodhisattva relies upon] to frighten [others in order to turn them away from nonvirtue] and to win them over [to the Buddha’s teaching] through [the use of] miraculous powers.
'di dag thams cad gcig tu bsdus pa ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan thams cad ces bya ste/ 'di las gong na yang med do/ / 'di las lhag pa yang med do/ /

All of these [forms of meditative absorption] combined together into one group are called the bodhisattvas’ “all-inclusive meditative absorption.” There are no [forms of meditative absorption] of greater significance than these and there are none besides these.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT IS DIFFICULT TO CARRY OUT [I.13.3]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dka' ba'i bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gsum du blta bar bya ste/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams bsam gtan la gnas pa mngon par sgrub pa rgya chen po rnam pa sna tshogs shin tu 'dres pa dag gis gnas nas/ rang dgar bsam gtan gyi bde ba mchog de bzlog ste/ so sor brtags nas/ sems can rnams la snying brtse bas sems can gyi don bya ba mang po dag dang / sems can yongs su smin par bya ba yang dag par mthong nas/ 'dod pa'i khams rnams su skye bar byed pa gang yin pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dka' ba'i bsam gtan dang po yin par rig par bya'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' bsam gtan la brten nas/ byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan dpag tu med grangs med bsam gyis mi khyab pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi yul thams cad las yang dag par 'das pa mngon par sgrub pa gang yin pa 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i bsam gtan gnyis pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' bsam gtan la brten nas/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar byed pa gang yin pa 'di ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i bsam gtan gsum pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that is difficult to carry out? It should be regarded as being of three types. Having dwelt in extensive, manifold states of meditative absorption which they have attained and to which they have become well accustomed, bodhisattvas voluntarily turn away from the supreme ease of those meditative absorptions and, [motivated] by sympathy toward [all] sentient beings, carefully consider the [kinds of] extensive actions [that will accomplish] the aims of sentient beings. Then, remaining vigilant about the spiritual ripening of sentient beings, they take birth in the desire realm [in order to fulfill those aims]. This should be understood as the first form of bodhisattvas’ meditative absorption that is difficult to carry out. Moreover, a bodhisattva relies upon meditative absorption to attain immeasurable, countless, and inconceivable forms of one-pointed concentration that are achieved by bodhisattvas but that are beyond the grasp of all listeners and solitary realizers. This should be understood as the second form of a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that is difficult to carry out. Further, a bodhisattva relies upon meditative absorption to attain unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment. This should be understood as the third form of a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that is difficult to carry out.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT IS DIRECTED EVERYWHERE [I.13.4]

de la thams cad kyi sgo nas bsam gtan gang zhe na/ rnam pa bzhir blta bar bya ste/ rtog pa dang bcas dpyod pa dang bcas pa dang / dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / tshim pa'i bde ba dang ldan pa dang / btang snyoms dang ldan pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that is directed everywhere? It should be regarded as being of four types: (1) that which is associated with deliberation and reflection,[911] (2) that which is associated with joy,[912] (3) that which is accompanied by the ease of pleasure,[913] and (4) that which is accompanied by equanimity.[914]
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION OF A TRUE SPIRITUAL BEING [I.13.5]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i skyes bu dam pa'i bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa lngar blta bar bya ste/ ro myang ba med pa dang / byams pa dang ldan pa dang / snying rje dang ldan pa dang / dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / btang snyoms dang ldan pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption of a true spiritual being? It should be regarded as being of five types. It is (1) [a meditative absorption] that is not relished, (2) one that is accompanied by [immeasurable] loving-kindness, (3) one that is accompanied by [immeasurable] compassion, (4) one that is accompanied by [immeasurable] joy, and (5) one that is accompanied by [immeasurable] equanimity.
MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION OF EVERY FORM [I.13.6]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i rnam pa thams cad kyi bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa drug dang rnam pa bdun te/ gcig tu bsdus na rnam pa bcu gsum yod par rig par bya ste/ dge ba'i bsam gtan dang / sprul pa sprul pa'i phyir lung du ma bstan pa'i bsam gtan dang / zhi gnas kyi phyogs dang / lhag mthong gi phyogs dang / bdag dang gzhan gyi don legs par nges par bsam pa'i bsam gtan dang / mngon par shes pa'i mthu yon tan mngon par sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / ming la dmigs pa dang / don la dmigs pa dang / zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma la dmigs pa dang / rab tu 'dzin pa'i mtshan ma la dmigs pa dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma la dmigs pa dang / tshe 'di la bde bar gnas pa dang / gzhan gyi don bya ba'i bsam gtan te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan rnam pa bcu gsum po 'di dag ni rnam pa thams cad kyi bsam gtan zhes bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption of every form? It should be understood as the thirteen types [that result from] combining together six types and seven types. They are (1) the meditative absorption that is virtuous; (2) the meditative absorption that is indeterminate and [is cultivated] in order to project emanations; (3) [the meditative absorption] that relates to quiescence and (4) [the meditative absorption] that relates to insight; (5) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to reflect correctly on one’s own and others’ aims; (6) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to achieve the qualities associated with the power of supernatural knowledge; (7) [the meditative absorption] which has names as its object;[915] (8) [the meditative absorption] which has meanings as its object;[916] (9) [the meditative absorption] which has the signs of quiescence as its object; (10) [the meditative absorption] which has the signs of retention as its object; (11) [the meditative absorption] which has the signs of equanimity as its object; (12) [the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to abide in a state of ease in this life; and (13) the meditative absorption [that is cultivated] in order to accomplish the aims of others. These thirteen forms of meditative absorption [that are cultivated by] bodhisattvas are called “[the meditative absorption] of every form.”
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT RELATES TO THE DISTRESSED AND WHAT THEY WANT [I.13.7]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i phongs shing 'dod pa'i bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa brgyad du blta bar bya ste/ dug dang / thog dang / rims drag po dang / 'byung po dang / gdon la sogs pa'i gnod pa yang dag par zhi ba sgrub pa'i gsang sngags rnams byin gyis rlob pa'i bsam gtan dang / khams 'khrugs pa las gyur pa'i nad rnam pa sna tshogs rnam par zhi bar byed pa'i bsam gtan dang / mu ge'i ngu 'bod chen po dag 'byung ba'i tshe char sgrub par byed pa'i bsam gtan dang / mi dang mi ma yin pas byas pa'i 'jigs pa sna tshogs chu dang skam la yod pa rnams las legs par yongs su bskyab pa'i bsam gtan dang / de bzhin du 'brog dgon pa na gnas pa zas dang / skom gyis phongs pa rnams la zas dang skom nye bar sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / dbul ba longs spyod med pa rnams kyi longs spyod nye bar sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / phyogs bcu dag na sems can bag med pa rnams la legs par bskul ba'i bsam gtan dang / sems can gyi bya ba byung ngo cog legs par bya ba'i bsam gtan no/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that relates to the distressed and what they want? It should be regarded as being of eight types. [They are] (1) the meditative absorption that governs the effectiveness of spells that quell misfortunes arising from poison, lightning, severe fever, illness, spirits, demons, etc.; (2) the meditative absorption that quells various kinds of illnesses caused by an imbalance of the constituents; (3) the meditative absorption that brings rain when severe famines are occurring; (4) the meditative absorption that saves [beings] from various kinds of human and nonhuman dangers that can occur in water or on dry land; (5) likewise, the meditative absorption that provides food and drink to those living in a forest wilderness who lack food and drink; (6) the meditative absorption that provides objects of material value to disciples who are in need of them; (7) the meditative absorption that correctly brings about the [spiritual] awakening of careless sentient beings throughout the ten directions; and (8) the meditative absorption that correctly carries out any proper activities relating to sentient beings that may have arisen.
THE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION THAT BRINGS HAPPINESS HERE AND IN THE NEXT WORLD [I.13.8]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i 'di dang gzhan du bde bar 'gyur ba'i bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa dgur blta bar bya ste/ rdzu 'phrul gyi cho 'phrul gyis sems can rnams gdul ba'i bsam gtan dang / kun rjod pa'i cho 'phrul dang / rjes su bstan pa'i cho 'phrul gyis sems can rnams gdul ba'i bsam gtan dang / sdig pa byed pa rnams la ngan song gis rnam par ston pa'i bsam gtan dang / sems can spobs pa med par gyur pa rnams la spobs pa nye bar sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / sems can brjed ngas pa rnams la dran pa nye bar sgrub pa'i bsam gtan dang / dam pa'i chos yun ring du gnas par bya ba'i phyir phyin ci ma log pa'i bstan bcos dang / snyan dngags dang / ma mo sbyar ba'i rnam par gzhag pa'i bsam gtan dang / 'jig rten pa rnams kyi bzo dang las kyi gnas don dang ldan pa sems can rnams la phan pa rnams dang / yi ge dang rtsis dang shod dgod pa dang grangs dang lag rtsis la sogs pa dang / khri dang khri'u dang / gdugs dang / lham la sogs pa dang / snod spyad rnam pa sna tshogs rnam pa mang po rnams 'byung bar byed pa'i bsam gtan dang / sems can ngan song gi sar skyes pa rnams kyi ngan song gi sdug bsngal de'i mod la bsal ba'i phyir 'od zer 'gyed pa'i bsam gtan no/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s meditative absorption that brings happiness here and in the next world? It should be regarded as being of nine types. [They are] (1) the meditative absorption that brings spiritual discipline to sentient beings by means of the marvelous ability of miraculous powers;[917] (2) the meditative absorption that brings spiritual discipline to sentient beings by means of the marvelous ability of revealing others’ thoughts;[918] (3) [the meditative absorption that brings spiritual discipline to sentient beings] by means of the marvelous ability of giving instruction;[919] (4) the meditative absorption that reveals the regions of lower realms to those who commit evil deeds; (5) the meditative absorption that bestows eloquence[920] on those sentient beings for whom it has been lost; (6) the meditative absorption that bestows recollection on those sentient beings whose recollection has become clouded; (7) the meditative absorption that enables one to arrange compositions of unerring treatises, poetry, and [instruction] manuals[921] so that the true Dharma will remain in existence for a long time; (8) the meditative absorption that promotes [the learning of] meaningful worldly crafts and occupations that are useful to sentient beings, such as scribal work, counting, record keeping, calculating, or signing, etc., as well as [the fabrication of] thrones, seats, parasols, shoes, etc., and various different kinds of vessels and other implements; and (9) the meditative absorption that emits light rays in order to relieve instantly the suffering of beings who have taken birth in the regions of the lower realms.
PURE MEDITATIVE ABSORPTION [I.13.9]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa bcur rig par bya ste/ 'jig rten pa'i dag pas rnam par dag pa ro myang ba med pa'i bsam gtan dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dag pas rnam par dag pa nyon mongs pa can ma yin pa'i bsam gtan dang / sbyor ba'i dag pas dag pa dang / dngos gzhi dag pas dag pa dang / dngos gzhi las khyad par gong ma rnam par dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan dang / 'jug pa dang / gnas pa dang / ldang ba la dbang ba rnam par dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan dang / bsam gtan bzlog na yang snyoms par 'jug pa la dbang ba dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan dang / mngon par shes pas rnam par 'phrul pa la dbang ba dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan dang / lta bar gyur pa thams cad dang bral ba rnam par dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan dang / nyon mongs pa dang shes bya'i sgrib pa spong ba rnam par dag pas rnam par dag pa'i bsam gtan no/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsam gtan dpag tu med pa 'di dag ni byang chub chen po'i 'bras bur gyur pa ste/ de dag la brten nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs nas/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas so/ / mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro/ / mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s pure meditative absorption? It should be regarded as being of ten types. [They are] (1) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of the mundane purity of not being relished; (2) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of the transcendent purity of being unafflicted; (3) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of having a pure form of preparation; (4) [the meditative absorption that is] pure by virtue of having a pure main stage; (5) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of having [attained] a pure [level] that is higher than and superior to the main stage; (6) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of [having attained] the purity of possessing mastery over entering, abiding in, and arising from [states of one-pointed concentration]; (7) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of [having attained] the purity that, even after having turned away from states of meditative absorption, still has the power to enter them again [at will]; (8) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of [having attained] the purity of mastery over the exercise of supernatural knowledge; (9) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of [having attained] the purity in which all forms of [mistaken] views have been eliminated; and (10) the meditative absorption that is pure by virtue of [having attained] the purity of abandoning the obscurations of the mental afflictions and the obscurations to that which needs to be known. These immeasurable forms of meditative absorption [give rise to] the fruit of great enlightenment and they are [spiritual qualities] on the basis of which bodhisattvas, after having completed the perfection of meditative absorption, have attained, shall attain, and are currently attaining unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment.
byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i gzhi'i rnal 'byor gyi gnas las bsam gtan gyi le'u ste bcu gsum pa'o// //
Within [Book I of] The Stage of a Bodhisattva, [known as] “The Object of Mental Application That Relates to the Support,” this completes the thirteenth chapter, entitled “Meditative Absorption.”
bam po bcu gnyis pa/
[shes rab]
14. WISDOM
sdom ni snga ma bzhin du rig par bya'o/ /
The summary verses should be understood in the same manner as before.
THE ESSENCE OF WISDOM [I.14.1]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i shes rab kyi ngo bo nyid gang zhe na/ shes bya thams cad la 'jug pa dang / shes bya thams cad la zhugs pa dang / chos rnams rab tu rnam par 'byed pa gang yin pa dang / rig pa'i gnas lnga po nang gi rig pa dang / gtan tshigs kyi rig pa dang / gso ba'i rig pa dang / sgra'i rig pa dang / bzo dang las kyi gnas kyi rig pa la dmigs nas 'jug pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab kyi ngo bo nyid yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is the essence of a bodhisattva’s wisdom? The discernment[922] of entities that [seeks] to attain [a realization of] or has attained [a realization of] all objects of knowledge[923] and that operates in relation to the five branches of learning—that is, (1) the inner science, (2) the science of logic, (3) the science of grammar, (4) the science of medicine, (5) and the science of crafts and occupations—should be understood as the essence of a bodhisattva’s wisdom.
ALL-INCLUSIVE WISDOM [I.14.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab thams cad gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gnyis su blta bar bya ste/ 'jig rten pa'i dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i'o/ / de yang mdor bsdu na rnam pa gsum du rig par bya ste/ shes bya la de kho na khong du chud cing rtogs par bya ba dang / ji skad bstan pa'i rig pa'i gnas lnga po rnams dang / tshogs gsum la mkhas par bya ba dang / sems can gyi don bya ba'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s all-inclusive wisdom? It should be regarded as being of two types: (1) that which is mundane, and (2) that which is transcendent. It should also be understood, in brief, as being of three types: (1) that which [is cultivated] in order to realize the object of knowledge that is [ultimate] reality; (2) that which [is cultivated] in order to develop expertise in the five branches of learning that were previously described as well as [expertise] in the three heaps;[924] and (3) that which [is cultivated] in order to accomplish the aims of sentient beings.
THE WISDOM THAT IS DIRECTED TOWARD REALIZING ULTIMATE REALITY [I.14.2.1]

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab gang chos bdag med pa brjod du med pa las brtsams te/ bden pa rtogs par bya ba 'am/ bden pa rtogs pa'i dus sam/ bden pa mngon par yang dag par rtogs pa yan chad mchog tu rab tu zhi bar nye bar gnas pa/ rnam par mi rtog pa spros pa thams cad dang bral ba/ chos thams cad la mnyam pa nyid kyi rjes su song ba/ spyi'i mtshan nyid chen po la zhugs pa/ shes bya'i mthar phyin pa/ sgro 'dogs pa dang / skur pa 'debs pa'i mtha' gnyis rnam par spangs pa'i phyir/ dbu ma'i lam du 'gro ba 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi de kho na khong du chud cing rtogs pa'i shes rab yin par rig par bya'o/ /

The wisdom of bodhisattvas that [is cultivated] in order to realize the truth that relates to the ineffable insubstantiality of entities, or that is present at the time that this truth is [first] being realized, or that occurs subsequent to that [transcendent] realization of truth [are forms of wisdom] that abide in a state of supreme peace, [forms of wisdom] that are free of conceptualization, [forms of wisdom] in which all [conceptual] elaboration has been eliminated, [forms of wisdom] that have arrived at [a realization of] the sameness of all entities, [forms of wisdom] that have attained [a realization of] the great general characteristic, [forms of wisdom] that have reached the end of objects of knowledge, and [forms of wisdom] that conform to the Middle Way in that they reject the two extremes of [falsely] attributing [a mode of being that does not exist] and [wrongly] discrediting [a mode of being that does exist]. This is what should be understood as the bodhisattva’s wisdom that [is cultivated] in order to realize [ultimate] reality.
THE WISDOM THAT DEVELOPS EXPERTISE REGARDING THE FIVE BRANCHES OF LEARNING AND THE THREE HEAPS [I.14.2.2]

rig pa'i gnas lnga la mkhas pa ni rgyas par snga ma bzhin du 'di lta ste/ stobs kyi rigs kyi le'u las 'byung ba dang 'dra bar rig par bya'o/ / tshogs gsum ni don dang ldan pa'i chos rnams kyi tshogs dang don dang mi ldan pa'i chos rnams kyi tshogs dang don dang ldan pa yang ma yin don dang mi ldan pa yang ma yin pa'i chos rnams kyi tshogs te/ gnas brgyad po 'di dag la shes rab kyis mkhas pa yongs su 'dzin na bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi phyir ye shes kyi tshogs chen po gong na med pa yongs su rdzogs par byed do/ /

Expertise in the five branches of learning should be understood in the manner that was explained previously in detail—that is, in the chapter entitled “The Lineages of the Powers.” For their part, the three heaps are (1) the heap of entities that are advantageous, (2) the heap of entities that are disadvantageous,[925] and (3) the heap of entities that are neither advantageous nor disadvantageous. Acquiring the expertise that consists of wisdom regarding these eight subjects fulfills the great, unsurpassed accumulation of wisdom [that is needed] in order to [attain] unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment.
THE WISDOM THAT ACCOMPLISHES THE AIMS OF SENTIENT BEINGS [I.14.2.3]
sems can gyi don bya ba ni snga ma bzhin du rnam pa bcu gcig kho nar rig par bya ste/ gnas de dag gi shes rab gang yin pa de ni sems can gyi don bya ba'i shes rab yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Further, the activities that accomplish the aims of sentient beings should be understood as the eleven types that [pertain to the situations which] were described previously. The wisdom that relates to those very situations should be understood as the wisdom that [is cultivated] in order to accomplish the aims of sentient beings.
THE WISDOM THAT IS DIFFICULT TO CARRY OUT [I.14.3]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gsum du blta bar bya ste/ chos bdag med pa zab mo shes par dka' ba dang / sems can rnams 'dul ba'i thabs shes par dka' ba dang / shes bya thams cad la sgrib pa med par shes pa mchog tu dka' ba'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s wisdom that is difficult to carry out? It should be regarded as being of three types: (1) that which is difficult to carry out in order to gain knowledge of the profound insubstantiality of entities; (2) that which is difficult to carry out in order to learn the means [of bringing about] the spiritual discipline of sentient beings; and (3) that which is supremely difficult to carry out in order to gain the knowledge that frees one from the obscurations to that which needs to be known.
THE WISDOM THAT IS DIRECTED EVERYWHERE [I.14.4]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i thams cad kyi sgo nas shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa bzhir blta bar bya ste/ nyan thos kyi sde snod dang / byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod las brtsams te/ thos pa las byung ba'i shes rab dang / bsam pa las byung ba'i shes rab dang / so sor brtags nas byang chub sems dpa'i bya ba la 'jug pa dang / bya ba ma yin pa las ldog pa'o/ / so sor brtags pa'i stobs kyis bsdus pa'i shes rab dang / bsgom pa'i stobs kyis bsdus pa'i mnyam par gzhag pa'i sa'i shes rab tshad med pa'o/ /

What is a bodhisattva’s wisdom that is directed everywhere? It should be regarded as being of four types: (1) the wisdom that derives from learning both the listener collection [of scriptures] and the bodhisattva collection [of scriptures]; (2) the wisdom that derives from reflection [upon the meanings contained in those two collections of scriptures]; (3) the wisdom that is supported by the strength of careful consideration and that is gained by having made a careful consideration of [what constitute] the proper activities that a bodhisattva should pursue and [what constitute] the improper ones that he or she should refrain from doing; and (4) the immeasurable wisdom that is supported by the strength of meditation and that relates to the stages of mental composure.[926]
THE WISDOM OF A TRUE SPIRITUAL BEING [I.14.5]

de la byang chub sems dpa' skyes bu dam pa rnams kyi skyes bu dam pa'i shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa lngar blta bar bya ste/ dam pa'i chos mnyan pas yang dag par thob pa dang / so sor nang gi tshul bzhin yid la byed pa dang ldan pa dang / bdag dang gzhan gyi don sgrub pa'i thabs dang ldan pa dang / chos rnams kyi chos gnas pa'i chos rnam par gnas pa phyin ci ma log pa las brtsams te/ shin tu rnam par dag pa gtan la dbab pa'i shes rab dang / nyon mongs pa rnam par spong ba'i shes rab bo/ / rnam grangs gzhan yang shes bya ji lta bar yod pa bzhin du 'jug pa'i phyir cha phra ba dang / shes bya ji snyed yod pa la 'jug pa'i phyir mkhas pa dang / ye shes kyi tshogs sngar yang dag par thob pa'i phyir lhan cig skyes pa dang / sangs rgyas rnams dang / sa chen po la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis yang dag par bstan pa'i chos dang don len cing 'dzin pa'i phyir lung dang ldan pa dang / bsam pa dag pa'i sa yan chad mthar thug par 'gro ba'i sa man chad yongs su bzung ba'i phyir rtogs pa dang ldan pa'o/ /

What is the wisdom of a true spiritual being that is possessed by a bodhisattva who is a true spiritual being? It should be regarded as being of five types: (1) [the wisdom] that has completed [the activity of] learning the true Dharma; (2) [the wisdom] that is accompanied by proper forms of attention that are directed internally in relation to oneself; (3) [the wisdom] that is accompanied by the means of attaining one’s own and others’ aims; (4) [the wisdom] that has been properly ascertained with regard to the unerring formulation and the settled nature of entities;[927] and (5) the wisdom that abandons the mental afflictions. Another [fivefold] formulation [of the wisdom of a true spiritual being] is the following: (1) [wisdom that is] subtle in that it gains an understanding of objects of knowledge in terms of the mode of being that represents their true nature; (2) [wisdom that is] skillful in that it gains an understanding of objects of knowledge in terms of the mode of being that represents their complete extent; (3) [wisdom that is] innate in that it is attained through a prior accumulation of wisdom; (4) [wisdom that is] endowed with [knowledge of] the scriptural teachings in that it takes up and upholds the meanings of Dharma [teachings] that have been imparted by buddhas and the bodhisattvas who have attained the great [ārya] stages; and (5) [wisdom that is] endowed with spiritual realization in that it has attained the levels ranging from the stage of a pure superior attitude[928] to the stage that is the perfect manner of going.[929]
WISDOM OF EVERY FORM [I.14.6]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i rnam pa thams cad kyi shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa drug dang rnam pa bdun te/ gcig tu bsdus na rnam pa bcu gsum yod par rig par bya ste/ bden pa rnams la sdug bsngal shes pa dang / kun 'byung ba shes pa dang / 'gog pa shes pa dang / lam shes pa dang / mthar thug pa zad pa shes pa dang / mi skye ba shes pa 'di ni shes rab rnam pa drug go/ / rnam pa bdun ni chos shes pa dang / rjes su rtogs pa shes pa dang / kun rdzob shes pa dang / mngon par shes pa shes pa dang / mtshan shes pa dang / stobs bcu sngon du 'gro ba'i shes pa dang / rig pa bzhi po dag la rig pa shes pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s wisdom of every form? It should be understood as being of the thirteen types [that result from] combining together six types and seven types. [The first six are,] with regard to the [four noble] truths, (1) knowledge of [the truth of] suffering; (2) knowledge of [the truth of] origination; (3) knowledge of [the truth of] cessation; (4) knowledge of [the truth of] the path; and, with regard to [the stage of] perfection, (5) the knowledge that [the outflows] have been terminated and (6) the knowledge that [the outflows] cannot arise again. These are the group of six types of wisdom. Further, the group of seven types [of wisdom] are (1) knowledge of entities; (2) subsequent knowledge; (3) knowledge of relative truth; (4) knowledge of the supernatural forms of knowledge; (5) knowledge of the major marks; (6) knowledge that precedes the ten powers; and (7) knowledge of the applications, which occurs in relation to the four applications.[930]
THE WISDOM THAT RELATES TO THE DISTRESSED AND WHAT THEY WANT [I.14.7]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i phongs shing 'dod pa'i shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa brgyad du blta bar bya ste/ chos rnams kyi rnam grangs shes pa las brtsams te/ byang chub sems dpa'i chos so so yang dag par rig pa dang / chos rnams kyi mtshan nyid shes pa las brtsams te/ don so so yang dag par rig pa dang / chos rnams kyi nges pa'i tshig shes pa las brtsams te/ nges pa'i tshig so so yang dag par rig pa dang / chos rnams kyi rnam pa'i gzhi'i rab tu dbye ba las brtsams te/ spobs pa so so yang dag par rig pa dang / phas kyi rgol ba thams cad tshar gcod pa byang chub sems dpa'i shes rab dang / bdag gi smra ba rnam par gzhag pa thams cad rnam par 'jog pa'i shes rab dang / khyim brgyud legs par bskyang ba dang / khyim 'byor par bya ba'i shes rab dang / rgyal po'i tshul dang / 'jig rten pa'i tha snyad kyi tshul rnams la byang chub sems dpa'i nges pa'i shes rab bo/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s wisdom that relates to the distressed and what they want? It should be regarded as being of eight types: (1) a bodhisattva’s informative knowledge of the Dharma that relates to an understanding of the formulations of Dharma [teachings]; (2) a bodhisattva’s informative knowledge of meaning that relates to an understanding of the [defining] characteristics [of entities]; (3) a bodhisattva’s informative knowledge of clear expression that relates to an understanding of the interpretation of Dharma [terms]; (4) a bodhisattva’s informative knowledge [that confers] eloquence and relates to making distinctions about the varieties of points that pertain to Dharma [teachings];[931] (5) a bodhisattva’s wisdom that defeats all disputation put forth by opponents; (6) the wisdom that establishes all the formulations of one’s own positions; (7) a bodhisattva’s wisdom that correctly preserves the propagation of a householder’s [family line] and brings prosperity to a family; (8) the wisdom that has ascertained the proper [form of] statecraft [to be followed by] a king and the proper conduct [to be pursued] in secular affairs.
THE WISDOM THAT BRINGS HAPPINESS HERE AND IN THE NEXT WORLD [I.14.8]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i 'di dang gzhan du bde bar 'gyur ba'i shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa dgur rig par bya ste/ nang gi rig pa la shin tu rnam par byang zhing rab tu gnas pa'i shes rab dang / gso ba'i rig pa dang / gtan tshigs kyi rig pa dang / sgra'i rig pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i bzo dang / las kyi gnas kyi rig pa la ni shin tu rnam par byang la/ rab tu gnas pa ni ma yin pa'i shes rab dang / rig pa rnam pa lnga po shin tu rnam par byang ba de dag nyid la brten nas/ gdul bya rmongs pa rnams dang / bag med pa rnams dang / zhum pa rnams dang / yang dag par zhugs pa gzhan dag la go rim bzhin du yang dag par bstan pa dang / yang dag par 'dzin du gzhug pa dang / yang dag par gzengs bstod pa dang / yang dag par dga' bar bya ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i shes rab gang yin pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s wisdom that brings happiness here and in the next world? It should be regarded as being of nine types: (1) the wisdom that has been well refined and well established in relation to the inner science; the wisdom that has been well refined but has not been well established[932] in relation to (2) the science of logic, (3) the science of grammar, (4) the science of medicine, and (5) the science of worldly crafts and occupations; and the bodhisattva’s wisdom that, on the basis of these five well-refined sciences, (6) educates, (7) causes to undertake [proper conduct], (8) stirs to action, and (9) gladdens, respectively, those disciples who are confused, heedless, discouraged, and correctly established [in Dharma practice].
PURE WISDOM [I.14.9]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dag pa'i shes rab gang zhe na/ de ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa bcur rig par bya ste/ de kho na'i don ji snyed yod pa dang / ji ltar yod pa bzhin du 'dzin pa'i phyir de kho na'i don rnam pa gnyis dang / rgyu dang 'bras bu legs par 'dzin pa'i phyir/ 'jug pa'i don rnam pa gnyis dang / phyin ci log dang phyin ci ma log pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su shes pa'i phyir len pa'i don rnam pa gnyis dang / bya ba dang bya ba ma yin pa thams cad yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su shes pa'i phyir thabs kyi don rnam pa gnyis dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa la kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / rnam par byang ba la rnam par byang ba yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su shes pa'i phyir mthar thug pa'i don kyang rnam pa gnyis te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab rnam pa lnga po rab tu dbye ba bcu po 'di dag ni rnam par dag pa mchog gis rnam par dag par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s pure wisdom? In brief, it should be understood as being of ten types. Two types [of pure wisdom] relate to the nature of reality,[933] in that they grasp reality in terms of (1) the mode of being that represents their complete extent and (2) the mode of being that represents their true nature. Two types [of pure wisdom] relate to the subject of progression,[934] in that they correctly grasp (3) causes and (4) effects. Two types [of pure wisdom] relate to the subject of grasping,[935] in that they have a complete understanding of (5) error and (6) absence of error. Two types [of pure wisdom] relate to the subject of [what constitutes a proper] means, in that they have a complete and true understanding of (7) actions that should be carried out and (8) actions that should not be carried out. Two types [of pure wisdom] relate to the subject of perfection,[936] in that they have a complete and true understanding of both (9) the process by which afflicting entities cause affliction[937] and (10) the process by which purifying entities bring about purification.[938] These five aspects and ten types of wisdom [that are attained] by bodhisattvas should be understood as being pure in terms of the highest form of purity.

de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi shes rab shin tu rnam par nges shing dpag tu med pa 'di ni byang chub chen po'i 'bras bur 'gyur ba ste/ de la brten nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs te/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o/ /

These immeasurable and well-ascertained [forms of] wisdom give rise to the fruit of great enlightenment and [they are spiritual qualities] on the basis of which bodhisattvas, after having completed the perfection of wisdom, attain unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment.

'di ni mdo sde gzhan de dang de dag tu bcom ldan 'das kyis pha rol tu phyin pa drug po dag thor bu thor bu bstan pa rnams kyi mdor bsdus te bstan pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa'i mdo sde gang las sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'am/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i bar dag bstan pa 'am/ bshad pa 'byung ba de ni sbyin pa'i ngo bo nyid nas/ rnam par dag pa'i sbyin pa'i bar du sbyar bar bya ste/ de'i bsdu ba yang ci rigs par rig par bya'o/ / de bzhin du tshul khrims la sogs pa shes rab la thug pa ji skad bstan pa gzhan dag gi sbyar ba dang bsdu ba yang ci rigs par rig par bya'o/ /

Now then, this [description] of the six perfections that were taught by the Blessed One intermittently throughout the sutras should be understood as constituting a concise summary [of them]. The [brief] presentations and [detailed] explanations that appear in the sutras that were taught by the Tathāgata—whether they are of generosity or [any of the other perfections] ranging up to wisdom—should be investigated in relation to [the nine categories ranging from] the essence of generosity up to pure generosity. A summary of [generosity] should also be understood in a manner that is appropriate [to that method of description]. Similarly, an investigation [of the canonical teachings on] as well as a summary of the other [five] perfections, ranging from morality to wisdom, should be understood in a manner that is appropriate [to each of those types of presentation].

de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dag tu skyes pa'i rabs dpag tu med pa dka' ba spyod pa dang ldan pa gang yin pa de dag thams cad las sbyin pa dang ldan pa rnams ni sbyin pa las brtsams par rig par bya'o/ / sbyin pa ji lta ba de bzhin du tshul khrims dang / bzod pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / bsam gtan dang / shes rab dang ldan pa thams cad kyang shes rab las brtsams par rig par bya'o/ / kha cig ni sbyin pa kho na las brtsams pa nas/ kha cig ni shes rab kho na las brtsams pa'i bar dang / kha cig ni gnyis 'dres pa dang / kha cig ni gsum 'dres pa dang / kha cig ni bzhi 'dres pa dang / kha cig ni lnga 'dres pa dang / kha cig ni pha rol tu phyin pa drug po thams cad las brtsams par rig par bya'o/ /

In addition, all those birth stories of the tathāgatas containing [descriptions of] arduous bodhisattva activities [that were carried out] during immeasurable numbers of lives that deal with generosity should be understood as relating to [the explanation of the perfection of] generosity. Just as with generosity, all those [birth stories] that contain [descriptions] of morality, patience, effort, meditative absorption, and wisdom should be understood as relating to [the explanations that range from the perfection of morality up to the perfection of] wisdom. It should be understood that some [of the birth stories] only have to do with generosity; some only have to do with [each of the remaining perfections up to] wisdom; some have to do with a combination of two [of the perfections]; some have to do with a combination of three; some have to do with a combination of four; some have to do with a combination of five; and some have to do with all six of the perfections.

pha rol tu phyin pa drug po 'di dag gis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub yang dag par thob par byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni dkar po'i chos kyi chu chen po dang / dkar po'i chos kyi rgya mtsho chen po zhes bya ste/ sems can thams cad kyi rnam pa thams cad phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu rin po che chen po sbyin pa yin no/ / de ltar de dag gis bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs yang dag par 'grub pa dpag tu med pa de'i 'bras bu ji ltar bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub dang mthun pa lta bu gzhan med do/ /

The bodhisattvas who are seeking to arrive at unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment by means of these six perfections are called “those who are great foaming seas of pure spiritual qualities” and “those who are great oceans of pure spiritual qualities.” [They are also] called “those who provide[939] the great jewels that give rise to every kind of good fortune for all sentient beings.” Moreover, there is no other fruit of their attainment of the immeasurable accumulations of merit and wisdom that is comparable to that of unsurpassed true and complete enlightenment.
byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i gzhi'i rnal 'byor gyi gnas las shes rab kyi le'u ste bcu bzhi pa'o// //
Within [Book I of] The Stage of a Bodhisattva, [known as] “The Object of Mental Application That Relates to the Support,” this completes the fourteenth chapter, entitled “Wisdom.”
[bsdu ba'i dngos po]
15. THE PRINCIPLES FOR ATTRACTING A FOLLOWING
sdom ni snga ma bzhin du rig par bya'o/ /
The summary verses should be understood in the same manner as before.
AGREEABLE SPEECH [I.15.1]
THE ESSENCE OF AGREEABLE SPEECH [I.15.1.1]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snyan par smra ba'i ngo bo nyid gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams la yid du 'ong ba dang / bden pa dang / chos dang mthun pa don dang ldan pa'i tshig smra ba 'di ni mdor bsdu na byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snyan par smra ba'i ngo bo nyid do/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is the essence of bodhisattvas’ agreeable speech? Here a bodhisattva utters speech to sentient beings that is appealing, truthful, relates to Dharma, and is meaningful. In brief, this is the essence of bodhisattvas’ agreeable speech.
ALL-INCLUSIVE AGREEABLE SPEECH [I.15.1.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snyan par smra ba thams cad gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gsum du blta bar bya ste/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa'i ngag gang yang dag par dga' bar byed pa ni/ byang chub sems dpa' khro gnyer med la gsong por smra zhing / bzhin gyi mdangs 'byin pa 'dzum pa sngon du gtong zhing tshig gang gis bde ba dang / bde legs su 'gyur ba yongs su 'dri ba'am/ khams snyoms pa yongs su 'dri ba'am/ mtshan mo dang / nyin mo bde ba yongs su 'dri ba'am/ tshur shog legs par 'ongs so zhes smra ba'am/ rnam pa de lta bu la sogs pa dag gis 'jig rten pa'i tshul grong khyer ba nyid dang / mthun par 'jug cing sems can rnams so sor yang dag par dga' bar byed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i ngag gang kun tu dga' bar byed pa ni byang chub sems dpa' sems can gang bdag nyid kyi 'byor pa khong du ma chud pa rnams la bu 'byor pa'am/ chung ma 'byor pa'am/ nye du 'byor pa'am/ nor 'byor pa'am/ 'bru 'byor pa mthong na bsnyad cing kun tu dga' bar byed pa'am/ dad pa dang / tshul khrims dang / thos pa dang / gtong ba dang / shes rab 'byor pas kun tu dga' bar byed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i ngag gang rnam pa thams cad kyi yon tan dang ldan pa'i chos ston pa dang ldan pa ni sems can rnams la phan pa dang bde ba'i phyir/ rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par nye bar gnas pa dang / phan pa'i mchog gis phan 'dogs par gyur pa ste/ 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snyan par smra ba rab tu dbye bas thams cad yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s all-inclusive agreeable speech? It should be regarded as being of three types. (1) Here it is the speech of a bodhisattva that is friendly,[940] and it is the speech by which a bodhisattva who refrains from frowning, who speaks politely,[941] and who shows a welcoming facial expression accompanied by a smile, following social custom and polite behavior, extends a friendly greeting to persons by asking if they are well and enjoying good fortune, if they are in good health, if their day or night has gone well, or expresses some other form of greeting, such as, “Welcome, please draw near.” (2) It is also the speech of a bodhisattva that pleases [beings], and the speech by which a bodhisattva, having seen sentient beings’ good fortune relating to their children that had not [previously] been known—or their good fortune relating to a wife or husband, their good fortune relating to family relatives, their good fortune relating to wealth, and their good fortune relating to crops—comments on [that good fortune] and [in doing so] pleases them. Alternatively, he or she pleases them [by commenting on] their development of faith, morality, learning, generosity, or wisdom. (3) It is also a bodhisattva’s speech that contains Dharma teachings endowed with every type of [spiritual] good quality, that is continuously and uninterruptedly concerned with bringing benefit and happiness to sentient beings, and that is beneficial to them in terms of the highest kind of benefit. These should be understood as the varieties of bodhisattvas’ all-inclusive agreeable speech.

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snyan par smra ba thams cad ni mdor bsdu na de ni rnam pa gnyis su blta bar bya ste/ 'jig rten gyi tshul dang ldan pa dang / yang dag pa'i chos bstan pa dang ldan pa'o/ / de la yang dag par dga' bar byed pa'i ngag gang yin pa dang / kun tu dga' bar byed pa gang yin pa de ni 'jig rten gyi tshul dang ldan par rig par bya'o/ / de la ngag gang dag gis phan 'dogs pas mchog tu phan 'dogs par nye bar gnas par bstan pa gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa'i chos bstan pa dang ldan par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a concise presentation of bodhisattvas’ all-agreeable speech? It should be regarded as being of two types: (1) that which corresponds to worldly affairs[942] and (2) that which corresponds to correct Dharma instruction. Regarding this, the speech that is friendly and [the speech] that pleases [sentient beings] should be understood as [the form of agreeable speech] that corresponds to worldly affairs. Regarding this [topic], the speech that is beneficial, that relates to the highest form of benefit, and that is declared [to others in the form of beneficial instruction] should be understood as [the form of agreeable speech] that corresponds to correct Dharma instruction.
AGREEABLE SPEECH THAT IS DIFFICULT TO CARRY OUT [I.15.1.3]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i snyan par smra ba gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa gsum du blta bar bya ste/ byang chub sems dpa' gsod pa'i dgra phyir rgol ba rnams la shin tu rnam par dag cing skyon med pa'i sems kyis so sor brtags nas yang dag par dga' bar byed pa'am/ kun tu dga' bar byed pa'am/ phan par bya ba'i tshig brjod pa gang yin pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i snyan par smra ba dang po yin par rig par bya'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' sems can shas cher rmongs shing dbang po rtul ba rnams la so sor brtags nas/ yongs su yi chad pa med cing / chos dang mthun pa'i gtam brjod cing skyo ba dang du blangs te/ rig pa'i chos dge ba 'dzin du 'jug pa gang yin pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i snyan par smra ba gnyis pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / yang byang chub sems dpa' sems can g.yon can dang sgyu ma mkhan po dang / slob dpon dang / bla ma dang / yon gnas slu bar byed pa/ log par zhugs pa rnams la kun nas mnar sems kyi sems med pa dang / khong khro ba'i sems med par yang dag par dga' bar byed pa dang / kun tu dga' bar byed pa dang / phan par bya ba'i tshig brjod pa gang yin pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i dka' ba'i snyan par smra ba gsum pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s agreeable speech that is difficult to carry out? It should be regarded as being of three types: (1) When a bodhisattva, after having engaged in careful consideration with a mind that is very pure and free of any defilement, utters friendly, pleasing, or beneficial speech toward murderers, adversaries, and enemies, this should be understood as the first type of agreeable speech that is difficult for a bodhisattva to carry out. (2) Moreover, when a bodhisattva, after having engaged in careful consideration and without becoming discouraged, engages in conversation that pertains to Dharma with beings who are very ignorant and whose faculties are [very] dull, and when he or she, after having [willingly] accepted any trouble [relating to this effort], causes them to take up a [form of] Dharma that is proper and virtuous, this should be understood as the second type of agreeable speech that is difficult for a bodhisattva to carry out. (3) In addition, when a bodhisattva utters friendly, pleasing, or beneficial speech with a mind that is free of animosity and anger to beings who are devious and deceitful, who are established in wrongful forms of practice, and who mislead teachers, preceptors, venerable persons, and persons who are worthy of being honored, this should be understood as the third type of agreeable speech that is difficult for a bodhisattva to carry out.
AGREEABLE SPEECH THAT IS DIRECTED EVERYWHERE [I.15.1.4]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i thams cad kyi sgo nas snyan par smra ba gang zhe na/ de ni rnam pa bzhir blta bar bya ste/ sgrib pa spang bar bya ba dang / bde 'gror skye bar bya ba'i phyir snga rol du bya ba'i chos bstan pa dang / sgrib pa dang bral zhing sems kyi nyams bde ba dang ldan te yang dag phul gyi 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi dang ldan pa'i chos bstan pa dang / sems can khyim pa dang / rab tu byung ba bag med pa rnams bag med pa'i spyod pa las bslang ste/ bag yod pa'i spyod pa la dgod pa'i phyir yang dag par bskul ba dang / the tshom byung ngo cog bsal ba'i phyir chos bstan pa dang / 'bel ba'i gtam rnam par nges par bya ba'o/ /

Regarding this [topic] what is a bodhisattva’s agreeable speech that is directed everywhere? It should be regarded as being of four types: (1) the Dharma instruction that is to be given at an early stage[943] in order to abandon obstacles and reach a happy migratory state; (2) the most excellent Dharma instruction pertaining to the four noble truths that is given to one who is free of the obstacles and whose mind is fit; (3) [the Dharma instruction] that correctly admonishes those beings who are inattentive, both householders and homeless ascetics, in order to turn them away from heedless conduct and cause them to become established in a mindful form of conduct; and (4) the Dharma instruction that settles [questions relating to] a [Dharma] discussion and that is meant to remove whatever doubt may have arisen.
THE AGREEABLE SPEECH OF A TRUE SPIRITUAL BEING [I.15.1.5]
