Regarding this [topic], (1) when a bodhisattva performs an act of worship in relation to a tathāgata or a tathāgata shrine with his or her own hand and does not have to be caused to do so at the direction of others because of heedlessness or idleness; (2) when he or she performs [an act of worship] with reverence and not in a dismissive manner; when he or she performs [an act of worship] (3) while remaining undistracted and (4) with a mind that is free of affliction; (5) when he or she does not worship [a tathāgata or a tathāgata shrine] with a counterfeit object out of hypocrisy so that [he or she might receive] gain and honor from eminent persons who have strong faith in the Buddha, such as the members of a royal family, etc.; and (6) when he or she does not [perform an act of worship] using [objects] such as ointments containing yellow orpiment,[989] ablutions [made with] ghee, incense made from guggulu resin, or arka flowers, or with any other unsuitable objects,[990] this should be known as the six aspects of worship that are free of affliction.

rnyed pa dang bkur sti'i mchod pa rgya che ba dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa can ma yin pa de yang byang chub sems dpa' longs spyod kyi gzhi rang gi zho shas bsgrubs pa rnams sam/ gzhan las yongs su btsal ba rnams sam/ yo byad la dbang thob pa rnams kyis de bzhin gshegs pa 'am/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la mchod pa byed de/ de la yo byad la dbang thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' lus gnyis sam/ gsum mam/ lus mang po lus bye ba khrag khrig 'bum phrag du ma'i bar dag mngon par sprul nas/ lus de dag thams cad kyis de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la phyag 'tshal te/ lus de dag re re la yang lag pa brgya 'am/ lag pa stong ngam/ de bas kyang lhag pa dag sprul nas/ lag pa de dag thams cad kyis lha'i las yang dag par 'das pa'i me tog mchog tu dri zhim pa/ mchog tu yid du 'ong ba dag gis de bzhin gshegs pa de dag la mngon par 'thor ba dang / lus de dag thams cad kyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i yang dag pa'i yon tan ldan pa'i bstod pa shin tu rgya chen po dag brjod cing / lus de dag thams cad kyi dpung rgyan dang / nor bus spras pa'i rna cha gdub kor rnams dang / gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan rnam pa sna tshogs mchog tu gyur pa gya nom pa dag de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la 'bul zhing 'dogs par byed de/ de lta bu dang mthun pa'i yo byad la dbang thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni rang gi sems la dbang yod pa'i mchod pa byed de/ des ni sangs rgyas 'byung ba la re bar byas shing don du gnyer bar bya mi dgos so/ /

Moreover, a bodhisattva performs such an eminent act of worship that is free of affliction and that is accomplished with wealth and honor in relation to a tathāgata or a tathāgata shrine, either with objects of wealth that he or she obtained with the strength of his or her own arms,[991] [objects of wealth] that were solicited from others, or [objects of wealth] that were obtained through the controlling power over implements.[992] Regarding this [point], a bodhisattva who has attained the controlling power over implements emanates one, two, or many bodies, up to many trillions of trillions[993] of bodies, and then makes prostration to the tathāgatas with all of these bodies. Moreover, after emanating a hundred hands, a thousand hands, or even more than that for each of these bodies, he or she, with all of these [hands], scatters over the tathāgatas supremely fragrant and supremely beautiful flowers that surpass those of the gods. All of these exalted bodies that possess the excellent physical qualities of a tathāgata voice hymns of praise. With all of these bodies, he or she offers various kinds of excellent and exceptional armlets, bracelets, and jewel earrings to the tathāgatas and holds up [for them various kinds of excellent and exceptional] parasols, banners, and pennants. These [acts], as well as others of a similar type, are acts of worship that are subject to [the power of] one’s mind and are carried out by a bodhisattva who has attained the controlling power over implements. This [kind of bodhisattva] also does not need to wish for or long for the appearance of a buddha.
de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar de ni phyir mi ldog pa'i sa la zhugs pas sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad du thogs pa med par 'gro ba'i phyir ro/ /

Why is that? [This bodhisattva does not need to wish for the appearance of a buddha] since he or she is able to travel in an unimpeded manner to all the buddha fields, by virtue of having reached the stage of irreversibility.
WORSHIP THAT CONSISTS OF SPIRITUAL PRACTICE [I.16.1.10]

byang chub sems dpa' longs spyod rang gi zho shas bsgrubs pa yang med la/ gzhan las yongs su btsal te rnyed pa yang med/ byang chub sems dpa' longs spyod la dbang thob pa yang ma yin yang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod pa gang ci yang rung ba 'dzam bu gling ngam/ gling bzhi pa'am/ stong ngam/ stong gnyis sam/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'am/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams mtha' yas mu med pa dag na chung ngu dang / 'bring dang / chen po yod pa de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' dad pa can gyis dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / rgya chen po la mos pa dang ldan pa'i sems kyis khyab par byas nas rjes su yi rang bar byed de/ de yang byang chub sems dpa'i tshegs chung ngus de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa chen po tshad med pa/ byang chub kyi tshogs chen pos yongs su bsdus pa yin te/ de la ni byang chub sems dpa' rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par sems nyams bde ba dang / sems dga' bas brtson par bya'o/ /

Even though a bodhisattva may not possess objects of wealth that were acquired by the strength of his or her own arms or [objects of wealth] that were acquired through having been solicited from others, and even though he or she may not be a bodhisattva who has attained the controlling power over implements, a bodhisattva who possesses faith can expand his or her mind that is possessed of joy and great devotion [so as to consider] all the lesser, intermediate, and great acts of worship that are being carried out [by others] in this Rose Apple Continent,[994] in this [world that is made up of] four continents, or in the thousand world spheres, the double-thousand world spheres, and the great triple-world spheres, up to the limitless world spheres of the ten directions, and rejoice at them. This, too, is a great and immeasurable form of tathāgata worship that a bodhisattva can perform with little difficulty and that obtains a great accumulation [of merit] for the sake of enlightenment, [and it is one] which a bodhisattva should carry out with a happy mind and an elated mind, continually and without interruption.

de la byang chub sems dpa' ni cung zad cung zad dang / yud tsam yud tsam du tha na ba 'jos tsam gyi bar du yang sems can srog chags 'byung po thams cad la byams pa'i sems sgom par byed/ snying rje dang ldan pa dang / dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / btang snyoms dang ldan pa'i sems sgom par byed/ de bzhin du 'du byed thams cad la mi rtag pa'i 'du shes dang / mi rtag pa la sdug bsngal gyi 'du shes dang / sdug bsngal la bdag med pa'i 'du shes dang / mya ngan las 'das pa la phan yon gyi 'du shes sgom par byed/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa rjes su dran pa dang / chos dang / dge 'dun dang / pha rol tu phyin pa rjes su dran pa sgom par byed/ de bzhin du cung zad cung zad dang / yud tsam yud tsam la yang chos thams cad la bzod pa chung ngu'i shes pa phyogs gcig pas kyang brjod du med pa'i chos kyi ngo bo nyid de bzhin nyid la mos shing rnam par mi rtog pa dang / mtshan ma med pa'i sems kyis gnas par byed na/ de'i gong dang de las lhag par lta ci smos/ de bzhin du byang chub sems dpas tshul khrims kyi sdom pa yongs su bsrung ba dang / zhi gnas dang / lhag mthong dang / byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos rnams la brtson par byed pa dang / de bzhin du pha rol tu phyin pa rnams dang / bsdu ba'i dngos po rnams la yang dag par brtson par byed pa de ni byang chub sems dpa'i sgrub par gtogs pas de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa'i mchog dam pa gya nom pa/ gong na med pa yin te/ snga ma'i rnyed pa dang / bkur sti'i mchod pa rnam pa thams cad pa yang / mchod pa de'i brgya'i cha dang / stong gi char yang nye bar mi 'gro ba nas rgyas par rgyu'i bar du yang nye bar mi 'gro ste/

Regarding this [topic], when a bodhisattva meditates upon a mind that possesses loving-kindness toward all living beings for a little while, for a moment, even merely for the length of time that it takes to milk a cow, or when he or she meditates upon a mind that is accompanied by compassion, [a mind] that is accompanied by joy, and [a mind] that is accompanied by equanimity; likewise, when he or she meditates upon the concept of impermanence in relation to all conditioned entities, the concept of suffering in relation to impermanence, the concept of selflessness in relation to suffering, and the concept of being advantageous in relation to nirvana; likewise, when he or she meditates upon recollection of the Tathāgata and recollection of the Dharma, the Sangha, and the perfections; likewise, when he or she has generated devotion toward the suchness that is the ineffable [ultimate] nature of all entities with even just a limited [form of] the awareness that possesses a weak amount of forbearance[995] and abides for a little while, for a moment, in a [state of] mind that is free of conceptualization and free of signs, much less if [he or she generates and abides in] a [form of awareness] that is higher than this or greater than this; likewise, when he or she preserves the bodhisattva [system of] moral discipline, exerts him- or herself in practicing quiescence and insight, as well as the qualities that are conducive to enlightenment; likewise, when he or she exerts him- or herself correctly in practicing the perfections and the principles for attracting a following, this is a bodhisattva’s [form of] tathāgata worship that consists of [spiritual] practice [and it is] the foremost, best, most excellent, and unsurpassed [form of tathāgata worship]. It is the [form of] worship in relation to which all the preceding kinds of worship that are carried out with wealth and honor do not reach even a hundredth part, [in relation to which] they do not even reach a thousandth part, etc., up to [it is the form of worship in relation to which] they do not reach [any level of] factoring.

de ni rnam pa bcu po de dag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa'i bye brag rnam pa thams cad yin par rig par bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa ji lta ba bzhin du chos la mchod pa dang / dge 'dun la mchod pa yang de dang 'dra bar ci rigs par rig par bya'o/ /

This [presentation] consisting of ten aspects should be understood as [one that describes] worship of the tathāgatas in all of its forms. Just as with [the description of] worship of the tathāgatas, [the descriptions of] worship of the Dharma and worship of the Sangha should be understood in a similar way, according to the particular circumstances [of those topics].

de la dkon mchog gsum la mchod pa rnam pa bcu po de dag byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni de bzhin gshegs pa la dmigs pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa drug gis byed de/ yon tan gyi zhing bla na med pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / phan 'dogs pa bla na med pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / rkang med dang / rkang gnyis pa la sogs pa sems can thams cad kyi mchog tu gyur pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / u dum wA ra'i me tog bzhin du shin tu dkon pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams na gcig pu 'byung ste/ 'ba' zhig pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / 'jig rten dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i phun sum tshogs pa'i don thams cad ston pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa ste/ de'i lhag pa'i bsam pa drug po 'di dag gis de bzhin gshegs pa 'am/ de'i chos sam/ de'i dge 'dun la mchod pa byas pa ni chung ngu yang 'bras bu dpag tu med par 'gyur na/ mang po lta ci smos/

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva who carries out these ten forms of worship of the Three Jewels does so with six types of superior attitude that hold the tathāgatas as their object. [They are] (1) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as the unsurpassed field of virtue; (2) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as the unsurpassed benefactors; (3) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as the foremost of all sentient beings—whether they have no feet or are two-footed, etc.; (4) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as extremely rare, like the udumbara flower; (5) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as unique in that they appear as the sole [enlightened being] within a world system consisting of a great triple-thousand worlds; and (6) the superior attitude [that regards the tathāgatas] as the refuge for all matters relating to mundane and transcendent forms of excellence. Even [a bodhisattva’s] minor act of worship of a tathāgata [that is carried out] with these six types of superior attitude, or his or her [minor act of worship] of the Dharma or the Sangha [that is carried out with similar forms of these six types of superior attitude], yields an immeasurably great result; how much more would it be so for [an act of worship] that is extensive.
SERVING A SPIRITUAL TEACHER [I.16.2]

de la rnam pa du dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen du rig par bya/ rnam pa du zhig gis ni dge ba'i bshes gnyen nyid don yod pa yin/ rnam pa du zhig dang ldan na/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen dad pa'i gzhi'i gnas la gnas pa yin/ byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du gyur pa'i 'dul ba rnams la dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi bya ba ni du zhig yod/ byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen la brten pa ni rnam pa du zhig yod/ 'du shes rnam pa dus ni byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos mnyan par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos nyan pa na/ gang zag chos smra ba de la gnas du zhig la ni yid la mi byed par bya zhe na/

Regarding this [topic], what characteristics does a bodhisattva possess in order to be known as a spiritual teacher? What characteristics cause the position of a spiritual teacher to be fruitful? What characteristics should a spiritual teacher possess in order to take on the status of being an object of faith? What are the duties that a bodhisattva who is a spiritual teacher should carry out in relation to his or her disciples? What are the forms of service that a bodhisattva should perform in relation to a spiritual teacher? What kind of conceptions should a bodhisattva maintain when he or she listens to the Dharma in the presence of a spiritual teacher? What circumstances should the bodhisattva who is listening to the Dharma in the presence of a spiritual teacher avoid bringing to mind in relation to that person who is his or her Dharma teacher?
THE ATTRIBUTES OF A SPIRITUAL TEACHER [I.16.2.1]

de la rnam pa brgyad dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnam pa thams cad rdzogs pa yin par rig par bya ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa'i tshul khrims rnams la gnas shing ma nyams pa dang / skyon med par byed pas tshul khrims la gnas pa yin/ blo ma byang ba ma yin pas mang du thos pa yin/ bsgoms pa las byung ba'i dge ba gang yang rung ba thob cing / zhi gnas dang lhag mthong thob pas rtogs pa dang ldan pa yin/ snying rje dang ldan pas snying rje ba can yin te/ de tshe 'di la rang gi bde bar gnas pa yal bar bor nas gzhan dag gi don la sbyor ba yin/ de gzhan dag la chos ston pa ni bag tsha ba'i 'jigs pas dran pa dang / spobs pa nyams pa med pas 'jigs pa med pa yin/ gzhan dag gis brnyas pa rnams dang / 'phya ba dang / bsting ba dang / ngan du brjod pa dang / ngan du smra ba la sogs pa mi 'dod pa'i tshig gi lam rnams dang / sems can gyi log par zhugs pa rnam pa sna tshogs rnams bzod pa yin/ 'khor bzhi po dag la chos bstan pa la stobs dang ldan zhing ngal ba med pas yid yongs su mi skyo ba yin/ tshig chos nyid las ma nyams shing gsal te/ tshig gi bya ba dang ldan pas dge ba'i tshig dang ldan pa yin no/ /

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva’s spiritual teacher who is possessed of eight attributes should be known as one who is complete in every aspect.[996] (1) He or she is one who maintains a virtuous way of life by being one who adheres to [the precepts of] a bodhisattva’s morality of restraint and one who keeps them whole and unflawed.[997] (2) He or she is one who possesses extensive learning by not being one who has failed to develop understanding. (3) He or she is also one who is endowed with knowledge by being one who has attained any of the virtuous qualities that derive from meditation and by being one who has attained [any of the virtuous qualities that pertain to] quiescence and insight. (4) He or she is sympathetic [in the sense of being] a compassionate person who has given up any interest in abiding in [a state of] ease in this life and one who is dedicated to the welfare of others. (5) He or she is possessed of self-confidence [in the sense that], when teaching the Dharma to others, his or her recollection and clarity of understanding[998] are not lost due to the fear that arises from shyness. (6) He or she is also one who patiently forbears unwelcome and undesirable remarks from others that are contemptuous, derisive, abusive, and injurious, etc., as well as various kinds of wrongful behavior carried out by beings. (7) He or she is also one who does not become mentally weary [in the sense that] he or she remains strong, exercises much careful consideration, and is tireless when teaching Dharma to the fourfold following.[999] (8) He or she is one whose speech is appealing in that he or she is endowed with the skillful qualities of speech[1000] and one who is naturally articulate and distinct in his or her speech.
MAKING THE ROLE OF A SPIRITUAL TEACHER FRUITFUL [I.16.2.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen de lta bu'i yon tan gyi rnam pa thams cad dang ldan pa ni rnam pa lngas dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi bya ba don yod pa yin te/ de ni snga nas kyang gzhan dag la phan pa dang bde bar 'dod pa yin/ phan pa dang bde ba de yang yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes pa yin/ de la blo phyin ci log tu mi 'gyur ba yin/ thabs gang dang chos bstan pa'i tshul gang gis sems can gang 'dul nus pa de la nus shing mthu yod pa dang / yid yongs su mi skyo ba yin/ sems can tha ma dang 'bring dang / khyad par du 'phags pa thams cad la phyogs 'dzin pa med de/ snying rje snyoms pa yin no/ /

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva who is a spiritual teacher and who is endowed with all the virtuous qualities causes the activities of a spiritual teacher to become fruitful in five ways: (1) From the very outset, he or she is desirous of benefiting others and bringing them happiness. (2) He or she also truly knows what is beneficial and will bring happiness and is not erroneous in his or her opinion about these [two aims]. (3) He or she has the ability and the power to spiritually tame any being who is capable [of being tamed] by whatever means and whatever form of Dharma teaching [is most suitable]. (4) He or she avoids becoming mentally weary, and (5) he or she feels compassion equally toward all beings and does not show any partiality toward those who are inferior, average, or superior.
THE CHARACTERISTICS THAT MAKE A SPIRITUAL TEACHER WORTHY OF BEING AN OBJECT OF FAITH [I.16.2.3]

de la dge ba'i bshes gnyen de ni rnam pa lngas dad pa'i gzhi la gnas pa yin te/ gang gi phyir gtam thos pas kyang de la gzhan dag shin tu dang bar byed na/ mngon sum du mthong bas lta smos kyang ci dgos te/ spyod lam rab tu zhi ba dang / spyod lam dang ldan pa dang / yan lag dang nying lag thams cad mi 'gyur ba'i spyod lam phun sum tshogs pa yin/ lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las kyi mtha'i rgyu ba la rgod pa med cing 'gyur ba med pas brtan pa yin/ gzhan dag la tshul 'chos pa'i phyir so sor brtags nas spyod lam dang / brtan pa ltar mi 'chos pa'i tshul 'chos pa med pa yin/ gzhan dag gi chos kyi gtam mam/ rnyed pa dang / bkur sti las brtsams te/ mi bzod pa skye bar mi byed kyi gzhan dag gis chos kyi gtam bya bar bdag la gsol ba btab pa dang / rnyed pa dang / bkur sti rgya chen po rnyed na yang g.yo med cing dga' ba'i sems kyis gzhan la gsol ba 'debs su 'jug la chos kyi gtan de dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti de yang gzhan dag la stobs par byed de/ ji ltar bdag gi rnyed pa dang / bkur stis mgu bar 'gyur ba de bzhin du gzhan gyi rnyed pa dang / gzhan gyi bkur stis ches shin tu mgu bar 'gyur bar phrag dog med pa yin/ snod spyad bsnyungs shing yo byad bsnyungs la 'tshog chas rnyed do cog thams cad yongs su gtong bas yo byad bsnyungs pa yin no/ /

Regarding this [topic], a spiritual teacher takes on the status of being an object of faith on the basis of five aspects in such a way that others will feel great reverence toward him or her even when they have [only] heard [about the spiritual teacher from others], let alone when they have seen him or her face-to-face. (1) [A spiritual teacher] possesses [proper] physical behavior, physical behavior that is composed, and excellent physical behavior in which he or she avoids holding all the major and minor parts[1001] of the body in an unbecoming manner. (2) [A spiritual teacher] is one who remains firm in that he or she is unwavering and free of excitation in conducting physical, verbal, and mental activities. (3) [A spiritual teacher] is free of pretense in that he or she does not deliberately affect [a certain type of] physical behavior or [the quality of] steadfastness as an act of hypocrisy.[1002] (4) [A spiritual teacher] is free of envy in that he or she does not become upset in relation to a Dharma discourse that is given by others or the gain and honor that they have received. Instead, when requested by others to give a Dharma discourse or when receiving extensive amounts of gain and honor, he or she directs [that request to teach or that gain and honor] to others with a sincere and gracious mind. Moreover, regarding the Dharma discourses given by others or the gain and honor that they receive, he or she is much more deeply pleased by their gain and honor than by his or her own gain and honor. (5) [A spiritual teacher] is also one who practices simplicity[1003] in the sense of having few possessions and few personal belongings, and giving away all the property that is received.
THE DUTIES OF A SPIRITUAL TEACHER TOWARD HIS OR HER DISCIPLES [I.16.2.4]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen du gyur pa de ni/ rnam pa lngas gdul ba gzhan dag las dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi bya ba byed de/ gleng bar byed pa yin/ dran par byed pa yin/ 'doms par byed pa yin/ rjes su ston par byed pa yin/ chos ston par byed pa yin te/ tshig de dag gi rgyas par dbye ba ni 'di lta ste/ nyan thos kyi sa las rig par bya'o/ / gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa ni/ de bas kyang lhag par 'di lta ste/ stobs kyi rigs kyi le'u las rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva who is a spiritual teacher carries out five types of activities in relation to those who are his or her disciples. (1) He or she is one who admonishes, (2) one who reminds, (3) one who instructs, (4) one who counsels, and (5) one who gives Dharma teachings. It should be understood that these terms can be differentiated at length, for example as they are in the Stage of a Listener.[1004] The topics of instruction and counsel were also described above, in the chapter entitled “The Lineages of the Powers.”
SERVING A SPIRITUAL TEACHER [I.16.2.5]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen la brten pa ni rnam pa bzhis yongs su rdzogs par rig par bya ste/ dus dus su nad g.yog dang / tha mal pa'i g.yog byed pa byams pa dang / gus pa dang / dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / dus dus su gus par smra ba dang / phyag bya ba dang / mngon du ldang ba dang / thal mo sbyar ba dang / 'dud par bya ba dang / mchod par bya ba dang / chos dang mthun pa'i gos dang / zas dang / mal cha dang / stan dang / na ba'i gsos sman dang / yo byad sbyin pas mchod pa dang / gnas bcas nas yang dag par gzud pa dang / rnam par gzud pa chos dang mthun pa'i don la dbang byed la/ rnam par mi g.yo zhing yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'chags pa dang / dus shes par bya ba'i bsam pas drung du 'gro ba dang / bsnyen bkur byed pa dang / 'dri ba dang / nyan pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], it should be understood that the act of serving a spiritual teacher is fully accomplished on the basis of four qualities. [Serving a spiritual teacher is accomplished] (1) by [carrying out] the activities of taking care of [a spiritual teacher] who is sick and waiting upon one who is healthy, regularly and at appropriate times, and [doing so after] having engendered [feelings of] affection, respect, and joy; (2) by [carrying out] the activities of respectful salutation, prostration, standing up [in his or her presence], making the gesture of joined palms, respectful behavior, and honoring, as well as by making offerings of clothing, food, seats, bedding, and medicine for curing the ill in a manner that accords with the Dharma, regularly and at appropriate times; (3) by obeying [a spiritual teacher] who is being relied upon with regard to meaningful spiritual undertakings and endeavors,[1005] by being unwavering [with regard to those activities], and by disclosing [to a spiritual teacher] in a correct manner [how one has behaved with regard to those activities]; and (4) by approaching, waiting on,[1006] asking questions of, and listening to [a spiritual teacher] who has given permission [for one to do so] and who has the desire [that these activities be done], and [by doing so] at appropriate times.
CONCEPTIONS TO MAINTAIN WHEN LISTENING TO THE DHARMA [I.16.2.6]

de la byang chub sems dpas dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos nyan par 'dod pas ni 'du shes rnam pa lngas chos mnyan par bya ste/ dkon pa'i don gyis rin po che'i 'du shes dang / lhan cig skyes pa'i shes rab rgya chen po 'thob pa'i rgyu'i rang bzhin gyi don gyis mig gi 'du shes dang / lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes kyi mig thob nas kyang shes bya yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rnam pa thams cad yang dag par ston pa'i don gyis snang ba'i 'du shes dang / mya ngan las 'das pa dang / rdzogs pa'i byang chub bla na med pa'i go 'phang thob pa'i rgyu'i dngos po'i don gyis 'bras bu dang / phan yon che ba'i 'du shes dang / tshe 'di la mya ngan las 'das pa dang / rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi chos ma thob pa yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i zhi gnas dang / lhag mthong gi dga' ba chen po kha na ma tho ba med pa'i rgyu'i dngos po'i don gyis dga' ba kha na ma tho ba med pa'i 'du shes so/ /

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva who is desirous of listening to the Dharma in the presence of a spiritual teacher should listen to the Dharma while maintaining five types of conceptions. [They are] (1) [that one should listen] with the conception that [the Dharma] is a jewel, in the sense that it is difficult to obtain; (2) [that one should listen] with the conception that [the Dharma] is [like one’s] eyes, in the sense that it has the nature of being a cause for obtaining an extensive amount of innate wisdom;[1007] (3) [that one should listen] with the conception that [the Dharma] is light, in the sense that, with the eye of innately acquired knowledge, all aspects of objects of knowledge become evident in their true form; (4) [that one should listen] with the conception that [the Dharma yields] a great result and benefit, in the sense that it has the nature of being the cause for attaining the unsurpassed states of nirvana and complete enlightenment; and (5) [that one should listen] with the conception that [the Dharma] is an irreproachable form of pleasure, in the sense that it has the nature of being the cause [for attaining] in this life the irreproachable and great pleasure of quiescence and insight, [which are qualities that enable] one who has not yet attained nirvana and complete enlightenment [to develop] genuine discernment of the Dharma.
CIRCUMSTANCES RELATING TO THE SPIRITUAL TEACHER THAT SHOULD NOT BE BROUGHT TO MIND [I.16.2.7]

de la byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos nyan pa na/ gang zag chos smra ba de la gnas lngar yid la byed pa mi bya bar rna blags te/ dad pa'i yid kyis chos nyan par bya'o/ / tshul khrims nyams pa la yid la byed par mi bya ste/ 'di ltar 'di ni tshul khrims nyams shing sdom pa la gnas pa ma yin gyis/ bdag gis 'di las mnyan par mi bya'o snyam du sems mngon par 'du mi bya'o/ / rigs dma' ba la yang yid la byed par mi bya ste/ 'di ltar 'di ni rigs dma' ba yin gyis/ 'di las bdag gis mnyan par mi bya'o snyam du sems mngon par 'du mi bya'o/ / byad ngan pa la yid la byed par mi bya ste/ 'di ltar 'di ni byad ngan gyis bdag gis 'di las mnyan par mi bya'o snyam du sems mngon par 'du mi bya'o/ / tshig 'bru ngan pa la yang yid la byed par mi bya ste/ 'di ltar 'di ni tshig legs par sbyar ba ma yin gyis/ 'di las bdag gis mnyan par mi bya'o snyam du sems mngon par 'du mi bya ste/ don la rton par bya'i tshig 'bru la rton par mi bya'o/ / snyan pa med pa yang yid la byed par mi bya ste/ 'di ltar 'di ni tshig rtsub cing khro ba snyan par chos smra ba yang ma yin gyis/ bdag gis 'di las mnyan par mi bya'o snyam du sems mngon par 'du mi bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva who is listening to the Dharma in the presence of a spiritual teacher should avoid bringing to mind five circumstances that relate to the person who is a Dharma teacher and, having done so, he or she should listen to the Dharma attentively and with a reverential mind. (1) He or she should avoid bringing to mind that [a spiritual teacher’s] morality is in [a state of] ruin. [That is,] he or she should not form thoughts like the following: “This is [a person] whose conduct is bad. He or she does not maintain the [system of moral] discipline. I shall not listen [to the Dharma] from him or her.” (2) He or she should avoid bringing to mind that [a spiritual teacher’s] family is in [a state of] ruin. [That is,] he or she should not form thoughts like the following: “This [person] is from an inferior family. I shall not listen [to the Dharma] from him or her.” (3) He or she should avoid bringing to mind that [a spiritual teacher’s] appearance is in [a state of] ruin. [That is,] he or she should not form thoughts like the following: “This is a person who is physically unattractive. I shall not listen [to the Dharma] from him or her.” (4) He or she should avoid bringing to mind that [a spiritual teacher’s] form of expression is in [a state of] ruin. [That is,] he or she should not form thoughts like the following: “This is a person whose speech is unrefined. I shall not listen [to the Dharma] from him or her.” One should rely only upon the meaning [of a Dharma teaching], not its literal form of expression. (5) He or she should avoid bringing to mind that [a spiritual teacher’s] pleasantness[1008] [of manner] is in a state of ruin. [That is,] he or she should not form thoughts like the following: “This is a person who speaks in a harsh manner. He or she is prone to anger and does not teach a Dharma that is sweet-sounding. I shall not listen [to the Dharma] from him or her.”

gnas lnga po 'di dag la yid la byed par mi bya bar byang chub sems dpas gus pa dang bcas pas dam pa'i chos yongs su gzung bar bya ste/ chos ni nams kyang gang zag gi skyon gyis skyon can du mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de la byang chub sems dpa' shes rab rtul po gang / gang zag gi skyon rnams la sems sdang zhing chos nyan par mi 'dod pa de ni/ bdag nyid kho na la gnod cing shes rab yongs su nyams par 'gyur bar zhugs pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Having avoided bringing to mind any of these five circumstances, a bodhisattva should embrace the true Dharma respectfully, for the Dharma can never be corrupted by the faults of a person. Regarding this [topic], a bodhisattva whose wisdom is weak and who, having become upset about a person’s faults, does not want to hear the Dharma [from that person] should be understood to be one who has undertaken [a form of behavior] that will only bring harm to him- or herself and [a form of behavior] that will bring a loss of wisdom.
THE IMMEASURABLES [I.16.3]

byang chub sems dpa' ji ltar tshad med pa bzhi bsgom zhe na/ byams pa dang / snying rje dang / dga' ba dang / btang snyoms te/ mdor bsdu na 'di la byang chub sems dpa' ni tshad med pa bzhi rnam pa gsum du sgom par byed de/ sems can la dmigs pa dang / chos la dmigs pa dang / dmigs pa med pa'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems can thams cad bde ba dang ldan pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang ldan pa dang / sdug bsngal ba yang ma yin/ bde ba yang ma yin pa dang ldan pa'i tshogs gsum du rnam par gzhag nas/ sems can bde ba 'dod pa rnams kyi dbang du byas te/ bde ba sgrub pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang ldan pa'i byams pa'i sems kyis phyogs bcu khyab par byas nas/ sems can la mos pas gnas pa de ni de'i sems can la dmigs pa'i byams pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

How does a bodhisattva meditate on the four immeasurables—[namely, those of] loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity? Here, in brief, a bodhisattva meditates on three forms of the four immeasurables: (1) [the form] in which sentient beings are the mental object, (2) [the form] in which entities are the mental object, and (3) [the form] in which there is no mental object. After having arranged all sentient beings into three groups—[namely,] those who are experiencing happiness, those who are experiencing suffering, and those who are neither experiencing happiness nor experiencing suffering—when a bodhisattva, in relation to sentient beings who have a desire for happiness, radiates into the ten directions the loving-kindness that consists of the superior attitude [that wishes] to provide them with happiness and he or she abides with a conviction [that believes in the existence of] sentient beings, this should be understood as his or her [form of] loving-kindness in which sentient beings are the mental object.

chos tsam du 'du shes pa dang ldan pa/ chos tsam la sems can du 'dogs par bsam pa thag pa nas mthong ste/ byams pa de nyid sgom par byed pa de ni de'i chos la dmigs pa'i byams pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / chos su rnam par mi rtog pa yang med par byams pa de nyid sgom par byed pa de ni de'i dmigs pa med pa'i byams pa yin par rig par bya'o/ /

On the other hand, when [a bodhisattva] who possesses an understanding of [the existence of] mere entities[1009] meditates on that very [form of] loving-kindness [that was just described] while recognizing with deep conviction that this mere [collection of] entities is designated a sentient being [only] in a figurative sense, this should be understood as his [or her form of] loving-kindness in which entities are the mental object. Moreover, when [a bodhisattva] meditates on that very [form of] loving-kindness while avoiding even generating a conception of entities, this should be understood as his [or her form of] loving-kindness in which there is no mental object.

sems can la dmigs pa dang / chos la dmigs pa dang / dmigs pa med pa'i byams pa ji lta ba bzhin du snying rje dang / dga' ba dang / btang snyoms kyang de dang 'dra bar rig par bya'o/ / de la byang chub sems dpa' sems can sdug bsngal dang ldan pa rnams las brtsams te/ phyogs bcu dag tu sdug bsngal bsal ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa snying rje dang ldan pa'i sems sgom par byed pa de ni de'i snying rje'i yin no/ / sems can bde ba dang ldan pa rnams las brtsams te/ phyogs bcu dag tu bde ba la rjes su yi rang ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dga' ba dang ldan pa'i sems sgom par byed pa de ni de'i dga' ba yin no/ / de'i phyogs bcu dag tu sems can sdug bsngal ba yang ma yin/ bde ba yang ma yin pa dang ldan pa dang / sdug bsngal dang ldan pa dang / bde ba dang ldan pa rnam pa gsum po de dag nyid kyis nyon mongs pa go rim bzhin du gti mug dang zhe sdang dang 'dod chags bsal ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa btang snyoms dang ldan pa'i sems sgom par byed pa 'di ni de'i btang snyoms yin no/ /

It should be understood that [immeasurable] compassion, joy, and equanimity are also [practiced] in the same way as [the three forms of] loving-kindness—[namely,] that in which sentient beings are the mental object, that in which entities are the mental object, and that in which there is no mental object. Regarding those [latter three practices], when a bodhisattva, in relation to sentient beings who are experiencing suffering, meditates upon a mind that is accompanied by compassion [and he or she radiates it] into the ten directions with a [form of] superior attitude [that wishes] to remove [sentient beings’] suffering, this is his or her [immeasurable] compassion. Further, when [a bodhisattva], in relation to sentient beings who are experiencing happiness, meditates upon a mind that is accompanied by joy [and he or she radiates it] into the ten directions with a [form of] superior attitude that rejoices at their happiness, this is his or her [immeasurable] joy. When [a bodhisattva] meditates upon a mind that is accompanied by equanimity [and he or she radiates it] into the ten directions with a [form of] superior attitude [that wishes] to free those very same three types of sentient beings—[namely,] those who are neither experiencing happiness nor experiencing suffering, those who are experiencing suffering, and those who are experiencing happiness—respectively, of their ignorance, hatred, and desire, this is his [or her immeasurable] equanimity.

de la byang chub sems dpa' byams pa la sogs pa tshad med pa sems can la dmigs pa gang yin pa de dag ni gzhan mu stegs can dang thun mong ba yin no/ / chos la dmigs pa gang yin pa de dag ni nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas dang thun mong ba yin gyi/ mu stegs can dang ni thun mong ma yin par rig par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i dmigs pa med pa'i tshad med pa gang yin pa de dag ni/ mu stegs can dang / nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang thun mong ma yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding these [four practices], it should be understood that [the forms of] a bodhisattva’s immeasurable loving-kindness, etc., in which sentient beings are the mental object are [forms of practice] that are shared by others who are followers of non-Buddhist traditions.[1010] Moreover, it should be understood that those [forms of the four immeasurables] in which entities are the mental object are [forms of practice] that are shared by listeners and solitary realizers, but they are not [forms of practice] that are shared by others who are followers of non-Buddhist traditions. However, it should be understood that [those forms of] a bodhisattva’s [practice of] the immeasurables in which there is no mental object are not [forms of practice] that are shared by any listeners, solitary realizers, or followers of non-Buddhist traditions.

de la byang chub sems dpa'i tshad med pa byams pa dang / snying rje dang / dga' ba gsum ni bde bar bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pas bsdus par rig par bya'o/ / tshad med pa gcig ni phan pa bya ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pas bsdus par rig par bya ste/ 'di lta ste/ btang snyoms so/ / byang chub sems dpa'i tshad med pa de dag thams cad ni snying brtse ba zhes bya ste/ de lta bas na de dag dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni snying brtse ba can zhes bya'o/ /

Regarding these [four practices], it should be understood that three of the bodhisattvas’ immeasurables—namely, loving-kindness, compassion, and joy—consist of [forms of] superior attitude [that wish for] the happiness [of sentient beings]. It should be understood that one of the immeasurables consists of a [form of] superior attitude [that wishes to] benefit [sentient beings]—namely, equanimity. All [four] of the immeasurables are referred to as [forms of] a bodhisattva’s “sympathy.”[1011] Therefore, those bodhisattvas who possess these [immeasurable attitudes] are described as “the ones who are sympathetic.”
CULTIVATING COMPASSION BY MEDITATING ON ONE HUNDRED AND TEN FORMS OF SUFFERING [I.16.3.1]
de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni sems can gyi khams na sdug bsngal rnam pa brgya rtsa bcu mthong bas sems can rnams la snying rje sgom par byed do/ /
Regarding this [topic], bodhisattvas consider one hundred and ten forms of suffering that occur within the domain of sentient beings as they meditate upon compassion toward sentient beings.

sdug bsngal rnam pa brgya rtsa bcu gang zhe na/ sdug bsngal rnam pa gcig ni bye brag med par 'jug pa'i sdug bsngal las brtsams te/ sems can thams cad 'jug par gtogs pa'i sdug bsngal dang ldan pa'o/ / sdug bsngal rnam pa gnyis ni 'dun pa'i rtsa ba can te/ dga' ba'i dngos po gang dag 'gyur zhing gzhan du 'gyur ba las sdug bsngal skye ba dang / rnam par smin pa rmongs pa can gyi sdug bsngal te/ lus kyi tshor ba drag po gang dag gis thebs nas/ lus de la bdag ces bya ba'am/ bdag gi zhes bya bar rmongs nas shin tu mya ngan byed cing gang gis lus dang sems kyi tshor ba'i zug rngu gnyis myong ba'o/ /

What are the one hundred and ten forms of suffering? Suffering has one form. As relates to “the suffering of [a state of] progression,”[1012] all sentient beings, without exception, are experiencing the suffering that occurs in a continuous manner. Suffering has two forms. (1) “[The suffering] that is rooted in desire” is the suffering that arises when objects that are held dear undergo change and turn into something different. (2) “The suffering that is [caused by] a ripening of ignorance” is those painful physical sensations that cause the individual who experiences them to become bewildered in the sense of [forming the erroneous notions of] an “I” or a “mine” in relation to his or her individual existence[1013] and then to undergo exceedingly great distress. [These two forms of suffering] cause two [types of] painful feelings to be experienced, [one] physical and [the other] mental.
sdug bsngal rnam pa gsum ni sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal dang / 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal dang / 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal lo/

Suffering has three forms: (1) that which is caused by the suffering of suffering, (2) that which is caused by the suffering of conditioned existence, and (3) that which is caused by the suffering of change.

sdug bsngal rnam pa bzhi ni 'bral ba'i sdug bsngal te/ sdug pa rnams dang bral ba las skye ba gang yin pa dang / rgyun chad pa'i sdug bsngal te/ ris mthun pa 'dor ba 'chi ba las skye ba gang yin pa dang / rgyun gyi sdug bsngal te/ shi ba'i 'og tu skye ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa las skye ba gang yin pa dang / gtan du sdug bsngal ba ste/ yongs su mya ngan las mi 'da' ba'i chos can gyi sems can rnams kyi nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po gang yin pa rnams so/ /

Suffering has four forms. (1) The suffering of separation is that which arises through being separated from those [beings] who are held dear. (2) The suffering of destruction is that which arises because of death, [an event that is characterized by] the casting off of a [particular] class affiliate.[1014] (3) Successive suffering it is that which arises sequentially in [each] rebirth following one’s death. (4) Perpetual suffering is the five grasping heaps[1015] of those sentient beings who are not capable of attaining nirvana.

sdug bsngal rnam pa lnga ni 'dod pa la 'dun pa'i kun nas dkris pa'i rkyen can dang / gnod sems dang / rmugs pa dang / gnyid dang / rgod pa dang / 'gyod pa dang / the tshom gyis kun nas dkris pa'i rkyen can gyi sdug bsngal lo/ /

Suffering has five forms: (1) the suffering that is conditioned by the perturbation of desire for sense objects, and [the forms of] suffering that are conditioned by the perturbations of (2) malice, (3) torpor and sleep, (4) excitation and regret, and (5) doubt.

sdug bsngal rnam pa drug ni ngan song gi rgyu rten pa'i phyir rgyu'i sdug bsngal dang / ngan song du skyes pa'i phyir 'bras bu'i sdug bsngal dang / longs spyod las brtsams te yongs su tshol ba'i sdug bsngal dang / bsrung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / chog mi shes pa'i sdug bsngal dang / med par 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal te/ de dag bsdus pa ni sdug bsngal rnam pa drug yin no/ /

Suffering has six forms. (1) Causal suffering is [that which leads to suffering] by engaging in the causes of [rebirth in] the lower realms. (2) Resultant suffering is [that which occurs] through having been born in the lower realms. [The forms of suffering that occur] in relation to material wealth[1016] are (3) the suffering of pursuing [the acquisition of material wealth], (4) the suffering of having to safeguard [the material wealth that has been acquired], (5) the suffering of not finding satisfaction [by the enjoyment of material wealth], and (6) the suffering [that arises] from the loss [of one’s material wealth]. Collectively, these are the six forms of suffering.

sdug bsngal rnam pa bdun ni skye ba'i sdug bsngal dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / 'chi ba dang / mi sdug pa dang phrad pa dang / sdug pa med par 'gyur ba dang / 'dod pa btsal te ma rnyed pa gang yin pa de yang sdug bsngal lo/ /

Suffering has seven forms. (1) Birth is suffering, (2) old age [is suffering], (3) sickness [is suffering], (4) death [is suffering], (5) meeting with disagreeable things [is suffering], (6) separation from agreeable things [is suffering], and (7) not acquiring what is desired and sought after is also suffering.

sdug bsngal rnam pa brgyad ni grang ba'i sdug bsngal dang / tsha ba'i sdug bsngal dang / bkres pa'i sdug bsngal dang / skom pa'i sdug bsngal dang / rang dbang med pa'i sdug bsngal dang / bdag la gnod pa byed pa'i sdug bsngal 'di lta ste/ gcer bu pa la sogs pa rnams kyi lta bu dang / gnod pa gzhan las byung ba'i sdug bsngal 'di lta ste/ gzhan gyis lag pa dang / bong bas bsnun pa la sogs pa dang / sha sbrang dang / sbrang bu mchu [{]rings [,]ring [}]la sogs pas zin pa dang / spyod lam sna gcig gis gnas pa'i sdug bsngal lo/ /

Suffering has eight forms: (1) the suffering of cold; (2) the suffering of heat; (3) the suffering of hunger; (4) the suffering of thirst; (5) the suffering of lacking the freedom [to act at one’s own discretion]; (6) the suffering of harm done to oneself, such as that of naked ascetics, and the like; (7) the suffering of harm done by others, such as being struck by another person with the hand or a clod of earth, etc., or being stung by gnats and mosquitoes, etc.; and (8) the suffering [that arises from] continually engaging in a single form of physical behavior.

sdug bsngal rnam pa dgu ni/ bdag nyid rgud pa'i sdug bsngal dang / gzhan rgud pa'i sdug bsngal dang / nye du rgud pa'i sdug bsngal dang / longs spyod nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / nad med pa las nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / tshul khrims nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / lta ba nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / tshe 'di'i sdug bsngal dang / tshe phyi ma'i sdug bsngal lo/ /

Suffering has nine forms: (1) the suffering of one’s own misfortune,[1017] (2) the suffering of others’ misfortune, (3) the suffering of misfortune pertaining to family relations, (4) the suffering of misfortune relating to possessions, (5) the suffering of loss of health, (6) the suffering [caused by] a failure of morality, (7) the suffering [caused by] failed views, (8) suffering [experienced] in this life, and (9) suffering [experienced] in future lives.

sdug bsngal rnam pa bcu ni lus kyi yo byad kha zas med pa'i sdug bsngal dang / btung ba dang / bzhon pa dang / gos dang / rgyan dang / snod spyad kyi yo byad med pa'i sdug bsngal dang / spos dang / me tog phreng dang / byug pa'i yo byad med pa'i sdug bsngal dang / gar dang glu dang rol mo'i sgra'i yo byad med pa'i sdug bsngal dang / snang ba'i yo byad med pa'i sdug bsngal dang bcu pa ste/ skyes pa dang / bud med dag dga' dgur spyod pa'i lus kyi yo byad med pa'i sdug bsngal lo/ /

Suffering has ten forms: (1) the suffering of lacking the food that is a material necessity[1018] for the body; the suffering of lacking the material necessities of (2) drink, (3) vehicles, (4) clothing, (5) ornaments, and (6) household utensils; (7) the suffering of lacking the material necessities of scents, garlands, and unguents; (8) the suffering of lacking the material necessities that relate to dance, song, music, etc.; (9) the suffering of lacking the material necessities for [creating] light; and (10) the suffering of lacking the material necessities [used by] women and men [in the pursuit of] sexual pleasure.

yang sdug bsngal ni rnam pa dgur rig par bya ste/ sdug bsngal thams cad dang / sdug bsngal chen po dang / thams cad kyi sgo nas sdug bsngal dang / log par zhugs pa'i sdug bsngal dang / 'jug pa'i sdug bsngal dang / mi 'dod pas byas pa'i sdug bsngal dang / phongs pa'i sdug bsngal dang / rjes su 'brel pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / rnam pa thams cad kyi sdug bsngal lo/ /

It should be understood that there is another [description of] nine forms of suffering: (1) all-encompassing suffering, (2) great suffering, (3) suffering that is directed everywhere, (4) suffering [caused by] wrongful conduct, (5) the suffering of [a state of] progression, (6) the suffering of being unable to fulfill one’s desires, (7) the suffering of failure, (8) suffering that follows necessarily, and (9) suffering of every form.
de la sdug bsngal thams cad ni sngon gyi rgyu las byung ba dang / da ltar gyi rkyen las byung ba'o/ /
Regarding this [topic], all-encompassing suffering is (1a) that which arises from a former cause, and (1b) that which arises from a condition that exists in the present.
de la sdug bsngal chen po ni yun ring ba dang / bzod brlag pa dang / sna tshogs pa dang / rgyun mi 'chad pa'o/ /
Regarding this [topic], great suffering is that which is (2a) long-lasting, (2b) exceedingly painful, (2c) manifold, and (2d) constant.
de la thams cad kyi sgo nas sdug bsngal ni sems can dmyal ba pa dang / dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang /[ {]yi dgas [,]yi dwags [}]kyi 'jig rten pa dang / bde 'gror gtogs pa'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], suffering that is directed everywhere includes (3a) that which occurs in the hells, (3b) that which occurs in the birth state of animals, (3c) that which occurs in the world of hungry ghosts, and (3d) that which occurs in the happy migratory states.

de la log par zhugs pa'i sdug bsngal ni tshe 'di la gzhan gyis gnod par byas pa dang / gzhan la gnod pa byas pa byung ba dang / kun nas slong ba dang / kha zas mi mthun pa zos pas khams ma snyoms pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal kun nas slong ba dang / tshe 'di la bdag nyid kyis mi rigs par sdug bsngal bar byas pa las bdag gis byas pa'i sdug bsngal kun nas slong pa dang / tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pa dang / de la shas cher gnas pas nyon mongs pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa'i kun nas dkris pa'i sdug bsngal nyams su myong bar 'gyur ba dang / lus dang ngag dang yid kyi nyes par spyod pa shas che bas phyi ma la ngan song ba'i sdug bsngal nyams su myong par 'gyur ba'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], suffering [caused by] wrongful conduct is (4a) [the suffering] of this life that is experienced due to harm carried out by others and (4b) [the suffering of this life] that is caused to arise by doing harm to others. (4c) It is the suffering that arises from an imbalance of the elements caused by eating unsuitable food. (4d) [It is the suffering] that an individual causes to him- or herself by improperly [engaging in behavior that consists of] doing harm to oneself. (4e) It is the suffering in which one experiences the perturbation [that is caused by] the root and secondary mental afflictions due to continuously engaging in improper forms of attention.[1019] (4f) It is the suffering that one experiences in a future life in the lower realms due to the widespread occurrence of misdeeds of body, speech, and mind.

de la 'jug pa'i sdug bsngal ni ma nges pa rnam pa drug las byung ba ste/ 'khor bar 'khor ba na lus ma nges pas rgyal por gyur pa las mi dbul por gyur pa dang / pha ma ma nges pa dang / bu dang chung ma ma nges pa dang / bran dang bran mo dang / las byed pa dang / zho shas 'tsho ba ma nges pa dang / mdza' bshes dang / gros grogs dang / nye du dang snag gi gnyen mtshams ma nges pa las byung ba de 'khor bar 'khor ba na/ pha mar gyur pa nas rgyas par mdza' bshes dang / gros grogs dang / nye du dang / snag gi gnyen mtshams kyi bar du gyur pa las dus gzhan du 'khor bar 'khor ba na/ gsod pa dang / phyir rgol ba dang / dgra bor gyur pa dang / 'khor bar 'khor ba na longs spyod ma nges pas/ longs spyod chen por gyur pa las phyis dus gzhan du mchog tu dbul por 'gyur ro/ /

Regarding this [topic], “the suffering of [a state of] progression”[1020] is that which arises due to six types of uncertainty [that occur] for one who wanders in samsara. (5a) Due to the uncertainty of one’s individual existence, a person who was a king becomes a pauper. Due to (5b) the uncertainty relating to one’s mother and father, (5c) the uncertainty relating to one’s children and spouse, (5d) the uncertainty relating to male and female servants, as well as workers and hired persons, and (5e) the uncertainty relating to friends, advisers,[1021] near relations, and kinsmen, at a different time in one’s [samsaric] wandering, those persons who were one’s mother or father, etc., up to those persons who were one’s friends, advisers, near relations, and kinsmen, will become one’s killer or a rival or an enemy. (5f) Due to the uncertainty relating to material possessions, as an individual who previously possessed great wealth continues to wander in samsara, he or she will become, at another time, someone who is extremely poor.

de la mi 'dod pas byas pa'i sdug bsngal ni tshe ring bar 'dod pa la mi 'dod bzhin du tshe thung bar 'gyur ba las byung ba dang / byad bzang bar 'dod pa las kyang mi 'dod bzhin du byad ngan par 'gyur ba dang / rigs mthon por skye bar 'dod pa las kyang mi 'dod bzhin du rigs dma' bar skye bar 'gyur ba dang / dbang phyug 'dod pa las kyang mi 'dod bzhin du dbul por 'gyur ba dang / stobs che bar 'dod pa las kyang mi 'dod bzhin du stobs chung ngur 'gyur ba las byung ba dang / shes bya shes par 'dod pa las kyang mi 'dod bzhin du rmongs pa'i shes pa kun du spyod pa las byung ba dang / pha rol pham par 'dod pa las kyang / mi 'dod bzhin du bdag nyid pham pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal lo/ /

Regarding this [topic], the suffering of being unable to fulfill one’s desires is (6a) that which arises for a person who wishes to have a long life but who, contrary to his or her wishes, experiences a short life; (6b) [that which arises for] a person who wishes to be physically attractive but who, contrary to his or her wishes, is physically unattractive; (6c) [that which arises for] a person who wishes to be born in a family of high standing but who, contrary to his or her wishes, is born in a [socially] inferior family; (6d) [that which arises for] a person who wishes to have power[1022] but who, contrary to his or her wishes, has become one who is [living] in a state of poverty; (6e) [that which arises for] a person who wishes to have great strength[1023] but who, contrary to his or her wishes, has become one who is weak; (6f) [that which arises for] a person who wishes to gain knowledge of [many] subjects but who, contrary to his or her wishes, must go through life as one who is bewildered and lacking in knowledge; and (6g) that which arises for a person who wishes to defeat others but who, contrary to his or her wishes, fails to defeat others and is instead forced to experience defeat.

de la phongs pa'i sdug bsngal ni khyim pa rnams kyi bu dang chung ma la sogs pa 'grib pa las byung ba dang / rab tu byung ba rnams kyi 'dod chags la sogs pa nyon mongs pa 'phel ba las byung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / sdug bsngal gang mu ges phongs pa'am/ pha rol gyi dmag tshogs kyis phongs pa dang / dgon pa dang / gcong rong du 'gro ba'i nyam nga bas phongs pa las byung ba dang / sdug bsngal gang pha rol la rag las pas 'tsho ba las byung ba dang / sdug bsngal gang yan lag dang nying lag nyams pas phongs par gyur pa las byung ba dang / sdug bsngal gang gsad pa dang / bcing ba dang bcad pa dang / brdeg pa dang / bskrad pa la sogs pas phongs pa las byung ba'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], the suffering of failure is, in the case of householders, (7a) [the suffering] that arises from the decline of their children, wife or husband, etc., and, in the case of those who have gone forth [into the homeless state], it is (7b) the suffering that arises from the increase of the mental afflictions of desire, etc. It is also (7c) the suffering that arises from being afflicted by a scarcity of provisions,[1024] (7d) [the suffering that arises] from being defeated by an opposing army, and (7e) [the suffering that arises] from being harmed by the distress and danger [that one encounters upon] entering a forest or a region that is difficult to traverse. It is also (7f) the suffering that arises from having to rely on others for one’s subsistence. It is also (7g) [the suffering] that arises from the impediment that is [caused by] lacking limbs or minor appendages. It is also (7h) the suffering that arises from [undergoing] such injuries as being killed, bound, cut, beaten, or banished, etc.

de la rjes su 'brel pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal ba ni 'jig rten gyi chos brgyad kyi sdug bsngal gang yin pa ste/ 'jig pa'i chos can 'jig pa dang / zad pa'i chos can zad pa dang / rga ba'i chos can rga ba dang / na ba'i chos can na ba dang / 'chi ba'i chos can 'chi ba dang / yang ma rnyed pa'am/ mi snyan pa'am/ smad pa las sdug bsngal 'byung ba gang yin pa de/ sdug bsngal rnam pa brgyad po 'di dag dang / 'dod pa'i sdug bsngal dang / 'di rnams ni rjes su 'brel pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal zhes bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], the suffering that follows necessarily[1025] is suffering [that occurs] in relation to eight worldly conditions. [That is, it is suffering that occurs] in relation to (8a) the perishing of that which is perishable, (8b) the disappearance of that which deteriorates, (8c) the aging of that which is subject to aging, (8d) the sickening of that which is subject to illness, and (8e) the death of that which is mortal. It is also the suffering that arises from (8f) loss, (8g) disrepute, and (8h) blame. These eight types of suffering, as well as the suffering [that arises because] of longing [for things], are what is referred to as “suffering that follows necessarily.”

de la rnam pa thams cad kyi sdug bsngal ni bde ba rnam pa lnga ji skad bstan pa'i mi mthun pa'i phyogs kyi sdug bsngal gang yin pa ste/ rgyu'i sdug bsngal dang / tshor ba'i sdug bsngal dang / bde ba med pa can gyi sdug bsngal dang / tshor ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i sdug bsngal dang / mngon par 'byung ba dang / rab tu dben pa dang / nye bar zhi ba dang / rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi bde ba'i mi mthun pa'i phyogs khyim pa dang / 'dod pa'i khams dang / kun du sbyor ba las byung ba'i rtog pa dang / so so'i skye bo'i sdug bsngal ni lnga pa yin par rig par bya ste/ sdug bsngal rnam pa lnga po 'di dang gnod pa las byung ba dang / yo byad med pa las byung ba dang / khams ma snyoms pa las byung ba dang / dga' ba 'gyur ba las byung ba dang / khams gsum na spyod pa'i nyon mongs pa'i phyogs gnas ngan len gyi sdug bsngal lnga po de dag dang / snga ma'i rnam pa lnga gcig tu bsdus te/ sdug bsngal rnam pa bcu ni rnam pa thams cad ces bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], suffering of every form [includes] the five types of suffering that are the opposite of what was explained as [the five aspects of] happiness.[1026] They should be understood as (9a) the cause of suffering; (9b) the experience of suffering; (9c) the suffering that is a mere absence of happiness; (9d) the suffering that does not cut off feelings; and (9e) the fifth type is those forms of suffering that oppose the happiness of departure, separation, tranquility, and complete enlightenment—namely, the suffering of living as a householder, [the suffering] that arises from being bound to the desire realm, [the suffering of] deliberation,[1027] and [the suffering of] being an ordinary person.[1028] These make up [one group of this category’s] five forms of suffering. [Another five are] (9f) [the suffering] that is due to violence, (9g) [the suffering] that arises from a lack of articles necessary for subsistence, (9h) [the suffering] that arises from an imbalance of the elements, (9i) [the suffering] that arises from a transformation of that which is held dear, and (9j) the fifth is the suffering of the indisposition[1029] that promotes the mental afflictions that operate in the three realms. This group of five combined with the previous [five] make up the ten types of suffering that are called “suffering of every form.”

de ltar snga ma'i rnam pa lnga bcu rtsa lnga po dang / rnam pa lnga bcu rtsa lnga po 'di dag gcig tu bsdus na sdug bsngal rnam pa brgya rtsa bcur 'gyur ba ni byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje'i dmigs pa ste/ dmigs pa des byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snying rje skye zhing rnam par 'phel la bsgom pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ /

When the previous fifty-five forms [of suffering] are combined together with this [group of] fifty-five, they make up the one hundred and ten forms [of suffering] that are [used as] meditation objects for the [type of] compassion that [is cultivated by] bodhisattvas. [These are] the meditation objects by means of which the compassion of bodhisattvas is developed and increased and their meditation reaches perfection.
GREAT COMPASSION [I.16.3.2]

sdug bsngal gyi phung po chen po de las sdug bsngal rnam pa bcu dgu la dmigs pa las ni snying rje chen po 'jug par 'gyur te/ sdug bsngal rnam pa bcu dgu po gang zhe na/ rnam par smin pa rmongs pa can gyi sdug bsngal dang / 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal du gtogs pa'i sdug bsngal dang / gtan du sdug bsngal dang / rgyu'i sdug bsngal dang / skye ba'i sdug bsngal dang / bdag nyid kyis gnod pa byas pa'i sdug bsngal dang / tshul khrims nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / lta ba nyams pa'i sdug bsngal dang / sngon gyi rgyu las byung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / sdug bsngal chen po dang / sems can dmyal ba pa'i sdug bsngal dang / bde 'gror gtogs pa'i sdug bsngal dang / log par zhugs pa rnams las byung ba'i sdug bsngal thams cad dang / 'jug pa'i sdug bsngal thams cad dang / mi shes pa'i sdug bsngal dang / rgyas pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / rjes su 'brel pa las byung ba'i sdug bsngal dang / tshor ba'i sdug bsngal dang / gnas ngan len gyi sdug bsngal lo/ /

Moreover, great compassion arises when nineteen of the types of suffering within this great heap of suffering [are used] as meditation objects. What are the nineteen types of suffering? They are (1) the suffering that is [caused by] a ripening of ignorance, (2) the suffering that is included within the suffering of conditioned existence, (3) perpetual suffering, (4) causal suffering, (5) the suffering of birth, (6) the suffering of harm done to oneself, (7) the suffering [caused by] a failure of morality, (8) the suffering [caused by] failed views, (9) the suffering that arises from a former cause, (10) great suffering, (11) the suffering of the hells, (12) the suffering that is included in the happy migratory states, (13) all the [forms of] suffering that arise from wrongful conduct, (14) all the [forms of] suffering of [a state of] progression, (15) the suffering that arises from a lack of knowledge, (16) the suffering that arises from the increase [of the mental afflictions], (17) the suffering that follows necessarily, (18) the experience of suffering, and (19) the suffering of indisposition.

de la snying rje ni rgyu rnam pa bzhis snying rje chen po zhes bya ste/ sems can rnams kyi sdug bsngal zab cing cha phra ba la rtogs par dka' ba la dmigs nas skyes pa yin/ bskal pa 'bum phrag du ma nas goms pas yun ring po nas 'dris pa yin/ rtsol ba drag pos dmigs pa la zhugs pa yang yin te/ rtsol ba 'di lta bu dang ldan zhing snying rjes zin pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de ni sems can rnams kyi sdug bsngal bsal ba'i phyir/ bdag nyid kyi srog brgya yang yongs su gtong na srog gcig lta ci smos/ lus kyi yo byad lta yang ci smos te/ sdug bsngal gyis gnod pa'i rnam pa thams cad kyang nyams su len par byed pa yin/ shin tu rnam par dag pa yang yin te/ 'di lta ste/ mthar thug pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi byang chub sems dpa'i sa yang rnam par dag pa'i phyir dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi de bzhin gshegs pa'i sa yang rnam par dag pa'i phyir ro/ /

Compassion is called “great compassion” on the basis of four causal factors: (1) [It is a form of compassion] that is developed after one has [mentally] taken hold of the suffering of sentient beings that is profound, subtle, and difficult to realize. (2) [It is a form of compassion] that one has become acquainted with over a long period of time and that one has cultivated for many hundreds of thousands of kalpas. (3) [It is a form of compassion] that has engaged its object with an effort of such intensity that the bodhisattva who is filled with compassion would give up even a hundred lives in order to remove the suffering of beings, let alone a single life or the material possessions [that sustain his or her] physical body. (4) [It is a form of compassion] that is exceedingly pure due to the purity of the [ārya] bodhisattva stage that [has been attained by] those bodhisattvas who have reached the [path’s] culmination and [a form of compassion that is exceedingly pure] due to the purity of the stage of a tathāgata that [has been attained by] the tathāgatas.

byang chub sems dpa' gang dag sdug bsngal rnam pa brgya rtsa bcu po 'dis sems can rnams la snying rje sgom par byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag ni byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje thams cad bsgom pa yin no/ / de dag gis ni bsam pa dag pa'i sa la zhugs pa'i snying rje'i bsam pa rnam par dag pa yang myur ba nyid du thob par 'gyur ro/ / sems can rnams la yang sems shin tu mnyen pa dang / byams pa'i sems dang / byed 'dod pa'i sems dang / skyo ba med pa'i sems dang / sdug bsngal nyams su len pa'i sems dang / las su rung zhing dbang du gyur pa'i sems dang ldan pa yin no/ /

Now then, those bodhisattvas who meditate upon compassion in relation to sentient beings using these one hundred and ten forms [of suffering] meditate on the complete [form of] bodhisattva compassion. Moreover, they also quickly attain the [form of] compassion that constitutes a purity of attitude—[namely, the compassion] of one who has entered into the [ārya bodhisattva] stage that constitutes a purity of attitude. They also develop a mind that is exceedingly tender toward sentient beings, a mind that is [exceedingly] affectionate [toward sentient beings], a mind that is [exceedingly] desirous of acting [on behalf of sentient beings], a mind that is tireless [in its desire to act on behalf of sentient beings], a mind that is able to endure suffering [as it acts on behalf of sentient beings], and a mind that is both fit and has been brought under control [in order to act on behalf of sentient beings].

'phags pa nyan thos sdug bsngal gyi bden pa mngon par rtogs pa dang ldan pa mthar thug pa skyo ba dang ldan pa'i sems kyi rgyud thag ring du song bar gyur pa yang ji ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams la snying rje chen po sngon du 'gro ba'i sems kyis sdug bsngal gyi phung po chen po rnam pa brgya rtsa bcur 'dus pa yang dag par mthong nas 'jug pa de ltar mi 'jug go/ / byang chub sems dpa' de ltar snying rjes yid yongs su bsgos pa ni nang dang phyi rol gyi dngos po gang ci yang yongs su mi gtong ba med do/ / tshul khrims kyi sdom pa gang yang dag par len par mi byed pa de med do/ / gzhan gnod pa byed pa la gang mi bzod pa de ci yang med do/ / brtson 'grus gang mi rtsom pa de med do/ / bsam gtan gang la snyoms par mi 'jug pa de med do/ / shes rab gang la mi 'jug pa de med do/ / de lta bas na de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la byang chub sems dpa'i byang chub gang la gnas zhes zhus na/ byang chub sems dpa'i byang chub ni snying rje la gnas so zhes yang dag par lung ston pas lung ston par mdzad do/ /

Moreover, the mind continuum of a listener ārya who has attained the culmination [of understanding] and possesses a [direct] realization of the truth of suffering, [a mind continuum] that has long since been accompanied by a sense of dissatisfaction [for samsara’s suffering], does not engage[1030] [in activities] with the same degree of urgency as [the mind continuum] of a bodhisattva who perceives, with a mind that possesses [great][1031] compassion toward [all] sentient beings, the great mass of one hundred and ten forms of suffering that is being undergone. There is not any [form of] inner or outer entity that a bodhisattva whose mind is permeated with such compassion would not give up. There is no [form of] moral discipline that he or she would not accept. There is not any [form of] harm inflicted by another that he or she would not endure. There is no application of effort that he or she would not undertake. There is no meditative absorption that he or she would not cultivate. There is no [form of] wisdom that he or she would not develop. Therefore, when the tathāgatas are asked, “Upon what [foundation] does the enlightenment of a bodhisattva rest?” the Ones Who Expound Things Correctly declare: “The enlightenment of a bodhisattva rests upon the foundation of compassion.”

de la 'dir byang chub sems dpa'i tshad med pa re re zhing ji skad bstan pa ni tshad med pa phun sum tshogs pas phun sum tshogs par 'jug ste/ sdud pa'i 'bras bu tshad med pa yongs su 'dzin cing rnam pa gcig tu nges par dge zhing kha na ma tho ba med pa tshad med pa dag gis 'jug pa'i phyir ro/ /

Regarding this [topic], each of the immeasurables that have been explained here brings about a bodhisattva’s development by means of their immeasurable development. [Each one] acquires immeasurable forms of desirable results.[1032] [Each one] is brought forth by immeasurable forms of virtue that are absolutely irreproachable.

byang chub sems dpa' de ltar tshad med pa sgom pa la brtson pa la ni phan yon bzhi yod par rig par bya ste/ de tshad med pa sgom pa de ni thog ma kho nar tshe 'di la bde ba mchog la gnas par 'gyur ba dang / bsod nams kyi tshogs tshad med pa yongs su 'dzin zhing 'phel bar 'gyur ba dang / bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la bsam pa brtan par 'gyur ba dang / sems can rnams kyi don gyi phyir 'khor ba na sdug bsngal thams cad nyams su len par 'gyur ba'o/ /

It should be understood that a bodhisattva who is engaged in meditation upon the immeasurables in this manner [obtains] four benefits. (1) From the very outset, [a bodhisattva’s] meditation upon the immeasurables promotes his or her abiding in supreme forms of ease during that lifetime. (2) [Meditation upon the immeasurables] promotes the acquisition and collection of immeasurable [forms of] the merit accumulation. (3) It promotes a firmness of attitude in relation to [the pursuit of] true and complete enlightenment. (4) It promotes the ability to endure every [kind of] suffering [while one remains] in samsara for the sake of sentient beings.
byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i gzhi'i rnal 'byor gyi gnas las mchod pa dang / bsten pa dang / tshad med pa'i le'u ste bcu drug pa'o// //

Within [Book I of] The Stage of a Bodhisattva, [known as] “The Object of Mental Application That Relates to the Support,” this completes the sixteenth chapter, entitled “Worship, Service, and the Immeasurables.”
bam po bcu bzhi pa/
[byang chub kyi phyogs]
17. THE SPIRITUAL QUALITIES THAT ARE CONDUCIVE TO ENLIGHTENMENT

sdom ni/ ngo tsha brtan dang mi skyo dang / / de bzhin bstan bcos 'jig rten shes/ / legs par ston par byed pa dang / / de bzhin so so yang dag rig / tshogs dang byang chub phyogs rnams dang / / zhi gnas dang ni lhag mthong dang / / thabs la yang ni mkhas pa dang / / gzungs rnams dang ni smon lam dang / / ting 'dzin gsum du shes par bya/ / chos kyi mdo ni rnam pa bzhi/ /

Summary verses: Shame, firmness, and tirelessness, Knowledge of treatises and the world, Likewise, the correct forms of reliance And the forms of informative knowledge, The accumulations, the qualities Conducive to enlightenment, Quiescence, insight, skillful means, The retentions, aspirational prayer, The three concentrations that ought to be known, And the four summary statements.
SHAME AND ABASHMENT [I.17.1]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi ngo tsha shes pa dang / khrel yod pa gang zhe na/ de ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa gnyis su rig par bya ste/ ngo bo nyid dang gnas so/ / byang chub sems dpa' kha na ma tho ba kun du spyod pa na bdag gi cha ma yin par shes nas 'dzem pa ni ngo tsha shes pa'o/ / de nyid la gzhan dag la 'jigs shing gus pas 'dzem pa ni khrel yod pa'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i 'dzem pa de yang rang bzhin gyis shas che ba yin na goms pa lta ci smos te/ byang chub sems dpa'i ngo tsha shes pa dang / khrel yod pa'i ngo bo nyid ni de lta bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what are the shame and abashment of bodhisattvas? In brief, they should be understood in two ways: in terms of (1) their essential nature and (2) their basis. Shame[1033] is a bodhisattva’s [sense of] embarrassment [that is felt] toward objectionable conduct through having realized its impropriety as relates to oneself. Abashment[1034] is the [sense of] embarrassment [that is felt] toward that very same object out of respect for, or fear[1035] of, others. This [sense of] embarrassment [that is felt] by a bodhisattva is naturally strong, not to mention after it has been developed through repeated practice. This is how a bodhisattva’s shame and abashment should be understood in terms of their essential nature.

gnas ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa bzhi ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i bya ba la nan tan mi byed pa la 'dzem pa gang yin pa de ni gnas dang po'o/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i bya ba ma yin pa la nan tan byed pa la 'dzem pa gang yin pa de ni gnas gnyis pa'o/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i bdag nyid kyi sdig pa 'chab pa la 'dzem pa gang yin pa de ni gnas gsum pa'o/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i bdag nyid kyi 'dod pa skyes pa ston pa dang bcas pa zhar las byung ba la 'dzem pa gang yin pa de ni gnas bzhi pa ste/ gnas de ni de lta bu yin par rig par bya'o/ /

On the other hand, their basis, in brief, is fourfold. The embarrassment [that is felt] with regard to failing to carry out the practice that a bodhisattva ought to pursue is the first basis. Likewise, the embarrassment [that is felt] with regard to performing activities that a bodhisattva ought to avoid is the second basis. Likewise, a bodhisattva’s embarrassment [that is felt] with regard to the concealment of his or her evil deeds is the third basis. Likewise, a bodhisattva’s embarrassment [that is felt] with regard to the regret that arises [in response to] his or her own [wrongdoing], along with [the embarrassment that is felt] toward the object that is necessarily relied upon afterward, is the fourth basis.[1036] This is how [shame and abashment] should be understood in terms of their basis.
FIRMNESS [I.17.2]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i brtan pa'i stobs bskyed pa gang zhe na/ de yang rnam pa gnyis su blta bar bya ste/ ngo bo nyid dang gnas so/ / nyon mongs pa can gyi sems yang dag par sdom pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i dbang du mi 'gro ba dang / sdug bsngal dang du len pa'i ngang tshul can nyid dang / 'jigs shing skrag pa rnam pa sna tshogs mang po mi bzad pa mngon du byung ba dag gis kyang yang dag par sbyor ba las mi g.yo ba dang / rang bzhin gyis snying stobs dang ldan pa 'am/ so sor brtags pas brtan pa 'di ni brtan pa'i stobs bskyed pa'i ngo bo nyid yin par rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s development of firmness? This [quality] also should be regarded in two ways: in terms of (1) its essential nature and (2) its basis. The quality of restraining one’s mind when it has become afflicted, the quality of not allowing oneself to come under the power of the mental afflictions, the quality of having a nature that tolerates suffering, the quality of not wavering from correct practice even in the face of many different and substantial kinds of fear and terror, and the firmness that [arises] either from possessing courage naturally or through careful reflection should be understood as the essential nature of the development of firmness.

byang chub sems dpa'i brtan pa'i stobs bskyed pa de'i gnas ni mdor bsdu na rnam pa lnga yod par rig par bya ste/ 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal rnam pa sna tshogs dang phrad pa dang / 'dul ba las gyur pa'i log par 'jug pa rnam pa sna tshogs dang / yun ring por sems can rnams kyi don gyi phyir 'khor ba khas blangs pa dang / phas kyi rgol ba dag gis nyams bskyod kyang 'khor phal po che'i nang du chos ston pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i gzhi thams cad khas blangs te/ rgya che zhing zab pa'i chos nyan pa ni gnas lnga par rig par bya'o/ /

In brief, the basis for that development of firmness by bodhisattvas should be understood as being fivefold. [The five aspects are] (1) the occurrence of a variety of samsaric forms of suffering and a variety of mistaken forms of practice that are carried out by disciples; (2) the acceptance of a samsara that is very long-lasting for the sake of sentient beings; (3) teaching the Dharma in a great assembly while one’s views are being scrutinized by rivals; (4) the acceptance of all the bodhisattva precepts; and (5) listening to the profound and extensive forms of the Dharma.[1037]
TIRELESSNESS [I.17.3]

de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi yang dag pa'i sbyor ba thams cad la rgyu lngas yid yongs su mi skyo bar rig par bya'o/ / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' ni rang bzhin gyis stobs dang ldan pa yin te/ des na yongs su skyo bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yang des yid yongs su mi skyo ba de nyid yang dang yang du goms par byas pa yin te/ des na yongs su skyo bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yang thabs kyis yongs su zin pa'i brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang ldan pa yin te/ des na snga phyi bye brag yang dag par mthong bas yongs su skyo bar mi 'gyur ro/ / shes rab kyis so sor rtog pa'i stobs drag po dang ldan pa yin te/ des na yongs su skyo bar mi 'gyur ro/ / sems can rnams la byang chub sems dpa' de'i snying rje'i sems dang snying brtse ba'i sems drag po rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par nye bar gnas pa yin te/ des na yongs su skyo bar mi 'gyur ro/ /

Regarding this [topic], the bodhisattvas’ quality of remaining mentally tireless in relation to all their correct forms of practice should be understood as being due to five causes. (1) Here a bodhisattva is naturally strong, which keeps him or her from becoming tired. (2) Moreover, that very attribute of remaining mentally tireless is cultivated repeatedly, which keeps him or her from becoming tired. (3) He or she is endowed with [the ability] to initiate a [form of] effort that is supported by skillful means, which, by enabling [the bodhisattva] to perceive different [circumstances] as they occur successively, keeps him or her from becoming tired. (4) [The bodhisattva] possesses a sharp and powerful [form of] discriminating wisdom, which keeps him or her from becoming tired. (5) A bodhisattva’s compassionate mind and sympathetic mind remain fixed with great intensity upon sentient beings continually and uninterruptedly, which keeps him or her from becoming tired.
KNOWLEDGE OF TREATISES [I.17.4]

de la byang chub sems dpa'i bstan bcos shes pa gang zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rig pa'i gnas lnga po dag las brtsams te/ ming gi tshogs dang / tshig gi tshogs dang / yi ge'i tshogs dang ldan pa'i chos gzhan las legs par bzung ste/ kha don legs par byang ba yin/ chos kyi don de nyid kyang gzhan las legs par thos pa yin/ yang na bdag nyid kyis legs par bsams shing / legs par brtags pa yin te/ de ltar byang chub sems dpa' chos shes shing don shes pas chos dang don de nyid mi brjed par bya ba'i phyir dang / chos dang don gyi bye brag sar pa sar pa dag gong nas gong du shes par bya ba'i phyir sbyor ba mi gtong ba yin no/ / thos pa dang bsam pa'i mthar thug pa des chos dang don de la dus gzhan na yongs su smin par byas pa'i dad pa thob pa yang yin te/ rnam pa de dag gis na byang chub sems dpa'i bstan bcos shes pa tshad med pa dang / yongs su rdzogs pa dang / phyin ci ma log pa nyid du rig par bya'o/ /

Regarding this [topic], what is a bodhisattva’s knowledge of treatises?
